TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Unrealised Capital Gains and Losses
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

The Petition of the undersigned shows: That the laws passed in December 1992 counting unrealised capital gains on shares held by pensioners as income for the purposes of the social security income test are unfair, illogical and discriminatory, and should be repealed as soon as is practicable.

Your Petitioners ask that the Senate should: (1) note that the Liberal and National Parties now oppose the laws after voting for them in December; (2) condemn the government for persisting with the laws; and (3) take whatever steps are necessary to achieve the repeal of the laws mentioned above.

PETITION.TITLE: Unrealised Capital Gains and Losses
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned shows:

We the undersigned citizens respectfully submit that the Government's proposals to treat unrealised capital gains and losses on listed securities as income under the Social Security Act 1991 and the Veterans' Entitlement Act 1986 be abandoned. The Petitioners note particularly that:
1. The majority of Australians regard the proposed method of calculating unrealised capital gains and losses as unfair and inequitable;
2. The implementation of this measure will have a deleterious effect on national savings and investments of pensioners and veterans;
3. We regard the Government's estimates of cost saving as spurious.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: HMAS Huon
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned shows:

PETITION.PARA: We the undersigned citizens respectfully submit that the Keating Government's decision to close down HMAS Huon is clearly and demonstrably wrong and should be reversed having regard to:
(a)The fact that HMAS Huon has been part of the Royal Australian Navy in Tasmania for over 80 years;
(b)It has continually demonstrated itself to be a most efficient shore-based designated Naval facility and Headquarters for the Royal Australian Navy in Tasmania;

(c)Its closure will place at risk the immediate future in Tasmania of 25 permanent Royal Australian Navy personnel, 108 active Reservists and 40 inactive Reservists and in addition will deprive the Naval Reserve Cadets of their Tasmanian Divisional Headquarters; and, the fact that only a miserable $250,000 will be allegedly saved out of the National Defence budget of over $9 billion,

and therefore call upon the Keating Government to immediately reverse the decision to close HMAS Huon and to give a commitment that it will continue to be the Headquarters of the Royal Australian Navy in Tasmania.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Constitutional Monarchy
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned shows:

We the undersigned citizens respectfully submit that Australia, under its constitutional system based on the Monarchy, is one of the world's most oldest and most successful democracies and has led the world in many democratic reforms.
Our constitution, based on the Monarchy, has:

PETITION.PARA: maintained national unity in a federation

PARA.TAB: Your petitioners therefore request that:
Australia should remain a democratic constitutional Monarchy with Her Majesty, the Queen of Australia as our Head of State and represented in Australia by a Governor-General.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

The operations of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission (ATSIC), the Aboriginal Legal Service (ALS) and any other body, company or corporation which receives funding from ATSIC with particular regard to:

TAB.TAB: (a)the accountability of ATSIC, ALS and ATSIC-funded bodies and individuals for the way in which they receive, spend and publicly account for taxpayers' money with particular reference to project grant money;

Dear Senator Loosley
Thank you for your letter of 6 September 1993 regarding the Australian Dried Fruits Board (AGM) Regulations, Statutory Rules 1993 No 144.

I refer to your first point on why the Regulations were not made until 22 June 1993. The Australian Horticultural Corporation Act 1987 requires `product boards' to hold an annual general meeting within twelve months of the end of each financial year. I authorised the preparation of drafting instructions on 26 August 1992. My Department prepared drafting instructions which were then circulated to the Australian Dried Fruits Board (ADFB), the Australian Horticultural corporation (AHC) and the Australian Dried Fruits Association (ADFA) for consultation and comment. Actual instructions were sent to the Attorney General's Department (AGs) on 2 October 1992, nearly thirty-eight weeks before the scheduled date for the holding of the AGM. The first draft was received from the AGs on 22 January 1993. Subsequent drafts were received on 4 February 1993, 7 April 1993 and the final draft on 18 June 1993 just two working days before the scheduled date for the AGM. The AGs have told my Department of difficulties for them with other significant priorities, staff movements and staff sickness.

The annual general meeting of the ADFB for the period 1991-92 was held on 23 June 1993 as the preferred day by the industry. The ADFB and the industry peak body, the ADFA, advised my Department, during the consultation period prior to the drafting of the Australian Horticultural Corporation Amendment Act 1991, that the best time to hold an AGM would be the period late May to June. The actual date of the AGM had been set tentatively by the industry and the ADFB about twelve months in advance. Culturing practices and harvesting and drying procedures preclude growers attending an AGM till late in the financial year, after the dried fruit is delivered to the packing sheds.

During the regulations drafting period, my Department consulted closely with the ADFB, the ADFA and the AHC. In accordance with the enabling Act the AGM was advertised in the national press and information was published in industry journals on various aspects of the AGM. From correspondence my Department has received from the ADFB, the AGM was held in substantial compliance with the regulations. The AGs, in its advice to my Department, confirmed this view.

I would now like to address some of the detailed concerns in your letter. In regard to Regulations 4 and 5, the ADFB wrote to the packers on 26 November 1992, seeking the information subsequently set out in the regulations. With the notice to the packers, the ADFB included a copy of the drafting instructions as had been submitted to AGs on 2 October 1992. All the packers co-operated and supplied the information used to make the register of levy and export charge payers.

The letter of 26 November 1992, referred to above, in fact substantially complied with Regulation 5. Regulation 5 was a suggested inclusion by the drafter and was accepted by the industry after the packers had already supplied the required information or had agreed to supply that information. Therefore, it did not have any effect on the AGM for the 1991/92 period.

Regulation 8 was substantially followed by the ADFB with correspondence of 14 April 1993 to all levy and export charge payers containing grower registration number, fruit tonnage and voting entitlement. Procedures to alter any of the levy or export charge payer's information was provided in an attached four-page leaflet. The Annual Report was also included in this mail out of 14 April 1993.

In regard to your comments on Regulation 10(1), in practice, the ADFB followed the procedures set down in the then draft regulations by way of the "Notice of Annual General Meeting". This information was also contained in the letter of 14 April 1993 to all levy and export charge payers, to which was attached the four page information leaflet about the AGM. The requirements of the then-draft Regulation 19 were also covered in the same letter and information leaflet.

By the time Regulation 11 was being finalised by the drafter, consultation with my Department had established that the ADFB had not received any notice of motion by the due date, so it could not have a direct effect on the AGM arrangements. I am advised that Regulation 11 is drafted along similar lines to other legislation in this portfolio, covering AGMs for the Australian Meat and Livestock Corporation and the Australian Wool Corporation. The reference in Regulation 11(1)(b) to Regulation 18(2) should be to Regulation 19(2) and the heading of the Explanatory Statement should be 1993, not 1992.

Amendments to correct these drafting errors and to address your concerns about the clarity of Regulation 11(2) will be made as soon as practicable. Attachment A of the Explanatory Statement was initialled by the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories, on my behalf, on 16 June 1993. I do not know why your Committee did not receive this Attachment. Because it explains the separate Regulations, it is the same as Attachment A of the Explanatory Memorandum.
Thank you for bringing these matters to my attention.
Yours sincerely
Simon Crean

Dear Mal

Thank you for your letter of 30 September 1993 to the Assistant Treasurer concerning Occupational Superannuation Standards Regulations (Amendment), Statutory Rules 1993 No.189 and No. 213. As you are aware the Senate is scheduled to consider a motion to disallow these Regulations.

With respect to Statutory Rules No. 189, your Committee specifically asked for advice on the effect of sub-regulation 18BB(3) on contracts partially performed. In order to assist both your Committee's and the Senate's consideration of this issue, I attach an opinion provided by the Attorney-General's Department that concludes the regulation has no effect on matters done before its date of commencement.

With respect to Statutory Rules No. 213 you indicated that it seemed appropriate that the discretions conferred upon the Commissioner in Regulations 5AAA(4—5), 5AAD(3) and (5), 18Q(3) and 18QA(2), and (4) should be subject to AAT review.
You also noted that both the parent Act and the principal Regulations provide for such review of other discretions.

Regarding the latter point, all of the reviewable decisions listed in Section 3(1) of the Occupational Superannuation Standards Act (OSSA) are decisions made under Sections of the Act. There is no provision for decisions made under the Regulations to be reviewable.

However, in practice, decisions made under the Regulations are reviewable because the matters prescribed by the Regulations are steps along the way to a determination of the Commissioner under s.12 OSSA which is a decision that can be reviewed by the AAT. More detail on how the Commissioner's decisions are open to review is provided below.

Regulation 5AAA derives from the power to prescribe operating standards for superannuation entities [ss 7(1), 8(1) and 8A(1)]. The prescription of standards is not open to administrative review under OSSA. In particular regulation 5AAA relates to the duty of the Commissioner to register a prospectus when he is of the opinion that the prospectus complies with the applied provisions. Until the prospectus is registered the fund cannot attract members or accept contributions [regulations 5AAD(3) and (5)]. In practice an opportunity to appeal to the AAT would be of no practical benefit to the trustee because of the time involved, since trustees require prospectuses in order to carry on business. Thus this is a commercial process for which direct administrative review as performed by the AAT would be inappropriate.

A breach of regulation 5AAA standards is a breach for which the Commissioner may issue a notice of non-compliance under section 12 of OSSA. Since a decision of the Commissioner under section 12 is a "reviewable decision", which may be reviewed in full by the AAT, the provisions of regulation 5AAA are, in practice, accessible by the AAT.

The discretion of the Commissioner referred to in regulation 18Q(3) to form the conclusion that a fund satisfies, or should be treated as if it satisfied, superannuation fund conditions, and the discretion referred to in regulations 18QA(2) and (4) to disregard a breach of fund conditions and, therefore, treat the fund as complying with the prescribed standards also both refer to that function which is performed under section 12 of OSSA. Therefore these discretions are also in practice reviewable by the AAT.

I trust that this information allays your Committee's concerns. In view of the interest of the Senate Select Committee on Superannuation in Clause 64 of the Superannuation Industry (Supervision) Bill and the general issue of review of discretions, I have copied this letter to Senator Watson for his information.
Yours sincerely
GARY JOHNS

Dear Senator Colston
Thank you for your letter of 30 September 1993 outlining the Committee's concerns in respect of the amended regulations under the Australian Sports Drug Agency Act 1990.

The integrity of the drug testing program in Australia depends on the ability of ASDA to test competitors at short notice and to ensure that they are given little or no prior warning of a proposed test. This prevents competitors from withdrawing from an event or taking other action to negate the test. This was the intention of the original subregulation 8(7) which prevented the disclosure of the identity of a competitor selected for testing until the competitor is asked to provide the sample.

To ensure the interests of the competitors are safeguarded, provision was also included in the original regulations (regulation ll(l)(j)) for all competitors to be advised, as soon as they are notified of their selection, that they are entitled to have a representative (parent, guardian, coach etc) present during the collection and testing of the sample. This is also set out in the Information Sheet that the competitors are provided with (Schedule 2). This provision remains in the regulations and would appear, generally, to address the concerns expressed in your letter.

In practice, subregulation 8(7) created a number of problems. It prevented ASDA officials from consulting with and seeking assistance from parents, coaches, officials, etc in identifying and locating competitors selected for testing. Hence, this provision was omitted and replaced by regulations (8(7)—8(13)).

These provisions have been made discretionary rather than mandatory because there are circumstances where it is not possible to notify third parties first. This would apply, for example, to competition testing where samples may be required immediately from the major place getters in particular events. In this situation it is often not possible to notify a third party prior to the notification of the competitor.

The privacy implications relating to the prior notification of a third party are also relevant in this regard. The Privacy Commissioner supports the discretionary provisions in the regulations and has observed that a significant number of competitors who are under 18 years of age may prefer to be contacted direct by ASDA officials and not through a parent or guardian.

ASDA is currently preparing a manual of procedures to be followed by field staff. The manual will include details of procedures to be followed in the notification of competitors selected for testing. Care will be taken to ensure that the intent of the regulations is complied with and that field staff apply appropriate sensitivity in dealing with competitors where discretionary provisions apply.

In view of the existing provisions to protect the rights of the competitors, advice from the Privacy Commissioner and the practical difficulties which would arise if the regulations were changed, I believe it is appropriate to keep the regulations in their current form.

I trust this advice deals with the Committee's concerns. If you have further queries, officers of ASDA (Mr Stephen Richards Phone 281 1553; Fax 281 1226) and my Department (Mr Graham Dempster—Phone 274 1850; Fax 274 1825) are available to discuss them with you.
Yours sincerely
ROS KELLY

"Whereas the United Nations Human Rights Commission unanimously adopted, on 5 March 1993, a resolution deploring the human rights situation in Burma and the continued arrest of Daw Aung San Suu Kyi; and

"Whereas, on 12 March 1992, the Committee on Foreign Relations of the (US) Senate unanimously stated that (1) the SLORC does not represent the Burmese people and should transfer power to the winners of the 1990 elections, (2) United States military attaches should be withdrawn from Burma, and (3) the United States should oppose United Nations Development Program funding for Burma. Now, therefore, be it
"Resolved, That it is the sense of the Senate that the President, the Secretary of State, and other United States Government representatives should—

SPEECH.PARA: (1)seek the immediate release of Daw Aung San Suu Kyi from arrest and the transfer of power to the winners of the 1990 elections in Burma; and
(2)encourage the adoption by the United Nations Security Council of an arms embargo and other sanctions against the regime of the State Law and Order Council in Burma.";

PARA.TAB: (b)notes the Australian Government's continued support for human rights in Burma;
(c)urges the Government to work with the United States Government and the United Nations to achieve peaceful democratic change in Burma; and
(d)requests that a copy of this resolution be forwarded to the leader of the United States Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner Sen J.P.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: VETERANS' AFFAIRS; DEFENCE SCIENCE AND PERSONNEL

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Manager of Government Business in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I table the explanatory memorandum, and move:

PARA.TAB: That this bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The speech read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: This bill contains a technical amendment to the Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918 to remove a doubt surrounding the composition of a federal redistribution committee for a state.

Redistribution committees for each state and territory subject to a redistribution must be appointed `as soon as practicable' after the commencement of a redistribution. For a state, the redistribution committee must, under current legislation, include the Surveyor-General for the state, or the Deputy Surveyor-General if the Surveyor-General is unavailable.

However, both Queensland and Western Australia have abolished the Office of Surveyor-General, leaving a doubt as to the legal composition of a redistribution committee in those states, and any others that follow a similar path. This bill provides for alternative arrangements to be made in these cases.

The bill provides that, where there is no Office of Surveyor-General in a state, the state minister responsible for land, surveying and mapping matters may nominate the person who, in the opinion of that minister, holds the equivalent office or, if that person is unavailable, the person who holds the office equivalent to the Office of Deputy Surveyor-General. If that person is also unavailable, or there is no such person, the Governor-General shall nominate a senior officer of the Australian Public Service from the state concerned. This will ensure that, under any scenario, an appropriate officer from the state concerned will serve on the redistribution committee for that state.

Current population trends indicate a likelihood that a federal redistribution will commence early next year in Queensland, Victoria and the Australian Capital Territory. It is necessary that this amending legislation be in place by then.
I commend the bill to the Senate and present the explanatory memorandum to the bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the following matter be referred to the Committee of Privileges:

Whether Dr Philip Nitschke was threatened with, or was subjected to, any penalty or injury on account of his evidence to the Standing Committee on Industry, Science, Technology, Transport, Communications and Infrastructure, and whether any contempt was committed by any action taken in relation to Dr Nitschke.

SPEECH.PARA: Dr Nitschke appeared before the Senate Standing Committee on Industry, Science, Technology, Transport, Communications and Infrastructure in Darwin on 20 July 1993 in relation to a reference on disaster management. Dr Nitschke subsequently wrote to the committee's secretary, Mr Robert Diamond, on 14 August 1993 claiming that his employment had been disadvantaged as a result of giving evidence.

PARA.TAB: In response to the claim, I wrote to Dr Nitschke on 24 August 1993 asking him to outline how he had actually been disadvantaged. Dr Nitschke responded in a letter dated 5 September 1993, in which he advised the committee that on the same day as his appearance before the committee the Minister for Health and Community Services in the Northern Territory, the Hon. M.A. Reed MLA, issued a press release containing comments which, combined with subsequent developments, represents clear evidence of the adverse effects of speaking to the Senate inquiry. Dr Nitschke also advised the committee that his contract had not been renewed for 1994 and that such a decision was `without precedent'.

I also wrote to the minister on 22 September 1993 and to the general manager of the Royal Darwin Hospital on 30 September 1993 seeking any information that they may have wished to provide about Dr Nitschke's claims. The committee has received replies from the minister and the general manager denying Dr Nitschke's claims. The committee, having considered the information available to it, concluded that a case of breach of privilege may exist and requested me to write to Mr President for consideration of this matter to be referred to the privileges committee. As the result of a request from opposition senators, the committee reconsidered this matter, reconsidered our decision, and at a meeting this morning a majority of the committee decided that the original decision should remain.

The simple position is that it is the view of the committee, and in conformity with the procedures laid down, that there may be a situation that should be considered. That is all we are required to do as a committee. The past practice has been for the President to consider the situation and then refer that matter to the privileges committee. I believe it is appropriate that the Committee of Privileges, of which I am a member, carefully gives consideration to the conflicting arguments that have been put forward, and bring a report back to this chamber, and I have moved accordingly.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are two matters I wish to raise in relation to this particular motion. The first one is a technical, Senate procedures matter. The Senate will recall that last year it unfortunately decided to join the Senate Standing Committee on Industry, Technology and Commerce with the Senate Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure. At the time the transport, communications and infrastructure committee, of which Senator Panizza and I, amongst others, were members, was in the throes of an investigation into disaster management. By arrangement—I do not think it was terribly formal—it was decided that Senator Panizza and I would continue.
—It was.

—Senator Panizza tells me that it was formally done. It was formally decided that Senator Panizza and I would continue on that committee as members of that committee, only for the purposes of completing the disaster management inquiry. This particular matter of privileges arises out of evidence given to that disaster management inquiry in Darwin. I think the people at that inquiry were—and Senator Panizza, Senator Murphy or Senator Childs will no doubt correct me—the chairman, Senator Murphy, Senator Panizza, myself and, I think, Senator Chapman. I do not think there were others there. Someone will correct me if I am wrong, but there were not too many other senators there.

PARA.TAB: As a result, of course, Senator Panizza and I were both totally involved in that matter. In the first discussion on privileges when the matter was raised in the committee back here—and Senator Panizza and I both took part in the first discussion on whether the matter should go to the privileges committee—I argued against it because I thought, firstly, it was not an appropriate case to waste the time of the privileges committee. Secondly, I thought there were political overtones to Dr Nitschke's stand. As a result of that, the committee decided to write to the Darwin hospital to seek a response.

The point of my concern, and I cast no aspersions on the chairman here—I understand the chairman has been acting on advice in doing this—is that when the matter was again considered by the committee, neither Senator Panizza nor I was even advised that the committee was to meet. Again, today when the committee met we were not even advised that the committee was going to meet. The chairman does have advice, apparently, that because Senator Panizza and I are not officially members of that committee we are not entitled to vote. Even if that advice is correct—and I do not accept that it is—then I would have thought, as a matter of courtesy, the committee might have simply advised Senator Panizza and I, knowing our interest in the matter, and allowed us to participate in the discussions even if we were not able to vote.

I do not have any argument to dispute the advice given to the chairman about whether or not we should have been permitted to be part of those discussions, but it does seem inappropriate considering Senator Panizza and I were formally part of that committee. We were two of the five senators totally involved in the matter. We know what it is about and yet we are not able to participate or vote on a question that arises out of a hearing of that committee. I think this is inappropriate. I have not formally raised this with my colleagues but I would suggest that it is a matter that the procedures committee should perhaps look at to see whether it is an appropriate ruling. If it is an appropriate ruling, perhaps something should be done to enable senators who are officially part of a committee to participate in all aspects of matters arising from an inquiry being conducted by that committee.

On the substantive matter in question, in the meetings that I was involved in I argued against having this matter referred to the privileges committee. I am told that the privileges committee is chock-a-block full of work; it has a lot of references before it and I would have thought that this particular matter was one which really should not waste the time of that particular committee. The complaints are by Dr Nitschke. He is a well-known activist in Darwin who becomes involved in political issues in Darwin—political issues that are always against the current government of the Northern Territory. Dr Nitschke claimed that he was discriminated against in his employment as—

TALK.START.PARA: —He sounds like a great man to me.
—You would no doubt think he was.
—Personally.
—Yes, personally, Senator West.
—He is doing no more than his public duty.

—I do not care what his views are or what he wants to put forward, but when it comes down to using the forms of this chamber to promote a political cause in another state, in another parliament, with another government, I think it is most inappropriate. His complaint is that he was discriminated against in his employment. Dr Nitschke claimed this because the minister happened to issue a press release on the day after we were there. I thought the matter would have been over and done with very simply because the evidence clearly showed, and Dr Nitschke admitted, that, subsequent to him giving evidence to us and subsequent to the minister's press release, he was offered a job and re-employed for another six months. I would have thought that was the end of it.

PARA.TAB: His claim was that he had been disaffected in his employment and the evidence—his own evidence—clearly shows that he was re-employed, I think about a month later. It seemed to me it was a silly complaint, one with no justification, one that really should not give Dr Nitschke a forum to promote his view of politics and one that really should not waste the time of this chamber. I have subsequently been told that Dr Nitschke has had a series of incidents involving political comment on his employers and the health department which I understand have been documented to the committee.

If Dr Nitschke was going to be sacked because he had spoken against the Northern Territory government, there had been oodles of other opportunities for the government to do it. It did not have to wait until our committee came to Darwin and he got up and made his complaints against the government; he had done that many times before. If the government was going to be vindictive, it would have sacked him then. Why wait for our committee? Again, it seems to me that the reasons advanced by Dr Nitschke were inappropriate, wrong and should not waste the time of this committee. I understand that subsequent to all that Dr Nitschke has since been offered a job at the termination of his current employment. That completely runs against his claim and the reason he says the matter should be referred to the committee. He says he is being victimised and yet not only—

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you guaranteeing he has got the job?
—He was employed, Senator Burns, a month after—
—Are you guaranteeing he has got the job?

—I do not have to guarantee it because the facts speak for themselves. About one month after—do not hold me to this—he gave evidence he was re-employed. That is a matter of fact. I do not have to guarantee anything. It is on the record and he admits it. Subsequent to that—as I understand it—in the normal course of events, he was again offered employment. This simply flies in the face of reality. I understand that he is one of the leftie antinuclear people. He was probably a waterside worker at one stage too, was he?
—We will see whether he pops up as a candidate.

—Perhaps in an upcoming Northern Territory election. My concern is that there is no basis for referring this matter to the privileges committee. I also raise the additional concern that it would disappoint me greatly if this chamber and this parliament were being used as part of a political campaign, particularly in another state and relating to another government. I may be doing Dr Nitschke a wrong by attributing those motives to him. If I am, I suppose he will ask for my speech to be referred to the privileges committee. The whole thing seems to be most inappropriate. It seems to be part of a political campaign in an area which does not involve this parliament. I am very disappointed that the Australian Labor Party has used its numbers to refer this matter to the privileges committee. I have argued that this matter—and I would have argued it again, had I been invited to the meetings of the privileges committee—is an inappropriate reference for the privileges committee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Macdonald has raised two issues. The first of those issues relates to those members who are either temporary members of a committee because it is a particular reference, or who have become temporary members of a committee because the reference has been shifted from one committee to another—the first committee having been disbanded. As I understand it, that issue has been dealt with by the Clerk. Advice has been given that it is the ongoing members of the committee who rightly consider these matters. Senator Macdonald has taken issue with that advice. I think his suggestion that the matter be reconsidered is an appropriate way to deal with it. However, for the time being, I think we are left with that advice. It seems to me that it is appropriate that the committee should have reconsidered this matter in the way in which it did this morning.

PARA.TAB: Turning to the other issue in relation to the reference of Dr Nitschke's complaint to the privilege's committee, it seems to me that what the industry, science and technology committee was asked to do, and did do, was simply to consider whether there was sufficient evidence for this matter to be investigated. The committee was not attempting to determine whether the evidence amounted to a breach of privilege but, rather, whether there was sufficient evidence for that matter to be considered. I am really surprised at Senator Macdonald's outburst, particularly against Dr Nitschke. The evidence clearly shows that Dr Nitschke had been employed over quite a long period of time and that immediately—not the next day—following his evidence to the committee a press release was issued which stated that `Dr Nitschke has got some sad news coming if he thinks the Territory government is going to waste large amounts of valuable health funding satisfying his ideology'.

It seems to me that all sorts of people having all sorts of ideologies come before Senate committees. Dr Nitschke happens to be one who has a professional standing which has been recognised by the Darwin hospital over a long period of time and which competently allows him to provide advice to this committee on disasters in relation to the very matter on which he was giving evidence, namely, radiation hazards in Darwin. Irrespective of the particular political background from which he comes, even if there was a political motivation—and I very much doubt that—he has a perfect right to appear before a committee and put his professional point of view without any threat at all as to his employment, or any other threat.

It is interesting that, on the 12th of this month, Dr Nitschke wrote to me and sent down some documents. I will table these documents with the approval of the Senate in a moment. In his opening paragraph he says:

SPEECH.PARA: Following our phone conversation today, there was a surprise media release from the Northern Territory Department of Health stating that they had offered me a 12 month contract at the Darwin Hospital. This is pleasing news, but coming after two months of hell here and three days before the Senate consideration, it makes one a bit cynical.

I think the members of this chamber have a right to be rather cynical also. As I think the Clerk of the Senate again has pointed out, it is irrelevant whether a threat is actually carried through—whether or not Dr Nitschke actually lost his job. The fact is that a threat was made and was sustained for a considerable period of time; and, on the eve of the reference of this matter to the privileges committee, miraculously a job appears and Dr Nitschke is reappointed.

PARA.TAB: I am not trying to canvass the decision that the privileges committee might make, but it seems to me that that evidence should be sufficient for the matter to be referred to the privileges committee. Dr Nitschke—and when he appeared before the committee he did not hide the fact—has for a long time been a member of the MAPW, the Medical Association for the Prevention of War. He holds strong views in relation to radiation dangers. That is his right, and it his right to put those views before any Senate committee he chooses, without threat of any action being taken against him.

They may be views totally different from the views that Senator Macdonald holds; they probably are. Almost certainly they are. I suspect that might be the fundamental reason for Senator Macdonald's objection to this matter going to the privileges committee.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I rise on a point of order concerning relevancy. I believe the motion is whether or not we refer this matter to the privileges committee, and whether Dr Nitschke's qualifications are what Senator Coulter says they are or not, I do not think is a matter for debate. There is no debate on his qualifications. The question is whether or not we refer it to the privileges committee. And I think that you, Mr Acting Deputy President, should bring him to order.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator McKiernan)—I do not believe that this is a point of order. It is an argument in support of a reference going to the privileges committee.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am simply trying to establish that there is a prima facie case that this man was adversely dealt with immediately after he gave evidence to the industry, science and technology committee on a particular matter on which he holds strong views. Those views are admittedly different from those held by the Northern Territory Health Commission and are different from Senator Macdonald's views. Nonetheless, he has a perfect right to put those views and he should not be threatened as a consequence. That is the point. He has been—
—We have not seen those.
—Order! Senator Macdonald, interjections are disorderly, particularly when you are not in your own seat.

—There is a sufficiently good case in this instance for the matter to go to the privileges committee. Again, just taking up Senator Macdonald's last point, this was not a case of only the henchmen of the Labor Party supporting this reference; I strongly support this reference.
—Your comments, Senator Coulter, and those of Senator Macdonald, about the procedure committee having a look at the membership of committees, I will draw to the attention of the President.
—May I table the documents to which I was referring. They are a letter from Dr Nitschke and the independent AMA review of the dispute at the Royal Darwin Hospital.

PARA.TAB: Leave not granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek to speak very briefly on this matter. As a member of the Senate Standing Committee on Industry, Science, Technology, Transport, Communications and Infrastructure who was at the hearing and at subsequent meetings of the committee that considered this matter, I think it is important to note that what we really have to look at here is whether or not there was any doubt as to the matters that might affect Dr Nitschke in respect of his employment. On both occasions the committee found that to be the case. It found that also on the basis of advice given to the committee and to the chairman of the committee by the clerk and by the President. It is not a matter of considering any view or position that Dr Nitschke holds, whether it has political overtones or anything else, and whether the privileges committee is busy or not is not relevant.

PARA.TAB: It was a matter of the committee considering whether there was any doubt as to whether there might be any effect or threat contained within the circumstances that surrounded Dr Nitschke's giving evidence to the committee. Contrary to what Senator Ian Macdonald has said, the committee found, by majority, that that was the case. In further consideration of the matter today, it also found that to be the case, and it ought to be referred to the privileges committee because that is the appropriate committee to consider whether or not there is a case to answer. I do not believe it is a matter for this chamber to consider. Rather, the issue has been determined by the committee, and the motion put by the chairman ought to be carried.

I repeat what Senator Coulter said in respect of the meeting today. It was not the Australian Labor Party using its numbers. The matter was decided by majority, and I believe that some of Senator Ian Macdonald's colleagues there supported that position. Senator Macdonald did leave out one honourable senator who was in attendance at the meeting in Darwin, and that was Senator Ferguson. Quite frankly, what Senator Macdonald has done is to express a view in this chamber about whether the matter or the substance ought to be dealt with by the privileges committee. He has expressed views about the substance of the issue, which I do not believe he should have done. The issue is that there is some doubt. That is the majority view of the committee. We ought to stop this debate, allow the motion to proceed and get the matter appropriately dealt with.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was a member of the Senate Standing Committee on Industry, Science, Technology, Transport, Communications and Infrastructure on that day in Darwin. I believe that I am an official member, having carried over from the original inquiry into major disasters, and that is exactly what we looked into in Darwin on that day. Today's Notice Paper, at page 57, gives the members of that committee. It says:

SPEECH.PARA: Senators Ian Macdonald and Panizza to replace Senators Archer and Ferguson for the consideration of the committee's inquiry into major disasters and large-scale emergencies.

That was the subject of the hearing in Darwin that day. I claimed my living away from home expenses or travelling allowance for being in Darwin that day and they were paid, so I believe that I am an official member and I acted in that way. Senator Ian Macdonald and I were both present that day, and I certainly believe that I was an official member of the committee. I also inform the Senate that on that day in Darwin Senator Coulter was not there.

PARA.TAB: I was not allowed to attend this morning's meeting and a meeting that the committee had previously, the reason being that I am supposedly not a member of the committee. I claim that I am. I took this up with the secretary this morning and he told me that he had advice from the clerk that we were not to be admitted because we were not official members. I claim that I am an official member and I claim that that advice from the clerk is wrong. I am sorry to have to say that while he is in the chamber, although I would prefer to say it while he is here rather than when he is away. I reckon that is wrong because the Senate appointed Senator Ian Macdonald and me to replace those two other honourable senators.

I claim that I am official, so I believe that we should have been admitted to the meeting, because I reckon it is stupid to have the two replacement senators—and I know that Senator Ferguson was in Darwin that day, but he was at that committee unofficially, as far as I can see; in my opinion, anyhow—

TALK.START.PARA: —The fishing inquiry was on as well.

—That is right; the fishing inquiry was on in Darwin at the time. So I claim that, as far as the disaster reference is concerned, he was there more or less as an observer. Anyhow, I reckon it is stupid for a committee to have what went on in the place considered by the two replacement senators, even though I know that Senator Ferguson was there.

PARA.TAB: Senator Coulter said that all the committee had to do was see whether there was enough evidence before the committee to refer it to the privileges committee. His argument may be right to a certain extent, but I believe the two senators that were there listening in person to Dr Nitschke, and any other witness for that matter, are in a far better position to judge, or to read into, the evidence presented on his sacking, or his non-sacking. It was not a sacking, actually; it was a non-renewal of a contract. Dr Nitschke obviously was on a contract which was not renewed, as can happen.

TALK.START.PARA: —Those events took place after the hearing.

—All right. That is the point. I just make the point that he was under contract and then it was not renewed. That is exactly what a contract is—it is for a certain length of time. Let us not go into contract law today, but that is the situation. Senator Ian Macdonald and I having been there, I believe that we are in a far better position. As well as my argument that we were official members of the committee, I believe that we are in a better position to consider the evidence that Dr Nitschke and others, for that matter, gave because we sat in on it.

PARA.TAB: I believe also that whether or not Senator Ian Macdonald and I are official members of the committee and whether we should be able to attend meetings like that should be sorted out by the procedure committee. I said before that I disagreed with the clerk's ruling at the time. I am not going to pretend to be able to judge why Dr Nitschke's contract was not renewed at the time. I am not going to go into that. But from my own inquiries, I believe there are some political overtones; and I am not going to comment on that.

TALK.START.PARA: —What are you doing right now?
—I said I am not going to comment. But—
—You are making totally political statements.

—It is not a political statement. Mr Acting Deputy President, would you like to rule your side of the chamber back into order. Just as a sideline, as a passing shot, I would just like to see whether this Dr Nitschke turns up as a candidate in any future election.
—Oh!

—Just wait a minute. Senator Murphy is jumping the gun. I did not say that he would turn up as a candidate for any particular party. I just said `whether he would turn up as a candidate'—full stop. I did not mention the Labor Party, the Liberal Party, independents, the Democrats or anyone. I just said `if he turns up as a candidate'. That is what I will wait to see. Anyhow, my main complaint is that I believe that Senator Ian Macdonald and I were official members of that committee and should have been allowed into the meeting.

—One must on this matter immediately start to think: why send it to the Senate Committee of Privileges? Really, there is nothing of substance. There is no prima facie case. Why should the privileges committee take up its time? Senator Ian Macdonald said, `If they're busy, it doesn't matter how good the case is, don't send it there. They're too busy'. I would reject that proposition. That is a denial of justice. As far as there is any substance in referring the matter, there have already been two inquiries. The documents have been tabled by Senator Coulter. To me that is fairly substantial and requires the matter to be referred.

PARA.TAB: We have heard a lot of discussion from people who are part-time, sometime members of the Senate Standing Committee on Industry, Science, Technology, Transport, Communications and Infrastructure and from people who are there full time. So one would have to look at—

TALK.START.PARA: —You are not there full time.

—I would say my attendance would compare with that of the senator's. I am there whenever no other business takes me away. I think the industry committee is one of the most important committees in this Senate.
—I have never seen you there.

—Have a look at my attendance over six years. In the way the industry committee operates and the matters it looks at, it operates very differently in terms of people's experience and knowledge of the issues and their interests. The privileges committee has a specialised role. People's desires take them there because they believe that is something that is important. They gather experience as they do it and they do it in a very different way from the way in which the industry committee operates.

PARA.TAB: When the industry committee advertises for witnesses it expects to get quality witnesses and in some numbers, because it wants to ascertain and analyse important information that will allow it to bring down a report that is useful to the community and will show that it really wants to see things improved for people in the community. When it does that, people are fearful that if they give evidence and that evidence shows the organisation to which they belong to be less than efficient or to be biased in some way, they are going to be dealt with because there is this difference. Why would they come to the industry committee? We would then have people with useful information who would be fearful to come there. So it is not only important—

TALK.START.PARA: —You want a whistleblowers committee—

—Yes, as Senator Murphy says, the opposition likes the whistleblowers committee but when someone blows a whistle it gets all upset and it does not want that person protected. I can assure senators that there will not be too many whistleblowers if they are going to be dealt with when they blow the whistle, regardless of what type of whistle it is. It is necessary that the witnesses have the perception they will be protected when they come to our committee.

PARA.TAB: I am not suggesting for a moment that anybody is guilty of anything; what I am suggesting is that there is a case to be considered by the privileges committee. It does seem to me that, given the reports over time that have been handed down, the committee members do appear to be bipartisan, they do appear to look at justice and bring down fairly objective reports.

Not for one moment would I suggest that politics does not come into such a debate. I do not know Dr Nitschke. He believes the nuclear process is dangerous to the world. I agree with him. However, if that is the reason he may have been dealt with in some way, I do not believe that is fair or just. But that is a matter for the privileges committee. I would not argue the thing in substance. I would suggest what is being said here today by the opposition seeks to deny the opportunity to examine the evidence and to bring down an objective decision by way of examination by the privileges committee. I really think that would be disastrous in terms of the future of all inquiries and the standing of the Senate, which must be protected. I certainly support the proposition put by Senator Childs.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will only speak briefly. I had not intended speaking at all, but I think a couple of the comments that have been made warrant some reply. I was present at the hearing in Darwin. I am not a member of the disaster management inquiry but there was a fishing inquiry on at the same time so I was at that meeting and sat in during the evidence. To the best of my knowledge, Senator Burns was not there, which he has admitted, and Senator Coulter was not there either.

PARA.TAB: Senator Coulter raises something which I find rather strange in this particular instance because we have had it mentioned that there may be some political overtones or perhaps some political flag flying. Senator Coulter says that Dr Nitschke wrote to him, a person who was not even present at the inquiry, and yet to the best of my knowledge he certainly did not write to any opposition member of the committee who was present. I presume he wrote to the chairman of the committee but I am not sure, and yet he wrote to Senator Coulter who was not at the hearing.

I would have thought that the fact that he chose Senator Coulter to write to, rather than to any other member of the committee present that day, would suggest that there are some political overtones, particularly since I heard the evidence that he gave that day. It disturbs me somewhat that we do have two inquiries going on at once.

TALK.START.PARA: —So you don't want the privileges committee to have a look at it?

—Just hear me out, Senator Burns. Senator Ian Macdonald and Senator Panizza were formally appointed to continue the disaster management inquiry that had started, prior to the reduction of the number of committees. I was not present the first time the committee met after its meeting in Darwin. Senator Archer, who is a permanent member of the committee, was also away at the time. But apparently the matter of referring this to the privileges committee was discussed at length at that meeting by Senator Macdonald and, I think, Senator Panizza.

PARA.TAB: At the next meeting of the industry, science and technology committee, an item on the agenda was the reference of a matter to the Committee of Privileges. I was unaware at that second meeting of any of the debate that had taken place at the first meeting. It was only subsequent to that second meeting that Senator Ian Macdonald raised with me some of the issues that he has raised today. I think the decision was taken at the second meeting, which I was at—I do not think Senator Archer was there—that we would refer the matter to the Committee of Privileges.

I felt comfortable with that decision as I was unaware of any of the other things that had taken place at the previous meeting with Senator Macdonald and Senator Panizza, which I was not at. Having made the decision earlier to refer the matter to the Committee of Privileges I was quite happy to agree that that should stand. However, I was unaware of many of the issues that Senator Macdonald raised today. They were discussed at a meeting that was held in conjunction with the disaster management inquiry, which I was unable to attend because it was being held at the same time as the fisheries inquiry.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about Nitschke's disaster?

—Senator Burns may well consider Dr Nitschke's position a disaster, but I think a lot of long bows have been drawn today in relation to Dr Nitschke. Senator Coulter suggested that the decision to hire or fire Dr Nitschke was based on the evidence that he gave at the inquiry. We already have, in a letter, a list of other complaints that had no connection at all with the disaster inquiry. I think it is drawing a long bow to suggest that the reason that he was not immediately reappointed was the evidence that he gave. I think that is something that the Committee of Privileges will decide. At this stage, I am quite happy that that should happen. But Senator Coulter is drawing a very long bow in using that as the evidence as to why it should go.

PARA.TAB: Senator Burns also raised the possibility that good quality witnesses may not wish to give evidence before Senate inquiries. I have not been in this place nearly as long as Senator Burns—in his speech he said that he regularly attended meetings and scarcely missed any—so he will have heard a lot more good witnesses than I. At the hearings that I have attended over the past 18 months, I have not heard of anybody not wanting to give evidence before a Senate committee because he was fearful of what might happen, but it may have happened.

I do not think it could be suggested that the work the committees do is in any way less effective because the people who give evidence before committees are not of a high calibre. I believe they are, and have been in all the time I have attended committees. As I said earlier, the decision to refer this to the Committee of Privileges was based on a discussion that took place at a meeting I was not at. So when I did finally get to the meeting that did decide to refer the matter, I was unaware of much of the documentation which we have subsequently received. But having taken that initial decision, I am quite happy that it proceed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Childs Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply—There have been two basic themes of opposition. I wish to deal with the first issue that has been raised by Senator Ian Macdonald and Senator Panizza. Nobody knows better than I the results of amalgamating two committees—the Senate Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure and the Senate Standing Committee on Industry, Technology and Commerce. I have attended just about all the meetings that have occurred as a result of the amalgamation of those two committees. There is a difficulty, and I certainly have no problem with referring to committee arrangements for the situation that has developed. In this industry committee we now have three separate teams representing the opposition, and that has caused a problem. In the first place it causes a problem because the industry committee, following a view that certain people were involved with that committee, had an initial discussion about this privileges reference.

PARA.TAB: Arising from that, we decided to seek advice on what was the appropriate situation, and we had that advice. When one thinks about it, it was correct advice—although I quite accept sending it to the procedure committee because that might codify the situation, so we do not have the upset that Senator Ian Macdonald and Senator Panizza feel because there was something with which they were involved but they were not in on the final decision. The advice was:

SPEECH.PARA: Although the matter of privilege arises out of the particular inquiry, it is not a matter which is wholly part of the inquiry, but relates to the general operations of the Committee, governed by paragraph (18) of Privileges Resolution No. 1. Therefore a decision in relation to it should be taken by the permanent membership of the Committee.

That really is the advice we had, as the basic thing. It is true that the advice included the fact that we could have invited other members of the committee to the committee. But when the committee dealt with it, I suppose in many of our minds the very strong views that Senators Macdonald and Panizza had expressed were well known to us. Honourable senators have had a sample today of their views which are quite up-front and straightforward.

TALK.START.PARA: —They always are.

—Yes, they always are. Therefore, any refinement of that process that prevents misunderstanding and upset would be an advantage. I do not think we have quite had the situation where there are three opposition teams—and that could be replicated on the government side; I am not—
—If you had more members, we would not need to do it.

—The thing about it is that we have such a high quality team that we do not need to replace them. But as chair, I can assure honourable senators that at times I get a bit worn down by the number of committee meetings I have to attend. So that first matter arising from this incident is something that could have a positive result.

PARA.TAB: Nevertheless, the truth of the matter is that Senators Ian Macdonald and Panizza, to some extent, are still under a misapprehension, and Senator Macdonald has said there are political overtones. Of all the honourable senators here, I think Senator Macdonald would acknowledge that he is as politically partisan as they come in representing his point of view. Some on this side would think that he has carried very strongly a political partisan view in this matter. I am a member of the privileges committee, and I have been a member from the seventh report to the 42nd report. I say that because I cannot go too far into the actual dispute—I do not think that is appropriate. I am guided by the resolution, and I will read the pertinent part of clause 18 of the privileges resolution. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: Where the Committee considers that the facts disclose that a person may have been improperly influenced or subjected to or threatened with penalty or injury in respect of evidence which may be or has been given before the Committee, the Committee shall report the facts and its conclusions to the Senate.

Those two words `may' and `shall' where they appear indicate to me that there is a responsibility. I would like to think that, regardless of the political bias of the person charged or charging, I would make sure that he had the opportunity and was given every chance to articulate his point of view in his defence. If that debate took place here in this chamber, as it has started to do today, or if we had agreed with the two honourable senators and had a long argument, which we were moving towards in the committee, we would have denied people justice.

PARA.TAB: Let me give one example. Senator Ian Macdonald in his partisan presentation, which is the other side of the story, has asserted that Dr Nitschke was offered the job, but let me refer to the correspondence from Dr Nitschke. I will mention one paragraph only to illustrate that we could do a disservice to a person in the dispute if we jumped to a conclusion and if we did not have the almost learned examination that will take place in all honesty by members of the privileges committee. Dr Nitschke asserts in correspondence to us, and this is all I can go by:

SPEECH.PARA: The Department put out a media release on Friday claiming that a job offer had just been made. I have had no confirmation of this and am suspicious while they continue to suppress the report that clears me.

I will not go into the case any further. I mention that only to raise a doubt, because it would be wrong if honourable senators made a decision in trying to examine who is right or who is wrong. There is one place to take it, and that is to the privileges committee. I am confident, from my experience on that privileges committee, that it will allow people to present their case and it will finally come down with a report. Then we can go into more detail of the issues that are involved.

PARA.TAB: There is only one other thing to say. It is true that some members of the industry committee may or may not have looked at the Hansard and all the other things, but the important thing is that, at the privileges committee level, if people wish to bring evidence forward, they will have the opportunity, both in writing and, finally, if it is necessary, at a public hearing. I conclude on this point. If we do not send it to the privileges committee, we run a real risk that people will not be able to present their own case. No matter whether some of us have a bit of a case on either side, we will do it a disservice if we do not allow those people to present their case in any way they want to. The appropriate place is the privileges committee. I urge all honourable senators to forget the political overtones or the partisan political feelings that we have all got and allow the matter to go to the proper place to be resolved.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: West Sen S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the report of the Standing Committee on Community Affairs on the alleged misuse of printing facilities at the Department of Social Security.

PARA.TAB: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to move a motion relating to the report.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish to make some very brief comments. In accordance with the agreement that the committee members have made amongst themselves, the majority of our tabling speeches will be incorporated in Hansard. This referral would not need to have been made to the Senate Standing Committee on Community Affairs if at the time of consideration of the estimates more details could have been provided by the department. It is very easy to say that in hindsight.

PARA.TAB: It also brings up one of the issues that will always be confronted by the Senate, which is how to handle the difficult problem of police investigations and other charges that might be laid under Public Service disciplinary acts and things like that. There was uncertainty, and that was the reason given for the delay or the non-provision of full details at the time of the estimates. It is a problem and an issue that the Senate has to grapple with at some stage.

I have been on another estimates committee where we have had cases that are also under investigation that are totally different from this and involve totally different departments. It is a difficult issue for everybody involved to have to deal with. We should also look at whether provision can be made for estimates committees to deal with these sorts of sensitive issues so that they do not require to be referred on to standing committees. That is one of the requests coming out of the report, and it was unanimously agreed to. There is a dissenting report. All the way through there has been a difference of opinion amongst members on some of the other details, as to how much departments should have been able to give and whether they were trying to avoid giving information. It is certainly the view of the majority that that was not the case.

We need to have very clear guidelines and clear recommendations and suggestions as to how we handle the subject of in camera evidence, of which quite a deal was taken in this committee. At the time of taking evidence there were matters still under investigation by the Australian Federal Police and also the end of some disciplinary hearings and charges. How committees respond to that in camera evidence and how committees deal with it when they are writing reports is also an issue where I think all honourable senators would find some further material and clearer guidelines of assistance in handling this difficult issue. I seek leave to incorporate my tabling statement.
Leave granted.

SPEECH.PARA: SENATE STANDING COMMITTEE ON COMMUNITY AFFAIRS REPORT ON ALLEGED MISUSE OF PRINTING FACILITIES AT DSS TABLING STATEMENT
1.I am pleased to table the report of the Committee on the Alleged Misuse of Printing Facilities at the Department of Social Security.

2.This inquiry was referred to the Committee on 10 November 1992, following a report from Estimates Committee D. It was originally to be reported on by 10 December 1992. However, hearings had not been completed by that time and an extension was granted until early in the Autumn sittings of this Parliament. A heavy workload for the Committee and other factors—such as a court case relating to the inquiry—have meant that further extensions have been necessary.

3.There is still some difference of opinion among Committee members about the issues considered. As far as the majority report is concerned, Committee members have taken on board some of the comments made by past and current Departmental officers on a draft of the report and believe that the report as it now stands has assessed all the evidence thoroughly and fairly.
4.The Committee's report states that:
there are no serious problems with the Department's management; and
the Department acted efficiently and appropriately in its response to unauthorised use of Commonwealth goods and facilities.

5.The Committee does consider, however, that Departmental officers, including the former Secretary of the Department, were unnecessarily abrupt and somewhat evasive at the Senate Estimates D Committee hearing of 17 September 1992.

6.The Committee is aware that Departmental officers have some reasons for not providing some information at the time on aspects of alleged misuse. They were uncertain of the legal situation; some of the events had occurred some considerable period of time before; some aspects of the disciplinary process had not been completed; and the Australian Federal Police were also investigating some matters.

7.However, after careful consideration of each of these reasons, the Committee was inclined to the view that the Department was over-cautious in some of its responses. On a number of occasions, information could have been provided which would not jeopardise other inquiries or appeal processes. It is important for senior officers in major departments to be aware of the extent to which they are able to provide general information on issues, and those areas on which they might wish to seek further time to provide a more considered response.

8.The Committee is of the opinion that more information could have been given about the fact that there were two separate inquiries. More importantly, it believes that more information could have been made available at Estimates on the matters which the Department itself had investigated. Most of the Departmental charges had been dealt with, and penalties imposed, before the Estimates hearing. General information could have been provided without affecting appeal processes.

9.The Committee was especially concerned about the use of bureaucratic terminology insofar as it was used to restrict answers and to limit the area of questioning. Some of the questions at the Estimates hearings were broad enough to require general answers; it was not appropriate for officers to provide a limited amount of information, and to provide it rather reluctantly.

10.The Committee considers that departmental officers should take some questions on notice when it is possible for a more considered answer to be provided at a later stage, rather than providing limited information—which may be inaccurate—at a hearing. While clearly this process should neither be used to avoid providing rapidly information, nor to seek to obtain substantial amounts of unnecessary data, it is one way in which departments are able to meet their responsibilities to Parliament.

11.The Committee considers that the Department's approach and abruptness suggested that matters were being hidden from public scrutiny. While the Committee does not consider that there was a cover up of events at the Department, it does believe that the general impression of unhelpfulness and evasion was the major reason for this inquiry being referred. In this manner, the Department was responsible for an expensive and protracted inquiry which could have been avoided.

12.The Committee is of the belief that in some cases it would be useful for Estimates Committees to be able to take evidence in camera. This would obviate the need for detailed written information, and would help ensure that sensitive issues could be clarified at the time of the Estimates hearings.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lees Sen M.H.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to incorporate my statement on the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Community Affairs, which explains in some detail my dissenting report.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

SPEECH.PARA: DISSENTING REPORT ON THE ALLEGED MISUSE OF PRINTING FACILITIES AT THE DEPARTMENT OF SOCIAL SECURITY

1.This report was referred to the Committee on 10 November 1992. Hearings were completed by mid-December 1992 and a report was drafted by 16 March 1993. A copy of that report was sent to the Committee on 29 March 1993.

2.On the return of the Committee to Parliament it was agreed, on 27 May 1993, that given there were some differences of opinion between Committee members, a new report would be drafted. This new draft, which contained substantially the same material as the revised report of April 1993, was completed by 17 June, further revised and sent to Committee members on 29 July 1993. It maintained the emphasis in the earlier version of the report on poor management by the Department; confused evidence; the possibility of false evidence having been given; serious discrepancies in evidence; unwarranted evasiveness by Departmental officers; and the behaviour of some Departmental officers and the poor attitude they appeared to have towards accountability to Parliament.

3.This report, with some further statements relating specifically to the former head of the Department of Social Security—Mr Derek Volker—was agreed to by the Committee on 9 August 1993. On 10 August a copy of the draft report was sent to Mr Volker, to the current head of the Department of Social Security, and to the AFP. This step was taken because the draft report contained a considerable amount of in camera evidence. The Committee also wished to provide persons specifically mentioned in the report with the opportunity to comment on adverse findings. These adverse findings related both to individuals and the operation of the Department of Social Security.

4.The responses to the draft report varied. The AFP provided two minor factual changes. The former Secretary of DSS, the current Secretary, and two other officers reacted quite differently. I will refer to these responses in a moment.

5.On 19 August 1993 the Committee agreed to postpone the tabling of its report again. It did this for two reasons. First, it wished to consider the responses made by Mr Volker and others, and to give them further time to provide comments if required. Second, a court case relating to matters being considered by the Committee was to be heard. I should note that some concern was expressed by some members of the Committee about the use of sub judice as a reason for continuing to delay the report. The person involved in the court case was not named in the Committee's report at all.

6.Since that postponement of the tabling in August 1993 there has been virtually no detailed discussion of the Committee's report. What has occurred is that the report previously agreed to has been demolished by the Chair of the Committee to a series of disconnected paragraphs. The whole thrust of the original report has disappeared. In the new version the Department, it appears, has done nothing wrong at all. If officers gave varying evidence, this was because the Committee's inquiry was more than twelve months after events, and it was difficult for officers to remember. There were no management problems with the Department. There were no problems with the attitude of Departmental officers and the way in which the then Departmental head behaved towards Parliament. What the report now states is that it would be nice if Departmental officers were a little more forthcoming at Estimates; and that, if they have sensitive information, there should be a process by which this information could be discussed in camera at Estimates.

7.I have not been advised by the Chair of the Committee of any reason why the comments made by the Department and by Mr Volker should have led to such a drastic change from the former detailed and thorough report. My examination of the comments made by Mr Volker, Mr Godfrey and others has, in fact, led me to ask even more questions about Departmental management and, indeed, the reliability and competence of various officers of the Department of Social Security.

8.In these responses, new material never previously advised to the Committee was presented as if it was established fact. The Department suddenly advised the Committee of the presence of two people, rather than one, in a building on a day in July 1991. This information, innocuous as it might seem, actually indicated that much previous testimony could be compromised. Yet the Department did not even bother to note that this was a matter which it should have referred to months before, nor did it raise the issue of how much it undermined the quality of other information provided.

9.It was also obvious from the Department's response that junior officers apparently knew more about what was happening than did the Departmental head and the Deputy Secretary—and failed to advise either. Information available in September 1992 was not advised to the Committee in November 1992.

10.Information provided to the Committee by the Department in April 1993 suggested that most of the charges against officers had been dealt with by August 1992. This conflicted with evidence provided at Estimates. The Department's response to this was that while a junior officer had prepared a minute to the Minister three days before Estimates about the charges, neither the head of the Department nor the Deputy Secretary was aware of this information. When they did become aware of it late in September, they did not provide more up to date information to the Estimates Committee, and Mr Godfrey did not provide clear information on the issue at the first hearing of the Senate Standing Committee on Community Affairs on this matter.

11.The Department also stated for the first time in August 1993 that it never intended to hold an internal investigation at all, even though it had evidence of wrong doing in July 1991 and later. This is surprising in that it is obvious that the problems in the Department were partly of the Department's own making and there was no evidence of extensive wrongdoing. Without knowing the extent of the unauthorised activity, the Department called in the AFP to investigate, rather than undertaking an internal investigation. But the AFP, a Departmental officer now states, was too slow in its inquiry; hence, the Department had to take action by examining a number of matters itself. There is no acknowledgment that common sense and firm discipline exercised by the Department would have made AFP involvement unnecessary.

12.The Department has still not explained why it allowed a junior officer, known to have been involved, to resign prior to any internal inquiry; it states that it had no option but to let the officer resign. This is not true.

13.The comments made by Mr Volker and by various officers in the Department have not convinced me to change the report of 9 August in any substantial way. Insofar as some of it is retained in the majority report, I support those paragraphs. However, there are several matters which have been removed from the majority report, presumably to avoid identifying further the incompetence of the Department. These should be made obvious. Furthermore, the accusations made by Mr Volker and various officers of the Department of Social Security against the Committee have convinced me that the Committee's earlier report—which commented on the arrogance of
those individuals—was correct, and should b maintained.
14.In particular, the Department has accused the Committee of the following:
changing its terms of reference and not advising these to the Department;
not following proper procedure regarding in camera evidence;
not allowing Departmental staff to have counsel at in camera hearings; and
taking secret submissions and other evidence into account.

15.None of the charges made by former and current Departmental officers is true. They have been addressed in more detail in the dissenting report. I would simply like to state at this point that, difficult as it may be for some departments to accept that their actions are subject to total scrutiny, it is nonetheless necessary for some department heads and their senior staff to realise that when requested to provide information they will do so, and do so fully and truthfully.

16.In conclusion, it is noted that this inquiry has demonstrated a number of problems which should be addressed by the Department of Social Security. In particular, the attitude and behaviour of the then Secretary and certain officers was inappropriate, particularly as regards the provision of accurate and adequately detailed information required by the Senate. Insofar as it is considered that the Department acted inappropriately through referring the matter to the AFP rather than utilising available processes; and insofar as it failed to provide prompt, accurate and detailed information at Estimates on 17 September 1992, the Department must bear the responsibility for wasting considerable time and resources. This cost to Parliament and to the Australian Federal Police was unnecessary, and could easily have been avoided if appropriate management and accountability processes had been an integral part of the Department's operation.

TALK.START.PARA: —At one stage we actually had a document that everybody had agreed to. It took a lot of time and a lot of effort. In particular, I want to pay tribute to Senator Michael Tate, who worked with the committee—only briefly, unfortunately—and helped us get a document that everybody agreed to. As we believed it only fair that those people mentioned in the report had the opportunity to have a look at it before it was made public, the committee agreed on 10 August that a copy of the draft report be sent to the Department of Social Security and, in particular, to Mr Volker, the current head of the department.
