The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator McKiernan)—Order! It being 12.45 p.m., I call on matters of public interest.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to raise a matter relating to local government generally, which is my shadow responsibility in this parliament and, in particular, to one shire council, the Whitsunday Shire Council in Queensland. One of the complaints I receive from councils as I visit them around Australia relates to their self-perceived lack of autonomy and the fact that they do not always have control of their affairs. Many of them have called for constitutional recognition to, in some way, confirm their very existence. The question of constitutional recognition is something I am currently looking at, and which the Liberal and National parties are reviewing. Obviously, we will come up with some proposal in relation to that at the appropriate time.

PARA.TAB: The Whitsunday Shire Council is a very clear example of how autonomy has been taken away. That has been done by the Queensland Labor government taking legal action to prevent the council from carrying out its duties. The council has had what I can only call an unhappy relationship with its shire clerk for some time. The council voted, for reasons which I will not go into in detail, to dismiss the shire clerk principally because members of the council were not able to work with her, and for other reasons. But the Queensland government has come in with a claim to the Supreme Court for an injunction to prevent the council from carrying out its decisions, the duty it is elected to do by the people of the Whitsunday shire.

It is rather sad that the Queensland government has chosen to take that action. It is taking the action on the basis that it is alleged that the shire clerk was a whistleblower involved in some investigation being conducted by the Criminal Justice Commission. But this, of course, does not seem to be the case. It seems the state Labor government is leaving her there simply to embarrass the Whitsunday Shire Council. The CJC investigations into some aspects of council operations were, in fact, investigations which the council itself—and particularly the shire chairman, Councillor Glen Patullo—took some time ago in asking the CJC to come in and investigate a particular matter. The CJC has been very slow on the matter. It never seems to get closer to coming to any determination and one wonders why it has adopted this attitude in relation to the Whitsunday Shire Council.

I am concerned at the length of time the CJC has taken because it does cause unease in that council. The investigations are being used as an excuse for keeping on a staff member who has obviously lost the confidence of the majority of the councillors on that council.

I am also concerned that the state Labor member for Whitsunday, Mrs Lorraine Bird, has taken a very anti-Whitsunday Shire Council and very anti-Whitsunday stance since she was elected about four years ago. As many honourable senators would know, the Whitsunday area is one of Australia's greatest tourist destinations. The islands of the Whitsunday are absolutely magnificent, and I would urge all honourable senators to visit that area and just see what a spectacular place it is.

TALK.START.PARA: —Very nice.

—Even Senator Burns agrees with me. People have compared it with the Greek islands, but I do not think there is any comparison at all. The Whitsunday are far and away much better than those. The towns of Airlie Beach on the coast, and Proserpine a fraction inland, are modern, progressive and lively communities. It is a very progressive shire. Proserpine was originally built on the sugar industry and the wealth from sugar. In more recent years, the spectacular tourism attractions, both natural and man-made, make the shire one of the most desirable places to live in and to visit. It is a place that is going ahead in leaps and bounds under very good management. It is a shire in which we would all be proud to live and have some part of the management of.

PARA.TAB: Unfortunately, Mrs Bird does not seem to share that view. She spends a great deal of her time denigrating the Whitsunday area and the Whitsunday Shire Council. She does nothing to instil any investor confidence into the area and refuses to cooperate with the council in things which would be of major benefit to that community. For example, in relation to the Laguna Quays Resort—this is a new tourist facility in that region, which has been very well received environmentally and is delightfully planned—Mrs Bird, I think it was in her maiden speech, said that that resort would go ahead, `Over her dead body'. She has no interest in promoting the area.

She has been appointed to the parliamentary committee of the Criminal Justice Commission. This appointment would seem to be pretty inappropriate in view of her attitude to the Whitsunday Shire Council, and in view of the fact that the Whitsunday Shire Council asked the CJC some time ago to do some work in the shire. Her use of parliamentary privilege in Queensland to attack the councillors on the Whitsunday Shire Council is something to be regretted. She has been able to make what were, if she made them outside parliament, quite defamatory statements. She does this under parliamentary privilege, without giving the people she attacks the opportunity of responding.

There have been some leaks from the CJC, designed to embarrass some of the councillors on the Whitsunday Shire Council, and there is a suggestion that Mrs Bird is the source of those leaks. Her continuous criticism of the council has reduced public and investor confidence in the area.

I think there is a need for the Queensland government to come forward with some whistleblower legislation. The Goss government promised some legislation four years ago, but it has never come. The lack of any rules has caused problems generally and in this instance in particular.

I am concerned that Mrs Bird, the member for Whitsunday, is using her position on the CJC in an improper way. I am very concerned about her continual denigration of the Whitsunday Shire Council and of the people of that area who are making a very good and positive attempt to continue progress and development in that area. Mrs Bird seems to think that people who have a different political view from hers are fair game to be attacked, even though they are not in a position like hers where they can defend themselves.

I certainly hope that the CJC will very quickly conclude its investigations into that council—investigations which were called for by the council—so that that issue can be got out of the way. One could perhaps be excused for thinking that this cloud will be left hanging over the council until just before the Queensland shire council elections are held towards the end of March next year.

There is a rumour around, and I do not know if it is much more than a rumour, that Mrs Bird's husband—I think he is a former Treasurer of the Labor Party in Queensland—might be out of a job. He is currently a member of an adjoining shire council, the Pioneer Shire Council, and that council is being amalgamated with the Mackay City Council, so there are suggestions that Mr Bird might be out of a job. There are also suggestions that he might be running in the Whitsunday Shire Council elections against the incumbent shire chairman.

The incumbent shire chairman and his council have done a lot for the Whitsunday area. It is a very progressive council—a council that obviously feels that it has the best area in the world and wants to make sure that it continues to progress and develop as it has in the past. I would simply call upon Mrs Bird to cease her campaign of denigration of this area, to get behind the Whitsunday Shire Council, to support the area which she is supposed to be representing, and simply to let that area continue to develop as one of Australia's greatest holiday destinations.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on a matter of considerable importance and, I must say, some urgency. It is an issue, unfortunately, which is regarded as arcane and technical, so it has not had the widespread attention that it deserves. I refer to the question of differential shares and, more specifically, the question of super shares currently being considered by the Australian Stock Exchange.

PARA.TAB: The matter has arisen following submissions to the Australian Stock Exchange by Rupert Murdoch's News Corp seeking a waiver to existing listing rules to allow changes in News Ltd's shareholding structure. In essence, the proposal seeks, firstly, the introduction of a new class of shares in News Corp, giving each shareholder super voting rights. Instead of a share in News Ltd having the value of one vote, super shares would have the same initial face value in money terms but entitle the holder to 25 votes instead of one.

Super shares would be issued as a bonus to all current shareholders in News Corp in proportion to their current holding. They would receive one super share for every 10 shares they held at date of issue. Since there are currently on issue approximately 1.8 billion shares in News Corp, the issue of the new shares would increase that by approximately 10 per cent to just under two billion. The voting shares structure would be altered, of course. Instead of 1.8 billion votes, there would be 6.3 billion votes because the super shares would be worth 25 votes each.

Under the proposal, every time a super share is sold it would revert to being an ordinary share and lose its inflated voting value, but not its dollar value—the so-called poison pill proposal—although I noticed that Rupert Murdoch in yesterday's Australian Financial Review was offering a concession on that to cut out that part of the proposal. Under the proposal also super shares would not be listed, so they would not be available for regular trading—that is in the initial proposal—although I understand that a concession is also possible there.

There is little doubt that the proposal would entrench the Murdoch family's interests as majority voting shareholders. In effect, what they would be doing would be making a public company into a private one.

The Australian Stock Exchange response is to produce a discussion paper. It is a good, objective discussion paper fairly balanced in its view, but it has given three weeks for people to respond to it from its delivery date last Wednesday and it will be considering the matter in the middle of December. I regard that time as an absurdly short period of time to be discussing such an important and wide-ranging issue with so many implications which are so difficult to anticipate.

I have become involved in the debates surrounding the issue in my capacity as Chairman of the Joint Committee on Corporations and Securities. I made the simple statement, which I stand by, that the response time, as I have said, is far too short for sensible debate around a very complex issue; that that response time in itself would indicate to any observer that undue—some would say obscene—haste is being used in such an important matter; and that it would send a signal that the Australian Stock Exchange has already made up its mind, regardless of the merits of the argument, and that it has cavilled under pressure from a powerful member.

My public request for the Australian Stock Exchange to extend the time for consideration of the matter was rejected in a tirade of abuse from the stock exchange through its chairman, Laurie Cox. I, and others, have become used to this from the Australian Stock Exchange. It has a lot to learn about productive relations with government and productive relations with the parliament. It has a lot to learn generally about public relations.

The matter is a complex one which I do not intend to take a position on here, although the corporations and securities committee will put a submission before the Australian Stock Exchange and we will also be tabling a statement in parliament and writing to the Attorney-General about this matter. Suffice it to say that there is significant unease in the business community about the super share proposals. The Australian Investment Managers Group, for example, which represents 43 of Australia's largest fund managers, with investments of over $45 billion—so it is not to be sneezed at—is totally opposed to it and will be writing a submission. It has made its views very publicly known.

The Securities Institute of Australia has made its opposition known and investment groups from overseas have also made their opposition known. For example, there was a visitor just last week to Australia from the American organisation CALPERS—the Californian Public Employees Retirement System—who are very big investors. They have an investment portfolio of $80 billion, $13 billion of which is in overseas investment and $250 million of which is in Australian investment. They have come out very strongly opposed to the proposition that has been put by Murdoch and that is being currently canvassed by the ASX.

Concerns range from the simple but usually unequivocal support for the principle of one share one vote—which is something that must be taken very seriously; there has to be a very serious reason for wanting to change that position—to the belief that the proposal may breach the Corporations Law. Certainly, in that regard it would circumvent at least the principles of the takeovers code, if it does nothing else. A particular concern which I share is that such a decision, particularly if taken in such haste, would undermine the integrity of the Australian Stock Exchange and undermine its capacity to be seen around the world as an upstanding exchange market which is fair, open, stable and well thought of.

There is also considerable concern at what is seen by many as the undue influence applied by the proponents of the super share proposal and some clear conflicts of interest in what is by international standards a very small securities market—I am talking about the Australian market now. There is concern, for example, that Rupert Murdoch, through Newscorp and his other interests—interests which represent a substantial percentage of the Australian Stock Exchange's market capitalisation—can apply undue influence.

There is concern that in the small Australian capital market a decision in favour of the change in voting shares would open the way to the entrenchment of major shareholders and powerful interests in many listed Australian corporations. This is not a desirable situation. It is situation which can have a profound negative effect on the standing of the Australian Stock Exchange.

Add to this the shameless and supine way the finance writers of the Murdoch press have tugged their collective forelocks and done the bidding of their masters. Add to that the fact that Mark Burrows, the Chairman of the Corporations and Securities Advisory Committee—the Australian Securities Commission's business advisory committee—is spearheading the Murdoch proposal. Add all these things together and one has to wonder whether any objectivity can be applied by the normal regulating agencies—the Australian Stock Exchange and the Australian Securities Commission. It begs the question of whether the government should not be involved as the only body which could apply reasonably detached judgment to the issue.

Of course, government may well be involved. Under section 774 of the Corporations Law, the Attorney-General has the power to disallow changes to the listing rules of the Australian Stock Exchange. The government, however, has no powers if a waiver from the listing rules is applied. This would be, of course, the worst of all decisions. If the proposal has merit in principle—I do not think that has been substantiated yet—this should be reflected in changes to the listing rules. The Australian Stock Exchange, which was established to raise standards and to maintain an open and fair market, will damage its well deserved high reputation by regulating by exemption.

Finally, the argument that, if the Australian Stock Exchange fails to accommodate Murdoch, some other exchange will, is flawed for two reasons. Firstly, the logical conclusion of this argument is that standards would be set by the most loosely run exchange. I am sure Murdoch could easily move to Shanghai or somewhere like that. I do not think we should be bothered by that. I think we should set our standards and maintain them. Secondly, the trend overseas is running against such arrangements.

While some exchanges have dabbled in various forms of differential share arrangements, there is a clear movement back towards the equitable enfranchisement of shareholders. That is true in the United Kingdom, it is true of continental Europe, and it is true of the New York stock exchange, which had a pretty messy experience in the 1980s—it was described by some as a race to the bottom—that led to the involvement of the US Securities and Exchange Commission and the Congress, a process that I predict will occur in Australia as a result of this proposal.

In summary, I am critical of the way the Australian Stock Exchange has handled the issue, both in terms of the time frame it has allowed for it and in terms of the way it has attempted to move through it. It has all the hallmarks of a predetermined decision. While the issues are complex, there is widespread unease and some concern that it will be difficult for the Australian Stock Exchange to make a decision in a detached and objective way. I believe that the government should be involved and that we should look at ways in future in which such fundamental decisions are made. I do not think it is good enough to allow such fundamental decisions to be made by a body which is so easily influenced by power groups. I indicate that the Corporations and Securities Committee will be making submissions to the Australian Stock Exchange, firstly, and to the Attorney-General, secondly, and that I will table a statement in parliament in due course.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carr Sen K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to raise a concern about the unacceptable delays that have been indicated by the Victorian government in its deliberations regarding the relocation of the Coode Island chemical storage facility. In this morning's Age, under the heading `State did not act on Coode report, says Pescott', it is reported:

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister for Industry Services, Mr Pescott, admitted yesterday that the State Government had not acted on a recommendation from the Safer Chemical Storage Taskforce that it proceed with moving the Coode Island chemical storage.
Mr Pescott said a submission prepared by the taskforce for Cabinet—
that is the state cabinet—
in August had not been taken to Cabinet because he had been trying to clear up uncertainty over the taskforce's authority to make recommendations.

This is a matter of great concern in Victoria because of the importance of the chemical industry. It is also reported in today's newspaper that members of the Safer Chemical Storage Taskforce are becoming very frustrated about the Victorian government's indecisions and procrastinations, to the point where Alan Seale, a respected industry representative, has resigned from the task force. The Age report today indicates:
The Government's failure to act on the taskforce's recommendation is believed to be behind the resignation of the chemical industry's representative on the taskforce, Mr Alan Seale . . .

It is also important and significant in the revelations that were put before the Victorian parliament yesterday that Mr Pescott had told that parliament that a letter he had sent to the Minister for Defence, Senator Ray, in May asking that Point Wilson be considered a real option to house the proposed armaments complex had been `written on the Premier's instructions', that is, Mr Kennett's instructions. So it appears that there may be other motives and other factors behind the state government's delay in moving the Coode Island facility.

PARA.TAB: The issue of Coode Island has been on the political agenda in Victoria for a number of years. I repeat that the chemical industry is of great importance to Victoria. It employs some 37,000 people. It is a key component in the state's manufacturing industry. It is an industry of enormous political power, particularly within a coalition government. It would appear that its more backward looking sections have increased their power in recent times within the Kennett government.

It is unfortunate that short-sighted and irresponsible employers seem reluctant to spend money on safety. It is unfortunate that they do not appear to be willing to invest in their own future and that of their employees and their community, which is directly affected by the actions of this giant industry.

In 1990, the then Victorian Liberal-National party coalition spokesman on the environment said that in government the coalition would close Coode Island and transfer the complex. Two years ago, a chemical storage tank at the complex ruptured, sending a fireball and toxic cloud over Melbourne's western suburbs. Some 50,000 people live within five kilometres of Coode Island. There are houses 550 metres from the storage facilities at that site. I am very familiar with the area; I have been associated with it for a long time. It is a matter of great significance to the people who live next to that facility and of great significance to the people of Melbourne as a whole. As indicated by the fire two years ago, the people of Melbourne were put at great risk.

The state Labor government at that time established a Coode Island review panel, chaired by John Landy. The review panel undertook enormous public consultations. Some 300 submissions were received. The panel looked at all the options and recommended the relocation of Coode Island to Point Wilson, just outside Geelong. In its 265-page report, it recommended a process whereby an interim task force would be established and replaced by a statutory authority in 1992. The cost of relocating Coode Island was estimated at approximately $200 million—$100 million in public funds and $100 million in private funds from the chemical industry.

The state Labor government pledged to move the chemical complex by the year 1996. Based on the Landy report, two years were assigned for planning and two years were assigned for the relocation of the tanks. At the time the chemical industry also supported the move. Because the lease on Coode Island expires in the year 2000, it made good sense for the chemical industry to take such measures. As that time is now rapidly approaching, it is of major concern to significant sections of that industry. It is important that some certainty be provided to that industry.

The progressive elements of the chemical industry and the Victorian Labor government at that time were committed to the world's best practice in the chemical industry. They were very keen to pursue the relocation plans and to protect the $195 million worth of chemical imports Australia receives each year.

The conservation movement has also strongly supported the relocation of Coode Island. At the time of the last Victorian election, the public and, in particular, the voters of the western suburbs of Melbourne also believed that the Liberal Party supported the relocation of Coode Island. Unfortunately, events since the October election have made people seriously doubt that commitment.

In May, the Victorian Minister for Industry Services wrote to the defence minister, Senator Robert Ray. As I indicated, he supported the proposal that the Commonwealth ammunition complex be built at Point Wilson. In today's newspaper he has indicated that he did that on behalf of the Premier of Victoria, Mr Jeff Kennett.

Mr Kennett indicated in parliament yesterday that he did not ask Mr Pescott to undertake that action. That is the sort of contradiction one gets used to in the Victorian parliament these days. It is important that I indicate that Alan Stockdale has also suggested that the actions of Mr Pescott were unauthorised in the way he approached the Commonwealth government seeking support for the ammunition complex to be placed at Point Wilson.

Three months ago the Victorian government, in what can be described only as a stalling tactic, employed Alan Oxley to conduct a review of the Safer Chemical Storage Taskforce secretariat. Mr Pescott now claims that the task force recommendations were made without authority. I understand that the Victorian government is sitting on that review and has not released it to the public, not even to the task force chairman. Mr Pescott claims that the delay in presenting the cabinet submission is a result of what he describes as jurisdictional problems. It seems to me that there are serious doubts about the minister's motive.

The Safer Chemical Storage Taskforce prepared a detailed cabinet submission three months ago. It is believed that this submission recommends proceeding with the new facility, and puts the cost to the government of Victoria at some $50 million. That is half the original estimate of the government contribution to the relocation of the storage facility. Clearly, this is a significant retreat for the Victorian government, but not significant enough for the current Victorian minister.

I believe that this submission has not been proceeded with because the Victorian government is stalling on fulfilling its earlier commitment to the Victorian people to relocate the Coode Island facility. The relocation of Coode Island will not only eliminate the enormous risk the facility poses to the people in Melbourne's western suburbs but also be a boost to the Victorian economy. The complex will be built, owned and operated by the industry and will create many much needed jobs for Victorian workers. The chemical industry has a major responsibility to the people of the western suburbs of Melbourne. It has a responsibility to all the people of Melbourne. The 1991 Coode Island fires highlight just how much that responsibility means to the people of Melbourne. Recently, $17 million has been spent on upgrading fire facilities at Coode Island, and this is to be commended. But it is not in itself an excuse to maintain the facilities at their current location.

The Kennett government must stop equivocating and act on the task force recommendations. It must release the Oxley review and make a clear public commitment to the relocation time frame and to provide the $50 million public contribution that is needed to secure that relocation. The Kennett government prides itself on what it believes to be its decisive decision making. It has been very quick to sack thousands of public servants. It has been very quick to close down hundreds of state schools. It has rushed through legislation without adequate public consultation and debate. It undermines traditional liberal democratic cultural values. It undermines an independent judiciary. It undermines an independent public service. It sacks judges. It sacks statutory appointees. Yet on an important issue such as this it is unable to come to a clear decision. This delay is sending quite considerable conflicting signals to the community. I think the people of Melbourne are entitled to ask why.

Mr Kennett, the message from Canberra is very clear. Senator Ray, the defence minister, has put it very bluntly. He is a man who has no trouble getting his message across. Yet it would appear that that message has been lost on the Victorian government. He made it clear on radio in Melbourne in September that he is waiting for an announcement from the Victorian government, and that message is very simple: if the government of Victoria is prepared to move Coode Island, it should announce it publicly. Once that is done, the question of Point Wilson will not be an issue in the relocation of the arms dump. Why has that offer not been taken up? Why is there a delay? I think the people of Melbourne are entitled to ask those questions and they are entitled to receive an answer.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will be very brief. I rise to support the comments of Senator Beahan, the Chairman of the Corporations and Securities Committee, of which I am a member. In supporting Senator Beahan in regard to super shares, I should point out that the behaviour of the Australian Stock Exchange in this affair has been odd. It really has been disgraceful. It may be that Mr Murdoch is trying the stock exchange on. That is probably what it is; it is true to form—and true to Mr Murdoch's good form. Maybe we should say good luck to him, but I think not.

PARA.TAB: It is the Australian Stock Exchange that is the focus here in relation to Mr Murdoch's request for super shares. Like Senator Beahan, I greatly admire the financial journalists of the Murdoch press, such as Mr Terry McCrann; I follow them closely day by day. However, on this issue Mr McCrann's writings have leaped over principles. On many occasions his logic is twisted when he writes about the super shares. I would have thought we had left behind the 1980s. Apparently we have not even mopped up the 1980s and all the rogues of the 1980s in the public eye.

It would seem that nothing has been learnt by the Australian Stock Exchange from the lessons of the 1980s, and that is proven by its unseemly haste to open and shut this case on super shares and not to allow greater discussion on the subject. Mr Cox has attacked and criticised Senator Beahan as chairman merely for raising the matter. To that end, the Attorney-General, Mr Lavarch, ultimately has the power—more power than our committee; we can go only so far—to disallow any decision by the Australian Stock Exchange on this matter. The ball is very much in Mr Lavarch's court. I call upon him to step in, following our committee's submission to the Australian Stock Exchange. It would seem that no sooner are we into the 1990s than the Australian Stock Exchange is letting Gordon Gecko back into the boardroom. That will be very much the effect of the introduction of these super shares.

The Chairman of the Australian Stock Exchange should look at the loss of credibility he has now brought upon himself through the way he has handled this matter and his criticism of the parliamentary committee merely for seeking more details. Quite frankly, I think the Chairman of the Australian Stock Exchange has lost a great deal of credibility and respect in regard to this matter. He should understand that we have a role to play in questioning such regulations in the Australian Stock Exchange, particularly in view of what the public has asked us to do.

After the shambles of the 1980s, does the Chairman of the Stock Exchange really think we will turn a blind eye to this? He did and, quite frankly, I think his position has become untenable. Either Mr Cox should be severely disciplined by the Attorney-General or he should step down from his position as Chairman of the Australian Stock Exchange. We are not going to turn our backs on the matter of the super shares. I fully endorse what Senator Beahan said, and he has the support of his committee.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Physical and Sexual Abuse in Catholic Institutions

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McKiernan Sen J.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 7 October, Senator Panizza and I spoke in the Senate on a matter which was reported in Hansard and headed `Alleged Physical and Sexual Abuse in Catholic Institutions'. That should have read `Admitted Physical and Sexual Abuse in Catholic Institutions', because it has been publicly admitted by the Christian Brothers organisation in Western Australia that both physical and sexual abuse has occurred in four child-care institutions in my home state of Western Australia. It was publicised earlier this year, together with an apology for that abuse happening.

PARA.TAB: There have been a number of developments since both Senator Panizza and I spoke on the matter. On Tuesday of this week the Roman Catholic Archbishop of Perth, Barry Hickey, was reported in the West Australian newspaper as refusing to support a call for a judicial inquiry into allegations of abuse of children in Christian Brothers institutions. On page 6 of the article in the West Australian the archbishop is quoted as saying:

SPEECH.PARA: There is no doubt, in my mind, that the victims of physical and sexual abuse will continue to feel aggrieved if the truth does not come out. Nevertheless, I do not think a judicial inquiry will necessarily achieve the desired result.

I am disappointed with that reaction. I understand the reaction but I am very disappointed with it. A judicial inquiry, to my mind, is the only way we will get to the bottom of this very nasty situation, and many people continue to suffer because of it. Further developments have occurred. I have today received a letter from the Western Australian Attorney-General, Mrs Cheryl Edwardes MLA. I will read the letter in total:
Dear Senator McKiernan
CHRISTIAN BROTHERS INSTITUTIONS
Thank you for your letter dated 17 September 1993 regarding the above matter.
I have noted the comments you have raised in relation to this very sensitive and difficult situation.

You will be aware that steps have been taken recently by the Christian Brothers to establish a helpline and professional counselling service to assist former residents of its child care institutions in Western Australia. The provision also of a panel which will work independently to provide advice to the Christian Brothers is an important step. I understand that this panel will also invite submissions from individuals and groups in order to facilitate an accurate overall assessment of needs.

For these reasons and in order to address the needs of former residents of Christian Brothers homes, I believe that the process of conciliation is a positive step in ensuring that the victims are given the opportunity to access appropriate support.

However, serious allegations have been made by a number of former residents and some may not wish to make use of this avenue of conciliation. These allegations may be more appropriately referred to the Police for investigation. Further, as there is some action presently before the Courts, it is not appropriate for a judicial enquiry to be considered at this stage.

I trust that I have clarified this issue for you and thank you for advising me of your concerns in this matter. I also thank you for your comments about my action to ban the showing of the film `Salo' in Western Australia.
Yours sincerely
Cheryl Edwardes
Attorney-General

I read from that letter that the Western Australian Attorney-General is not going to establish a judicial inquiry to look into this matter. It is very interesting that she refers in the fifth paragraph of the letter to these words:
These allegations may be more appropriately referred to the Police for investigation.

Yesterday the Director of Public Prosecutions in Western Australia announced that he will not launch prosecutions on any of the 16 cases of alleged sexual and physical abuse complaints that have been made to him. In today's newspaper there is a photograph of a gentleman called John Lawrence, who indicates that he is going to go on a hunger strike until he gets an inquiry. I can understand Mr Lawrence taking that course of action because it looks, from the information we have got here, that there will be no official government or, indeed, church action on this matter.

PARA.TAB: I think it is the church itself that is suffering most because of its inactivity. I am loath to make calls of a cover-up or to draw inferences about the power and the influence of the Catholic Church in Western Australia. I know that it has enormous influence in the country I was born in. I did not think it had that same degree of influence in Western Australia or, indeed, in Australia, but certainly it looks that way.

In response to the decision by the Director of Public Prosecutions not to launch prosecutions, Mr Bruce Blyth, a spokesman for the Victims of Institutional Cruelty, Exploitation and Supporters—the VOICES organisation—says:

SPEECH.PARA: It has taken great courage for them to go through the trauma of going to a police station and making statements on abuse. But the group hope to turn yesterday's disappointing announcement to its advantage. The government had previously pushed aside a judicial inquiry to establish the truth on the basis that police investigations were under way. Now that Mr McKechnie has dismissed the idea of police prosecutions there should be no impediment to an inquiry.

This scenario of events puts me in a difficult position. I indicated in my speech on 7 October, which I have referred to before, that I would use my office, as an elected member of parliament for the state of Western Australia, to pursue this matter. I cannot let these people down now. I will have to press on to have some action taken in this parliament because the Western Australian government appears not to want to take any action on it. So I will have to press forward in this parliament, using whatever avenues are available to me to represent the interests of these people who I think are getting a very raw deal from the Director of Public Prosecutions, the police forces, the state government of Western Australia and the Roman Catholic Church, in Western Australia particularly but in Australia generally.

PARA.TAB: I am not exactly sure at this time what we can do from this parliament. I hope to consult Senator Panizza, for one, and my colleagues on this side of the chamber about what we can do. I do not think this matter can appropriately be investigated by a parliamentary committee. The matters are far too sensitive and it would be wrong to expose the individuals who are victims, many of whom I have met in my electorate office, to a parliamentary inquiry. But, if that is the last avenue open to us, that is what I would be pushing for.

I use this speech now to make a final plea to the Western Australian government, to Mrs Edwardes, to have a judicial inquiry. An inquiry is desperately needed. There are many hundreds of individuals, victims in their childhood, that need somewhere to tell their story. What the church has done so far is inadequate. It is not enough. We will have to get to the bottom of this. I certainly am not going to rest on this matter. I would hope that we could do it in a conciliatory way rather than setting up a battle with the Western Australian government or indeed the church. I will do whatever I can to ensure that the victims of the physical and sexual abuse that took place in child-care institutions in my state of Western Australia do have some approach to justice so that justice can be given to them.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like briefly to address the subject that Senator McKiernan raised but I certainly will not be running over everything he said. I am very glad that Senator McKiernan did say that the Western Australia government appears not to be heading towards a judicial inquiry at this stage. Senator McKiernan showed me the letter he received from my good friend Mrs Edwardes in the Western Australia parliament. I spoke briefly on this matter in the parliament on 7 October, as Senator McKiernan mentioned. Before that, I had already written to Mrs Edwardes, the Attorney-General in Western Australia, and also to the Christian Brothers and the Archbishop of Perth, requesting them to have an inquiry.

PARA.TAB: So far, I have been contacted by the Christian Brothers and by people representing the Christian Brothers, but I have not had an answer from the Archbishop of Perth on this matter. I am very disappointed about that. I have been contacted by supporters of the Christian Brothers who were wondering why I had struck up such an alliance with Senator McKiernan. I pointed out that in matters that concern humanity I will team up with anyone in order to see that justice is done.

I have said previously that I was educated by the Christian Brothers and I am a reasonably practising member of the Catholic Church. So I told those supporters that, by doing this, I am not denigrating the Catholic Church or the Christian Brothers. Senator McKiernan said that the church is suffering the most. I do not believe that is correct. I believe that the Christian Brothers are suffering most and I would like to see an inquiry.

As far as the Attorney-General in Western Australia goes, I have not had a chance to speak to her since I wrote to her. I presume that my reply is in the mail, and I am not going to give any opinion of what she is about to do until I talk to her face to face. I was asked by a representative of the Christian Brothers not to do anything until we get this help line police inquiry and all of that out of the road. I agreed to that at the time and I still believe that the line I took was correct.

I spoke to the minister for police in Western Australia and he assured me that the police were looking at these alleged incidents of sexual and physical assault. He also told me that these things had, of course, happened a long time ago. However, he promised that the police were investigating it to the best of their ability. I was very surprised by the announcement yesterday from the public prosecutor in Western Australia that he was not going to proceed. I do not think that is necessarily the end of the line for this.

TALK.START.PARA: —You did note what he said about why he is not proceeding?
—I did read that, yes.
—He does not have sufficient evidence to successfully prosecute.

—Yes, that is right. I think he said, `At this stage'. The point is that he did use the argument that they were not proceeding because these things had happened 40 years ago and that it is hard to get evidence to corroborate what has been given by the victims. But when you look at the war crimes situation that this government set up, it is much the same thing. That happened 45 years ago, at least.
—I would have said that was fairly supportive evidence for the Western Australian Director of Public Prosecutions, in terms of the outcome of that.

—I will not go into that now. I was a bit surprised that he did come to that conclusion and, as I understand it, the police are still investigating the situation. I told those people who contacted me that I am willing to hold off until we see what comes out of all that. I have a meeting with Mrs Edwardes at the end of next week. Hopefully, I will be able to get some indication of what she intends to do. If this issue is not concluded satisfactorily in Western Australia, I would have to look very seriously at supporting an inquiry in this place. Of course, I have not sought the opinion of my colleagues on this. That is just my personal feeling. I will report further to the Senate on this.

DEBATE.TITLE: OCCUPATIONAL HEALTH AND SAFETY (MARITIME INDUSTRY) BILL 1993OCCUPATIONAL HEALTH AND SAFETY (MARITIME INDUSTRY) CONSEQUENTIAL AMENDMENTS BILL 1993

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 29 September, on motion by Senator Collins:
That these bills be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Occupational Health and Safety (Maritime Industry) Bill 1993 and the Occupational Health and Safety (Maritime Industry) Consequential Amendments Bill 1993 set out the codification of the common law duty of care and provide a modern regime for the health and safety of persons working on ships and oil rigs. It complements the Seafarers' Rehabilitation and Compensation Act 1992 which reformed the workers compensation system for seafarers. All parties must take all reasonable steps to ensure that the workplace, and the work performed there, does not endanger the safety and health of the workers or any other person in the vicinity. There is no doubt that ships and oil rigs should have equipment and facilities that are healthy and safe.

PARA.TAB: Regulation for the maritime industry has previously been through the requirements of the Navigation Act 1912 which gave the industry ample authority to impose the highest safety standards and to maintain the preparedness, training and competency of the crew. Australian employers have always maintained extremely high standards. Indeed, many operators, such as BHP, have been over standard for some time. Until now, there has been no legal obligation for a union or employee to participate. Any provision for health and safety imposes obligations on employees as well as employers, and they should be required to cooperate to ensure the highest possible standard. As part of those obligations industry employers and the unions are developing industry wide training packages suitable for use on board ships.

In reality, of course, there are no artificial divisions or barriers of this nature between those who co-exist on board a ship. It is not as though the employer or master is enclosed in an office or boardroom while employees are on the factory floor or employed in another area. Safety requirements affect equally all those on board a boat. It is pleasing to see that the highest standard of safety in the world, previously maintained by the Australian maritime industry, is maintained and encouraged by this legislation. It puts in place that these standards must be the benchmark, and it gives legislative authority to have the standards maintained to a level below which they should not go. As I said, previously the standards have been in place but there has been no legal obligation to maintain them. Employers have expressed positive opinions about this legislation.

There were previous concerns expressed on the early drafts of this legislation and I will briefly mention two of these. The training of the work force in matters such as this can often prove to be of great expense to management and operationally disruptive. However, because of the special circumstances of life at sea, this legislation provides that a significant element of the necessary training will be undertaken during off-duty periods at sea. Once again, this is an illustration of the particular nature of this industry in that some training can take place in the work place environment rather than having costly training at other locations.

The costs associated with the operations of the inspectorate, under the auspices of the Australian Maritime Safety Authority, will be fully recoverable from the industry. The functions of the inspectorate are to ensure that industry parties are complying with the legislation requirements. Inspectors will also conduct spot checks, respond to requests for investigations, conduct investigations into significant accidents and dangerous situations, and take such action as is required to ensure deficiencies are rectified. The costs associated with the implementation of the proposed legislation are not expected to impose an onerous burden on the shipping industry.

Another concern was that an inspector coming on board a vessel would have the power to override the authority of the master of the vessel. However, clause 7 of the bill specifically states that the master or operator of the ship retains control of the vessel unless designated otherwise by him. A contractor does not become an operator. As stated, we assume that the government has, in clause 7, confirmed that the authority of the master or the operator is unchallenged and that it is the intention of government to encompass this very necessary provision.

In my opening remarks, I mentioned the Seafarers Rehabilitation and Compensation Act of 1992 which reformed the workers compensation system for seafarers. It seems to be government practice to put the cart before the horse, and nowhere is this better exemplified than the order in which these two pieces of legislation have been presented. Prevention, as set out in the bill we are considering today, will always be better than cure as set out in the earlier bill. Yet the government has chosen to ignore this logical progression. It is typical of this mate and union dominated government to have pushed through compensation payments before dealing with the working environment which would have made those payments unnecessary. It would have been, one would think, an entirely proper and much preferred course of action to have put these two bills together in a package. This is clearly demonstrated by the fact that the consequential amendments to the rehabilitation and compensation bill would not have been necessary if the two bills had been placed together.

The rehabilitation and compensation bill was passed one year ago. Why has there been the wait? It has taken one year to get this bill, the occupational health and safety bill, up and running. The bill has lain dormant since June 1992. The industry had been extensively consulted up to that point, and nothing further was done. There was no further consultation until July 1993, when the industry was contacted again and informed that the bill was to be lodged for consideration by the legislation committee of cabinet one week later. The sudden imposition of this timetable after the bill had lain dormant for one year is most unsatisfactory and inexplicable, and I note that the industry will be raising this point separately with the responsible minister.

The coalition regards it as a demonstration of a cavalier attitude toward the industry, where vital issues are left in limbo for no good reason for one year and then rushed through in a state of crisis that is of the government's own making. This cavalier attitude to the industry goes beyond the government's attitude to this bill, as in recent times the industry has not been well served. The maritime industry would have every reason to feel betrayed at this point. The Seamen's Union and employers have been at great pains to cooperate and have worked hard with the government to make sure that workplace reforms have taken place in the maritime industry. Everyone concerned with the industry has over the last while taken some very difficult decisions.

In many ways, the workplace reform achieved in the shipping industry has been the government's only successful micro-economic reform program. The last round of reforms saved $270,000 per vessel per year. It will now be undermined by the unnecessary added cost of the fuel excise hike. Originally, this would have cost the industry $360,000 per vessel per year. However, the post-Harradine amendment cost has reduced this to $216,000 per vessel per year. Even though this is a reduction, it is still a tax on producers and exports, and therefore a tax on jobs. How can the government justify this course of action to seamen who bit the bullet and realised that redundancy was essential for the healthy state of the industry? The industry is now suffering from great disillusionment and realising that many of the hard decisions were in vain. That disillusionment is across the board.

The industry is supportive of this legislation and has been closely involved with its development, since it lends enforceability to measures that employers have instituted but which they had to rely on the goodwill of employees to implement. This has not always been fully forthcoming and the employers have stated that the measures in the bill will give them the ability to require that their employees adhere to standards of health and safety that the employers regard as positive standards and that are fundamental to good and safe operation. Financial penalties can be imposed on employers or employees who breach the legislation. Similarly, manufacturers and suppliers will be liable to prosecution and fines for contravening these rules. The coalition supports the legislation, but notes the concerns expressed regarding the priority of the legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply—I was wondering for a minute after the honourable senator's opening remarks whether the opposition was going to support the legislation. I do not notice any particular crisis about this. The honourable senator has clearly forgotten about a few things, like an election in the last 12 months. I am pleased to say that, at the conclusion of the speech, there was support indicated for the bill. The bill is supported by the industry, by the employees and by this government.

PARA.TAB: I must say, also briefly, that crying crocodile tears for the Australian shipping industry is a new occupation for the coalition, considering that one of the fundamental planks of its maritime policy, such as it is, is the removal of any degree of protection whatsoever from the Australian shipping industry by the abolition of cabotage on the domestic shipping industry along Australia's coastline. Having replied to those ungracious remarks from the honourable senator with a few ungracious remarks of my own, I thank her for her support of the legislation.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bills read a second time.
The bills.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I table a supplementary explanatory memorandum relating to the government amendment to be moved to the Occupational Health and Safety (Maritime Industry) Consequential Amendments Bill. I move:

PARA.TAB: Clause 2, page 1, line 6, insert "Division 4 of Part 1 of" after "day on which".

SPEECH.PARA: The proposed amendment addresses a simple drafting error in the commencement clause of the Occupational Health and Safety (Maritime Industry) Consequential Amendments Bill. As introduced, clause 2 of the consequential amendments bill provided for that bill to commence on the day on which the Occupational Health and Safety (Maritime Industry) Act 1993—the principal bill—commences. However, the principal bill has more than one commencement date. Parts of the bill commence on royal assent, while the remainder commences on a day or days to be fixed by proclamation.

PARA.TAB: The proposed amendment will link the commencement of the consequential amendments bill to the commencement of division 4 of part 1 of the principal bill. This linkage is relevant because division 4 of part 1 includes the provision which expands the role of the existing Seafarers Rehabilitation Compensation Authority to cover maritime industry occupational health and safety matters. The consequential amendments bill amends the Seafarers Rehabilitation and Compensation Act 1992 to cover the expanded role of the authority.
Amendment agreed to.

Occupational Health and Safety (Maritime Industry) Consequential Amendments Bill 1993 agreed to with an amendment and Occupational Health and Safety (Maritime Industry) Bill 1993 agreed to without amendment; report adopted.
Bills (on motion by Senator Collins) read a third time.
Debate resumed from 7 October, on motion by Senator Faulkner:
That this bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Migration Amendment ("Points" System) Bill 1993 amends the Migration Act 1958 to simplify the operation of the points system and the pooling mechanism for the independent and concessional family categories of Australia's migration program, first of all, by replacing the current three-mark system—namely, priority, pass and pool entrance marks—with a two-mark system consisting of a pass mark and a pool mark; and, secondly, by introducing a 12-month limit after which time an application still held in the pool must be rejected. This replaces the current requirement of three gazettals of changed pass marks which could occur over a period well in excess of 12 months.

PARA.TAB: The coalition supports those measures. We consider that the simplification of the operation of the points system contained in this bill is sensible and fair. We also support the transitional arrangements provided in the bill. It allows for applications currently in the pool to remain there for a further period of up to 12 months. The points system for independent and concessional family migration has operated since 1989. It was introduced as part of the extensive reforms to migration administration, following the excellent report by the FitzGerald committee on Australia's immigration policies. The coalition supported the introduction of this system back in 1989, and we were concerned then to ensure that it continued to operate in a manner as efficient and as fair as possible.

The bill before the Senate does not change the essence of the operation of the points and pooling systems; rather it refines its administration. The proposals in the bill make sensible improvements to the current system, which has proved to be administratively cumbersome. The priority and the pass marks have, in practice, been set at the same level since May 1990, according to information provided to the coalition by the government. It is therefore reasonable, as the government has proposed, to combine these two into one mark. The bill will enable the government to determine the size of the pool at any one time by enabling it to increase or decrease the pool entrance mark with immediate effect. That will improve the current arrangements, which cause uncertainty and confusion, as well as being as administratively cumbersome.

The government will now have much greater control over the numbers in the pool at any one time. This contrasts with the existing situation where the pool cannot be reduced by increasing the pool entrance mark because of the requirement that applications remain there for three gazetted pass mark changes. I note in this context that there have been only two changes in the pool entrance mark for both the concessional family and independent categories since the system began in 1989. Since June 1991, the number of principal applicants in both pools has steadily increased.

The measures contained in this bill will give a clear statement to applicants in the pool of the circumstances and time frame in which their applications can be removed, either for further processing or for rejection. Therefore, the coalition has no difficulty in endorsing this bill. Had time permitted, there were various other matters in relation to Australia's immigration program that I would have raised. In view of the time and the circumstances, I will defer those matters until a future date. They go to the heart of the administration of the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and to the whole question of the access to the judicial system for appellants within the system and similar matters. I think all of these matters are extremely important to the future integrity of Australia's immigration program.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without amendment or debate.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Acting Leader of the Government in the Senate as Minister representing the Prime Minister. I ask whether the minister is aware that the head of BHP, Mr John Prescott, commented in relation to the Labor Party's native title legislation in the following terms:

QUESTION.PARA: Examining the proposed bill is like reading porridge.
It is far too complex, far too difficult to understand and fraught with the danger of leading us into additional uncertainty and unnecessary conflict.
In this time of economic difficulty, it is not in the nation's interests to hamstring our future prospects with unworkable and inappropriate rules.
How is it that the government has got it so wrong that, instead of its bill contributing to increased certainty and confidence, it is actually leading to greater confusion and uncertainty?

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen some reference to Mr Prescott's views on Mabo and his views on the legislation. In my time in government there has been no more complex issue to come before government than the consideration of what came out of the High Court decision. For those who want to see a simplistic solution, I simply say to them: it is not available.
—Rubbish!

—If it were so simple, why did Senator MacGibbon's party spend so many hours yesterday wrestling with the issues? Why did it spend so many weeks and so many months on it, as this government has? The only difference in the end is who came up with a fair solution and who came up with a solution that reflected internal division within the Liberal Party. That is the other side of politics. Those opposite are so divided on the issue that they had to come up with a compromise.
—A unanimous decision.

—Sure—a unanimous decision based on the fact that those opposite want to have their cake and eat it. They want to recognise the High Court decision; they want to protect the Racial Discrimination Act—they want to do all those things. But they do not want to support the federal legislation, nor will they put their full support behind Premier Court in Western Australia. What they have come up with as a solution to Mabo is to opt out, because the decisions were too hard and too difficult.

PARA.TAB: In essence, the question that Senator Hill asks today is this: is there a really simple, easy, one-line or few-line solution to Mabo? No, there is not. It is a complex issue in which, if all bases are not covered, future mistakes will be made and legislation will be challenged—and rightly challenged—in the High Court. That is a position that this government has resisted. We have spent many months, and we have had many meetings, developing the issues. All the opposition did in the initial stages was run all sorts of rednecked arguments, trying to create uncertainty in the community. What the opposition did yesterday was a great cop-out—the greatest cop-out an opposition has ever been involved in in this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I think the minister actually missed the question. The question was: why is the government providing a solution that is actually leading to greater confusion and uncertainty?
—It would not be hard to confuse Senator Hill or the opposition.
—Why don't you call Prescott a redneck?

—Senator Alston, the inveterate injector who puts his mouth into gear before his mind even catches up, says, `Am I describing Mr Prescott as a redneck?' No, I am not. I am describing some of those on the opposition as precisely that. What the opposition did yesterday was basically a political solution to its own internal party problems; it did not tackle this issue properly or head on.

PARA.TAB: What I was saying in answer to Senator Hill's question, before his colleague interjected, was that this is a complex issue that cannot be answered simply. To understand it means quite a deal of application—probably more than Senator Hill or I could apply to it—in order to come up with solutions. That is what this government has done.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: VIP Aircraft: Use by Mr J. Brumby

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Defence. Has the minister's attention been drawn to allegations in the Victorian parliament made by Mr Geoff Leigh that Mr John Brumby, while working for Alan Griffiths MP, misused VIP aircraft? Can the minister confirm that Mr Leigh's allegations are baseless?

—I am aware that the state member of parliament Mr Leigh has made allegations that Mr John Brumby, when working for Alan Griffiths MP, may have been involved in the misuse of VIP aircraft. It is not my general intention to get involved in the argy-bargy of Victorian state politics and the plethora of allegations that exist in that parliament. In this case, it involves my administration of the defence department so I will put the record straight.
—Those opposite do not like that. They quite liked Michael Baume working for John Howard in 1983-84. Poor old Senator Baume was working down at Wollongong when he accepted the job with John Howard.

PARA.TAB: I can state categorically that John Brumby did not ever misuse VIP aircraft. Like any other ministerial staff member, he accompanied his minister—like any other staff member, including staff members for the opposition—to and from a destination on a positioning leg. It should be noted that Mr Leigh, having made the allegation, has said nothing specific. He has made no allegation as to an actual event. He has just made a broad allegation.

He then goes on and complains that his colleagues could not get any information on this matter. Even if he had done just a modicum of research, Mr Leigh would have realised that the manifests of all VIP flights, which indicate passengers, date and the destination of the flight, are tabled twice a year in the federal parliament. Those records are obviously intensely scrutinised by members of the opposition. So, clearly, if Mr Brumby was at fault at any stage, the opposition members here would have picked it up. What Mr Leigh is implying is that they have not done their job. It is obvious that Mr Leigh's allegations are simply made in response to the fact that Mr Brumby has made—and proved—allegations in the state parliament as to the probity of the Kennett government.

For the record, Mr Leigh has a great track record of conspiracy theories and unsubstantiated allegations over the years. His own party—and Senator Alston would know this—was so repulsed by him and his activities that it de-preselected him for the seat of Malvern last time around.

TALK.START.PARA: —Exactly what you did to Jean Meltzer.

—Then, Senator Kemp, Mr Leigh went feral, as you know. He started criticising the party. He started leaking information to the Labor Party about internal Liberal Party matters. So the Liberal Party bought him off with the endorsement for Mordialloc and prayed that he would not win the seat.

PARA.TAB: I invite Mr Leigh, either inside or outside the parliament—although he never says anything outside—to produce any evidence of wrongdoing by Mr Brumby. If he fails to do so, I invite him to retract.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Acting Leader of the Government in the Senate. I refer the minister to the recent speech by the government's chief economic adviser, the Secretary to the Treasury, Mr Ted Evans, in which he said that Australia's current tragically high level of unemployment, now 11.2 per cent, was `a matter of choice'. In view of this admission, subsequently supported by the Secretary of the Prime Minister's own department, why has the government deliberately chosen a policy of high unemployment for Australians, and how does it justify this choice to the one million unemployed?

—I have not seen the context in which those remarks were made, but I have certainly seen them quoted. They do not represent the government's position. We do not choose to have an unemployment rate as high as it is at the moment. We have commissioned a paper on unemployment and have tried to restructure this economy to the benefit of economic growth. That is the policy of this government. What Mr Evans was referring to in terms of choice may well go to some of the solutions available. But it is not the policy of this government to choose high unemployment.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I note that the minister has now just disowned the government's chief economic adviser. I remind the minister of the Prime Minister's election night speech, in which he said:

QUESTION.PARA: The people of Australia have taken us on trust and we'll return that trust and we'll care about those people out there, particularly the unemployed—we want to get them back to work.

With unemployment still stuck in a groove at near record levels and higher than it was when Mr Keating spoke on election night, how can anyone take the Prime Minister or his government on trust when, since the election, they have done nothing whatsoever about unemployment in this country?

TALK.START.PARA: —When it comes to trusting colleagues, a few weeks ago I read in the Sydney Morning Herald that Senator Short was going to be persuaded to put his cue in the rack in order to assist a colleague sitting a few yards away. Senator Short says that I have disowned Mr Evans; that is not the case. I said that I did not know the context in which he was quoted in that regard. I think the construction that Senator Short has put on his quote therein is wrong.

PARA.TAB: I return to the more substantive point—the remarks made by Mr Keating after the election that his most important mission in government was to return Australia to a much better employment position. That remains the government's position at this stage and will into the future. We regard it as a most important issue that can face a government. There are not simple solutions to it. If Senator Short wants to give us some simple solutions to it, he might also like to advise the governments of the UK, Canada, France, Italy, Spain and many other countries that are grappling with the same problems in these difficult economic times.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Public Accounts Committee: Report on Taxation

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. Noting yesterday's release of the Joint Committee of Public Account's report on tax and its recommendation for a bill of rights for taxpayers, can the minister advise what rights taxpayers currently enjoy under the tax act?

—I am aware of the JCPA's very substantial report. I have not yet had the opportunity to examine it in great detail but I welcome the report and the general thrust of its endorsement of the direction in which the tax office has been going. The full range of recommendations will be considered by the government and there will be a statement on the government's position in due course.

PARA.TAB: One of the recommendations that has attracted some attention—and obviously that which is referred to in Senator Denman's question—is the proposal for the establishment of a taxpayers' charter, which even seems to have the endorsement of the dissenting report. It needs to be appreciated that taxpayers already have rights that have been established by the common law. I think the JCPA would support the right to be treated equally under the law, to object to an appeal, to rely on a private ruling, to seek an explanation, to be represented and to have documents remain confidential when they are prepared by a lawyer. Those rights do exist.

The most fundamental right—and the JCPA's proposal endorses that this should be in the charter—is the right to enjoy privacy in one's tax affairs. Most Australians would think that is a very fundamental element of rights as it relates to the tax act.

I was very surprised to find that, while the minority report endorses the charter and its recommendations, it attacks the tax office for failing to make available the tax affairs of a taxpayer. But I should not have been surprised because, in this very chamber on a previous occasion, Senator Bishop asked me to release the tax affairs of a taxpayer, and I declined. She knew that I would decline and she knew the tax office had to decline, so she asks questions to give herself a chance to trail a red herring across the path, and then say, `Shock, horror', when people fail to provide the answer, when she has asked a question that she knew they were bound by law not to answer. She continually does it and then says she is a defender of privacy and a defender of the rights of the taxpayer. Both cannot be right. The right of taxpayers to enjoy their privacy is very fundamental.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I raise a point of order. I am quite able to speak to my own report. My point of order is for the minister to address the question that was asked and to put him on notice that I will take note of his answer at the end of question time.
—Order! It is not a point of order but I am sure it will be debated again later.

—The thing I would most like is five extra minutes to talk about Senator Bishop's report. I thank her very much. That is exactly what I hoped she would do. My second round of the answer is directly related to my expectation that she would do that.

PARA.TAB: The minority report author claims to be the champion of the rights of taxpayers but continually tramples on the rights of citizens.Everybody knows what has occurred before committees of this parliament through Senator Bishop. I welcome the fact that every other member of that committee repudiated her unreasonable attack upon Mr Boucher. I welcome that. It is typical of people with media presence and no substance that they make these sorts of attacks. It is typical of people who have vapid and unfair proposals on tax policy in their report, who went absent without leave in the Mabo debate yesterday in their party room because the last time she tried she got howled down. It confirms the view that she is all tip and no iceberg.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. I draw the minister's attention to the fact that the bank profit reporting season is on us again this week. Nobody minds banks making profits, but I ask: is it a fact that Australian banks' margins are double the OECD average, and are running at four to five per cent on housing and up to 10 per cent on small business? Given that bank margins are the responsibility of the Treasury and the Reserve Bank, how will the government act to protect consumers and to enforce low interest rates?

—Far from nobody minding profits for the banks, I think most Australians are absolutely delighted that our banks are getting out of the red. I certainly am. It is in the significant interests of this country that our major banking institutions are returned to profitability. I welcome the fact that that is starting to happen as a product of a number of things, including improved management and the improved state of the economy.

PARA.TAB: I do not know the detail with regard to the profit margin to which Senator Kernot refers. I think most small businesses in Australia and most borrowers greatly welcome the fact that interest rates are substantially lower in Australia than they have been for a very long time and, as a result of a number of factors—principally the very low rate of inflation which is internationally comparable for the first time—it makes our interest rates very competitive.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about real interest rates?

—I accept that there is a different question about real interest rates. Nevertheless, it is true for investors that the rate is very low and that is very welcome. I can tell Senator Harradine that I do not dispute the fact that real rates remain high and there are some things we need to address with regard to that. This does not go to Senator Kernot's question concerning the margins which banks add on. What the government has done and will continue to do with regard to banking margins for customers is to provide competition in the banking system so that people can choose the bank from which they wish to borrow. Other than instructing people what rates they should charge, which is not what we intend to do, that is the most effective vehicle available to us.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Science and Small Business. I refer the minister to an article that appeared recently in the Bulletin entitled `Business turns a blind corner'. The author, businessman Mr John Gilmour, refers to his personal experience and concludes that small business is experiencing a boom. Would the minister comment on Mr Gilmour's observations, especially his assertion that the reduction in the corporate tax rate from 39 per cent to 33 per cent in the current year is almost a boom for many enterprises.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Schacht Sen The Hon C.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of the article written by Mr Gilmour in the Bulletin of late October. I also point out that Mr Gilmour is a member of the Small Business Council of Australia. In that article to which Senator Chris Evans refers, Mr Gilmour uses the description that small business is experiencing a boom. Those are his words; it is not a government description. He then goes on to give anecdotal evidence of his own small business as to why he believes the boom, as he calls it, is happening in small business in Australia, and I think it is very instructive.

PARA.TAB: For example, Mr Gilmour said that he wanted some printing done but the printer said he was too busy to take the extra work; Mr Gilmour wanted some radio advertising done but he noticed that a couple of free spots for advertisers was no longer on offer. Other people in the small business area have confided to him—and this is in the article—that business trade at the moment is very good. I inform Senator Ian Macdonald that when Mr Gilmour asked a cabinet-maker—another small business person—to quote for a job, he was told that it would take at least three months. He asked: what is going on? Despite all the doom and the pessimism which most members of the opposition are only too happy to talk about all the time to talk the Australian economy down, Mr Gilmour asked why the boom was starting to occur.

First of all, Mr Gilmour believes the official statistics are always one or two quarters behind what the real experience is. After discussions with his colleagues in small business, Mr Gilmour said the reason for this boom—and `boom' is the word he used, not what the government has used—is that costs are down sharply, wage costs are being contained, financing costs are collapsing as interest rates on borrowed funds are running at a third of the level of three years ago, occupancy costs are down and space is available for expansion, rentals are half those of 1989 and even tax is being reduced. The reduction in the corporate tax rate from 39 per cent to 33 per cent in the current year is almost the equivalent of a boom for many enterprises.

So Mr Gilmour has identified a number of areas where small business is really starting to kick along. I think it ought to be taken as a matter of great interest by all members of the Senate. As we have said before, we recognise that small business will be leading this economy into new growth and creating new jobs and, for the rest of the decade, that is where the action will be in the economy. Unfortunately, most members opposite do not wish to recognise that. Whenever we talk about small business we get catcalls and hisses from the other side. I want to draw the attention of the members opposite to the article by Mr Gilmour in the Bulletin and, in particular, to his final conclusion in that article when he said:

ANSWER.PARA: When the taxation data for the year to June 1994 emerge . . . they will prove what many small businesses know already . . . there's a boom.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Transport and Communications. I refer to today's latest disaster in the long-running pay television fiasco, for which I assume the senior minister for communications accepts full responsibility. Instead of behaving like a stunned mullet while Australia rapidly becomes an information technology backwater and an international laughing-stock, why will the minister not take immediate action to disqualify UCOM from any further participation in the satellite licence process? Why will the government not immediately release details of all the remaining bids?

—As I have often said to my colleague Senator Cooney—because I understand he was associated for many years with Senator Alston at the Melbourne bar—from time to time when Senator Alston makes these astonishing statements, I seriously doubt that he ever could have been a lawyer. Senator Alston knows full well the legal implications of doing what he has suggested. He knows full well the advice that the government has obviously received on those matters.
