He knows full well that it would be legally irresponsible of the government to even contemplate it.

PARA.TAB: One of the things that I have said in Senate estimate committees before in respect of this matter—and Senator Alston wants to dodge it—is that one of the reasons for the delay in the process was the amendment to the legislation moved by Senator Alston, opposed by this government and supported by the Democrats, to involve the Trade Practices Commission at this stage with a 45-day period for consideration. That was Senator Alston's own pet project that got put into law. The one thing I do know is that this matter will be resolved in the near future and the market will determine what the real value of those licences are.

The facts are that UCOM did not pay the balance of the bid price that was due yesterday; UCOM has now forfeited its deposit of $4.8 million under the provisions of the Broadcasting Services Act 1992. The one error that was made, and which has been canvassed widely in this parliament and, indeed, in the committees of this parliament, was corrected by legislation that went through this parliament—it was passed by the Senate. The market in the near future—and perhaps sooner than Senator Alston thinks—will determine the real value of those licences and the return to the government for that public asset.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. I ask the minister: further to recent reports of Australian commercial activity in Indo-China, can he inform the Senate how well placed Australian businesses are to participate in the emerging economic opportunities in the countries of the region? Could the minister also give the Senate some information on the successes that have been achieved to date?

—I appreciate Senator McKiernan's interest in this matter. I know that he has just returned from a visit to most of the countries in that region—no doubt they will all have very bright ties in the next few months!

PARA.TAB: The Australian embassy in Vientiane has reported that, on 8 November, Transfield signed a development agreement with the government of Laos for $A1.15 billion for a power station project. The development agreement fulfils part of a memorandum of understanding between Transfield and the government of Laos, which was signed in March of this year. The project is the largest ever negotiated by the Lao government. Australian interests had to fight off competition from United States, Japanese and European firms and are now ideally placed to secure final construction contracts. Australia's solid bilateral relationship with Laos has underpinned Transfield's success in that country.

The Nam Theun 2 is one of a number of major investment projects secured by Australian companies in Indo-China over the last year. Last April BHP Petroleum signed an agreement for the $US2 billion development of the Dai Hung offshore oilfield in Vietnam. BHP is a major shareholder in and operator of the joint venture.

More recently, Telstra signed an agreement with Vietnam's director general of post and telecommunications increasing its stake in Vietnam's telecommunications sector to more than $A200 million. At the third meeting of the Australian-Vietnam joint trade and economic cooperation committee on 6 October, Vietnam's trade minister, Mr Le Van Triet, described the Telstra/DGPT cooperation as Vietnam's most outstanding joint foreign venture to date.

These commercial successes in Indo-China are underpinned by sound and expanding government to government relations which have been developing steadily and surely with the countries of Indo-China over the last 10 years.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I draw the attention of honourable senators to the presence in the chamber of a delegation from the parliament of the United Kingdom, led by Sir Jerry Wiggin. On behalf of all honourable senators, I take great pleasure in welcoming you to the Senate and trust that your visit will be both informative and enjoyable.

PARA.TAB: Honourable senators—Hear, hear!

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services to the unprecedented back to back Keating creative fellowships awarded to composer Geoffrey Tozer. Does the minister agree with composer Ms Judith Clingan that `nobody on earth' deserved a second grant when so many people were still seeking their first? What guidelines are there for the awarding of back to back fellowships to the one artist when so many other deserving applicants remain unrewarded? Will the minister categorically deny that the Prime Minister had any influence, either directly or through his contacts on the advisory panel, in the awarding of these two fellowships, valued at $575,000, to his family friend Mr Tozer?

—The first question I get from the opposition on the arts is a little bit of sleaze—no substance, just sleaze. Even the Herald-Sun, which ran this story, said, `We are not making any allegations that Mr Keating was involved in any way and you would not'. Let me say very clearly that when the guidelines were originally set down in this scheme in 1988 they said that people would be able to get a second round of grants. It has been in the guidelines since 1988.

PARA.TAB: Of course, given that the first five-year round of fellowships has just expired, it is not surprising that no-one else has had two, but it has been in the guidelines since day one. Nobody should be surprised. There are strict guidelines. This matter is resolved at arm's length from the government by a committee of the Australia Council.

TALK.START.PARA: —How many have got back to back grants?

—I just tried to explain but, of course, Senator Hill was not listening. Will he just shut up and listen! This is the first time that the 1988 round of five-year fellowships has expired. How could there have been others? Why does Senator Hill not listen?

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. I very rarely take points of order in question time because I do not like to take up the time unnecessarily. But I just want to know whether you think it is appropriate under the standing orders to let a senator, or a minister—we expect lesser standards from ministers in this parliament—to tell someone else to shut up and sit down. Mr President, can I tell you to shut up and sit down? Why don't I tell you to shut up and see how far I get? You just let it go because he is one of your own.

—Order! Senator Vanstone, I resent that implication. It is unparliamentary. I would ask that it be withdrawn, but I would spend the whole of question time pulling people up if I took that to its logical extreme. Will you apologise, Senator McMullan?

—I certainly withdraw. All these decisions are made by an independent committee on the basis of applications made to it. It seems to me a gross reflection on that distinguished group of Australians to pretend that they in some way made this decision on the basis of some sleaze. Mr Tozer was chosen on his merits.

PARA.TAB: There are an enormous number of talented Australians who could well have qualified. It is a very vigorously contested process to determine who wins these fellowships, as it should be. It would be terrible if it were not because this is a proper recognition of the outstanding contribution of a number of outstanding Australians.

I welcome the fact that this capacity has been available since 1988. It has provided tremendous support to many outstanding Australian artists who have been able to make an even greater contribution because of the access to these fellowships. There is always a hot contest for them and people are always disappointed at the outcome because inevitably more people fail than succeed; that occurred on this occasion. But nobody should be surprised that the potential for a second round success exists because it has been in the guidelines since 1988.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I have a supplementary question. The minister said that nobody should be surprised—but they might be surprised, given that Mr Tozer reportedly said yesterday that he had been one of the catalysts for the federal government's setting up the awards in 1987 through his contacts with the then Treasurer, Paul Keating. Does the minister think it is appropriate that he has been an award recipient for 10 out of the first 11 years of the awards?

—I realise that Mr Tozer should be severely punished for the offence of knowing the Prime Minister. But it is actually a free country and he is entitled to apply even if he knows the Prime Minister. Even if he is a friend of the Prime Minister he is entitled to apply. Even if he knew Senator Patterson I suppose he could apply—that would not discount him. It might be an extraordinary confession, but it is still possible. I think it is appropriate that anybody who is selected by the independent committee receives the grant—it is that person's right. In a democracy even friends of the Prime Minister remain citizens.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Family Services. Is there any basis for recent claims in the media by the honourable member for McPherson, Mr John Bradford, that the government does not support traditional nuclear families? Can the minister inform the Senate of the progress of the government plans for the International Year of the Family and confirm the government's commitment to all Australian families?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen The Hon R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is absolutely no basis for the concerns expressed by Mr Bradford. This government supports traditional families and all Australian families, but it does not—like some on the other side—seek to label or judge them. The government has developed a great record in the area of programs and policies aimed at meeting the needs of Australian families. Indeed, its efforts over the last 10 years in government have made it a world leader in provision of services for families.

PARA.TAB: On 8 November, Mr Bradford was interviewed on Life Matters on Radio National about the formation of the Lyons Forum, described by Margaret Throsby as `a reasonably little-known ginger group in the coalition'. But when the honourable member for McPherson was asked to name the members of the Lyons Forum—named after Dame Enid Lyons—he declined. All he would say was:

ANSWER.PARA: Around forty coalition senators and members and all of us are more or less committed to taking up the cause of the traditional family. . . Well I'd prefer not to (name the members). Not that it's a secret society. . . we want to turn back a bit.

That sentiment is in complete contrast to what the government is doing. We do not aim to turn back; we aim to move forward. On this issue, the government is joined by many Australians and many vital institutions and organisations. I note that today the Australian Catholic Bishops Conference, as part of its contribution to the International Year of the Family, released a landmark statement on families in Australia. In the forward to the statement, Archbishop Clancy from Sydney says:

While reaffirming the primacy of the traditional two-parent family, the bishops acknowledge the development of other kinds of families and include them in this expression of their pastoral care and concern.

I believe that statement from the Catholic bishops is visionary and strong. I believe it also promotes tolerance and understanding for the diversity of families while recognising a central role for traditional families. I think the Australian Catholic Bishops Conference has made a great contribution to the International Year of the Family and it ought to be applauded for doing so.

PARA.TAB: Why can the opposition not understand that the country has left it behind? Australians do not want to go back to the future. When Mr Bradford was asked what he thought about his party and whether he thought his party was doing the right thing by families, he had this to say:

ANSWER.PARA: No, I think in the past we have been influenced because many members, I guess, are exposed to contemporary thinking about families, which really tends to be anti the traditional and nuclear family, and there's a lot of pressure on, I suppose, for us to appear to be relevant for the purpose of getting elected.

What Mr Bradford was trying to express is that the pressure of being relevant to Australian families is a bit too much to ask of the coalition. The government aims to support all families, and it judges them no more or less worthy because they are or are not what Mr Bradford calls nuclear or traditional.

PARA.TAB: In answer to the second part of the honourable senator's question, I want to inform the chamber that the government's plans for the International Year of the Family are proceeding very well. The year's activities will be launched by the Prime Minister in early December. The details of the year's activities will be released to coincide with that launch.

The year will culminate in the production of an Australian agenda for families—a blueprint that will take the government's concern for families well beyond the International Year of the Family. It will seek to be, and serve as, a guideline for and promotion of government concern for family policies well beyond 1994—indeed, to the end of this century.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Acting Leader of the Government in the Senate. Is it true that central heating has been installed for a dog kennel at the Prime Minister's Lodge at taxpayers' expense?
—I will have inquiries made. If the answer is in the affirmative, I will have Senator Chapman invited out there.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Attorney-General. I refer to my letter to the Attorney-General of 12 November 1993 raising the Australian Democrats' concerns about the Victorian Crimes Amendment Bill 1993. First, does the minister agree that the Victorian bill contravenes the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights—
—Sit down, you fool!
—Order! I ask that that be withdrawn. It is not parliamentary to call someone a fool. Senator Panizza, you said, `Sit down, you fool', and I ask you to withdraw it.
—I withdraw.

—Does it contravene that covenant as well as the international covenant on the rights of the child? Secondly, has the minister referred the bill to the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commissioner? Thirdly, is the minister prepared to take action to override those elements of the bill which are in contravention of Australia's international human rights and judicial process obligations under the conventions we have signed and ratified?

—I thank Senator Spindler for bringing the Senate back into the mainstream of public debate, raising an issue which is really of relevance to people and dissociating himself, and the Democrats in the process, from the sorts of diatribe and trivialities we find from the other side. Senator Spindler raises a question which is of concern. It is of concern not only to Senator Spindler but also to the government.

PARA.TAB: Mr Kerr, the acting Attorney-General, in fact has written to the Hon. Jan Wade raising this government's concern at both the totality of the legislation and specific aspects of it. He is concerned that the legislation, though still in its second stage, has the potential to infringe Australia's international human rights obligations under both the ICCPR and the convention on the rights of the child. In particular, the government has a whole raft of concerns which have been raised with the Attorney-General of Victoria. We are concerned about—

TALK.START.PARA: —It should not have been passed by this parliament.

—Senator Kemp would not be concerned. He would not know what to be concerned about. He should sit there in his isolation and vacuum and let us in this part of the parliament get on with the real issues.

PARA.TAB: The government is concerned in particular about issues such as the abolition of the requirement of a court order to permit police fingerprinting, regardless of whether or not a person has been charged with an offence. This may breach article 17 of the ICCPR and article 16 of CROC, as well as principle 4 of the UN body of principles for the protection of all persons under any form of detention or imprisonment. We are concerned also about the treatment of children under the age of 15 and above as adults for the purposes of fingerprinting. The concern of the Attorney-General is that this could be contrary to articles 24(1) of the ICCPR and article 40 of CROC.

There is further concern about the abolition of the judicial mechanism whereby children aged under 15 years and over 10 can challenge the reasonable grounds under which police can take fingerprints. The concern here is that this may be in contravention of article 12(1) of CROC as well as articles 42(4) and article 14(3)(e) of the ICCPR.

There are other concerns. There are concerns about the court's discretion in limited circumstances to admit fingerprints in evidence, even when the procedures for taking those fingerprints or their destruction were not followed. The concern here is that this may breach article 17 of the ICCPR and article 16 of CROC.

As can be seen, these are not all the concerns. Others have been raised in correspondence with the Victorian Attorney-General. Mr Kerr has also raised with the Victorian government whether it proposes to make any further changes to the bill to take into account these human rights concerns.

The second part of the question concerns HREOC. As Senator Spindler will understand, the human rights commission has already examined a draft of the legislation. It is having a continuing interest in the bills and the government is keen to see that interest continue. The government is also keen to see that all governments are concerned that they comply with our international obligations when it comes to these sorts of provisions.

Mr Kerr is having his department prepare an options paper to examine the possible measures to ensure that all states are meeting such obligations. In the meantime, we are concerned to ensure that the legislation that is being introduced complies with those obligations.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. With respect, the minister has not answered the last question. Could he please advise the Senate whether, in the event that the Victorian government does not change the bill to ensure that it complies with human rights obligations, the federal government is prepared to override it.
—The advice that I have is that the Acting Attorney-General is preparing an options paper for the government to consider what further action can be taken. I will have to leave it at that.

—The Minister for Defence may be aware that one of the members of Australia's Somalian peacekeeping force, Corporal Fiona Forsyth, is a member of the army reserve. The minister may also be aware of the substantial lift in morale that this type of worthwhile role creates in the Australian volunteer reservists. Will the government increase the number of Australian army reserve soldiers in our peacekeeping obligations, bearing in mind that other countries, namely Canada, use up to 50 per cent reservists in their peacekeeping operations?

—We have given it consideration, but we have not come to a concluded view. I acknowledge Senator Sandy Macdonald's point that the use of Defence Force reservists overseas is quite a large morale booster for the reserves. It should equally be understood that depriving regulars of the opportunity to serve overseas can have a depressing effect on their morale. There is no question that morale in many sections of the armed forces that have been involved in UN operations has been lifted enormously.

PARA.TAB: We train people in the defence forces and give them skills—skills essentially regarding killing others. We hope we never have to put any of those skills to use and that we have a peaceful and benign environment. The United Nations operations, generally with the full support of the whole domestic community in Australia and the rest of the countries of the United Nations, allow for those skills and the general training to be used.

We will give the matter consideration. But I point out one matter that makes me a little cautious: sending regulars overseas is also very important for their morale. In some cases, that must take priority. But we will look for opportunities to pursue in the future cases such as the one that Senator Macdonald has mentioned.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Minister representing the Minister for Trade inform the Senate whether the US Congress has voted yet on the North American free trade agreement? If so, what is the government's response to the result?

—The House of Representatives has voted on this matter. I believe that the result is 234 in favour and 200 against. We welcome the congressional vote on NAFTA as it represents a victory for outward looking forces in the US trade policy.
—That is not what you were saying last year.

—I will come to that. The congressional vote should provide the stimulus for the United States to seize the moment and push quickly for an even bigger outcome to the Uruguay Round of negotiations, which remains the single biggest issue facing the global trading community. The vote should also strengthen President Clinton's hand in pushing for continued trade liberalisation in the Asia-Pacific region through APEC and the historic APEC leaders meeting, which Prime Minister Keating will be attending in Seattle this weekend.

PARA.TAB: We recognise that NAFTA, as a significant agreement, may expand trade and investment opportunities in the North American market. Nonetheless, Australia still holds reservations about aspects of NAFTA. In particular, its rules of origin and local content requirements could lead to trade and investment diversion and operate in a preferential and discriminatory fashion. Australia will be monitoring the implementation of the NAFTA very carefully to ensure that the actions of the parties are consistent with their GATT obligations, especially that the free trade agreements should seek to facilitate trade between the members and not lead to raising of barriers to the trade of other countries.

We have had some concerns about the tenor of the Clinton administration's defence of NAFTA in recent weeks. Whilst we accept that the administration rhetoric has been coloured by the need to respond to often alarmist and ill-founded assertions of the NAFTA opponents, it is nonetheless worrying to hear the administration at its highest levels arguing that NAFTA will benefit the USA because it will disadvantage non-members in terms of access to the US market.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Crane Sen W.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. I refer the minister to Minister Brereton's comments at the NFF council this week, when he said:

QUESTION.PARA: . . . the export potential for meat is nowhere near being fulfilled.

He then went on to talk about a number of things, including production costs. I further refer the minister to the federal government's commissioned Harrison inquiry into the meat industry which reported over two years ago. This inquiry cost more than $1 million and included an overseas junket. I ask the minister: in light of Minister Brereton's statement of the obvious, when is this government going to seriously address the problems in the meat industry? Or did the government approve this expenditure of over $1 million with an overseas junket without any intention of following through with the recommendations?

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the best reply I can give to Senator Crane is that I will pass this question on to the appropriate minister and get a full reply on the status of that review.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Crane Sen W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question. I am rather disappointed, naturally, that the minister cannot respond to my question. Could I ask him also to address the issue of whether or not the real reason for the government's lack of commitment to the report of the Harrison inquiry is that the secretary of the AMIEU, Mr Wally Curran, stated even before the recommendations were brought down that he would still do what he wanted to do. Furthermore, when he was asked recently by Dr Mauldon of the Industry Commission about the Harrison inquiry, Mr Curran said:

QUESTION.PARA: Well, you say it's a non-event. Tell us it's a non-event if you—
Well, I will tell you now it's a non-event.
My question is: is not Mr Curran's intransigent attitude to the Harrison report the real reason why the government has not implemented the recommendations in the report?

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Before I call Senator Bolkus, I would say that it is very hard to have a supplementary question when no answer has been given to the original question. I think this is something that we will have to look at in the future, particularly taking into account that one minute is allowed for supplementary questions.

—I will take the question on board. I make this point at this time: we on this side of the parliament address issues, and address them in a rational way. We do not, as do those on the other side, go to personalities.Mr Curran is an individual with a point of view. We do not dismiss that because, firstly, he is Wally Curran or, secondly, because he is part of the trade union movement. We will take his point of view into consideration, as we will take the views of those opposite, if at any time they actually develop any points of view of relevance.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Arts and Administrative Services. I understand that the Van Gogh exhibition is opening tonight in Melbourne. In what ways, if any, has the federal government assisted with the mounting of this major collection?

PARA.TAB: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome the opposition's continuing enthusiasm for the success of the arts in Australia. I thank the Victorian government and the Queensland government for their support in this matter.

—Senator Boswell might not have noticed that an enormous number of people are getting jobs out of this. It is a very important exhibition. I welcome the cooperation of the private sector sponsors and of the state governments of Queensland and Victoria. It is only with the combination of the indemnification provided under the Commonwealth's indemnification scheme and the cooperation from Victoria and Queensland that this has been possible.

PARA.TAB: This is a very important exhibition, as have been the several other outstanding and successful blockbuster exhibitions which have been put on, principally by the National Gallery, as a product of the Commonwealth indemnification scheme. These exhibitions are important for several reasons.

Firstly, this exhibition simply provides an enormous amount of cultural stimulation and pleasure for Australians—and that is very worthwhile and important. Secondly, this exhibition is valuable because, as Senator Boswell so inadvertently but successfully interjected, an enormous number of jobs are created by the success of these major cultural exhibitions—jobs in the gallery, jobs in tourism, jobs in transport, et cetera. Thirdly, it is a very important contribution to the development of the skills and talent of young Australian artists.

One of the reasons why the National Gallery has developed this continuing program of major exhibitions—apart from their commercial success, which is very important in itself, and the economic benefits that flow—is their capacity to provide the stimulation, the encouragement and the great excitement that can flow for anybody who is interested in this, from seeing the best that is available. It gives young Australians who have the talent and who are contemplating developing a career in this very important part of employment—

TALK.START.PARA: —More Australians go to the art gallery than the football; that is why more people voted for us than they did for those opposite. It is very important that we continue to provide this opportunity because the Australian cultural tradition derives substantially from the combination of our wonderful indigenous culture, that European heritage which has been built on it, and the growing input from the Asian region. It is access to the best which all those sources have to offer which provides the basis for young Australians to develop their talent, to experience what is best and also to enjoy the substantial employment opportunities that flow from these sorts of initiatives. It is very worth while; that is why the Victorian government and the Queensland government have joined with us, as I am sure it is why the commercial sponsors have provided their support.

—My question, which refers to meat workers and meat workers' jobs, is addressed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. I refer the minister to the government's support for primary producers to have a direct involvement in processing and marketing beyond the farm gate and to Fosters Brewing's announced intention to sell its 45 per cent shareholding in the AMH to ConAgra, leaving the large US owned ConAgra with 95 per cent ownership. Considering that the AMH accounts for 23 per cent of all beef exports and 86 per cent of all beef slaughtered in North Queensland; that it had a combined turnover of $1.38 billion last year and is positioned for successful entry into the north Asian market; and considering also that the recently launched Farmers Investment Trust will know if it is in a position to invest in the AMH a matter of days after the FIRB decision is due; and as most export abattoirs are now foreign owned and competitive benefits would flow to the beef industry from Australian involvement in the $3 billion export industry—
—Mr President, can I have a bit of protection from these people.
—Order! There are too many interjections. You are well over time, but you have got a few seconds' grace.

—Thank you, Mr President. I am asking the minister whether he will ask the FIRB to delay the decision on the AMH ConAgra takeover for three or four days or a week until the Farmers Investment Trust is in a position to make a bid?

—Senator Boswell raises a serious question and I want to reply to it very directly. But I want to point out first that there are a lot more people employed in the cultural industry than in the meat industry.
—They are all on the dole.

—I said `employed'. I acknowledge and welcome Senator McGauran's interjection because it will be recorded in Hansard. A substantial number of people in Victoria work in the arts and cultural industries and I am sure they will note Senator McGauran's significant contribution. The only pity is that they did not get a chance to respond to his ignorant press release the other day. Fortunately, it did not get published.

PARA.TAB: Senator Boswell has raised a serious question that deserves a serious answer and I would like the opportunity to give it to him. The question of to whom Fosters will sell its share of AMH is a matter for Fosters. I know Senator Boswell is not saying other than that, but I had to say that first.

The government's job in relation to this matter and in accordance with its publicly stated foreign investment guidelines, is to consider whether or not to approve the proposed sale to ConAgra. It is a very sensitive matter and the FIRB is having consultations with a range of interested parties.

I am advised that the Assistant Treasurer has also written to the Cattle Council and the Cattlemen's Union inviting them to make a submission to FIRB on this matter. My present understanding is that a decision would currently need to be made by 1 December 1993. But I understand that that decision is not set in concrete. If the government does not feel there has been time for adequate consultation, there is scope for it to make an interim order.

My understanding is that the act requires a decision by that date but it does not have to be a final decision. That appears to be what the Assistant Treasurer's advice is leading to. This is a decision which the government can make only when it is provided with advice on the application by FIRB in the usual manner. But we are aware of the sensitivities of this matter and I note the important issues that Senator Boswell has raised.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.

—Under the 30-day rule contained in procedural order No. 15, I ask the Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs for an explanation as to why I have not received a answer to question No. 516 which I put on notice on 17 August 1993 concerning travel costs of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission.

—I do not know. I have not got any information about that outstanding question. If Senator Panizza had given a bit of prior notice that he wanted to raise this matter—as is the normal procedure—I probably could have got him either the answer or an explanation as to why he has not received an answer. I will have that matter addressed immediately and provide Senator Panizza with an explanation today.
—And the answer.
—I do not know about an answer, but I will certainly get an explanation.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Public Accounts Committee: Report on Taxation

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services (Senator McMullan), to a question without notice asked by Senator Denman this day, relating to taxation.

SPEECH.PARA: I said earlier that I was quite happy to talk about the minority report that was tabled yesterday entitled Taxation is inevitable, injustice is not. I said in the opening pages of that report that it was a report which was in addition to the majority report rather than dissenting from it, except in relation to the two particular issues of the majority report recommending the establishment of a taxation commission and my wanting to have a taxation board, which was subsequently supported by Mr Downer in a press release.

PARA.TAB: The other area of contention concerned the tabling and disallowance of rulings made by the Commissioner of Taxation which have the effect of making law which I believe should be made by the parliament. The other important area that I dealt with and I said was not dealt with in the majority report, was the question of the failure of the Commissioner of Taxation, since the 1985 tax summit, to publish estimates of the amount of revenue that should be collected.

In the last 10 years we have seen the Labor Party bring in so-called reforms which have been designed to close evasion and avoidance loopholes. The only way we can measure the success of that is if we see the amount of money that is available to be collected and measure that against the amount that is, in fact, being collected. Therefore, the most serious matter that I dealt with in my report relates to the fact that the commissioner has failed to produce these estimates and that since the mid-1980s the financial accounts of the Australian Taxation Office have been qualified by the Auditor-General. That is a very serious matter for the commissioner and for the tax office as a whole.

Let me deal with the other place and Mr Gear, who was having a quid each way too. He had not bothered to read the report—which, of course, one would never want to let get in the way of making a good point, would one? He said that I was commenting in my report on the need to further analyse self-assessment before it is fully implemented. I might add that the majority report made a similar recommendation.

The other point that needs to be made relates to the FBT and one other tax. I said these were outside the terms of reference and should be looked at by an external review to make them more efficient. But on the question of Mr Tony Wright, I think I have to be very specific.

TALK.START.PARA: —Wrong one.
—Mr Tony Wright was the bagman for the Labor Party—Mr Charles Wright, I beg the Senate's pardon. Mr Charles Wright was named in the Western Australian royal commission. The WA Inc. report found:

SPEECH.PARA: The other payments of particular concern were made to Mr Charles Wright, who operated a fundraising and business relations consultancy. He had done work for the ALP since 1976 in assisting with fundraising at the Federal level . . . Subsequently, Mr Wright made payments to Mrs Brush for which he was recompensed from the No. 1 account. In essence, Mr Wright was a conduit for $80 000 that was paid from the No. 1 Account to Mrs Brush. Mr Burke gave a similar explanation.

In other words, he was the conduit man for the disgraceful fundraising effort in WA Inc. The same Mr Wright was appointed by the ACT government to the position of head of the ACT Tourism Commission after he went bankrupt and went into liquidation. He was said to get that position because of his business experience. This is the same man about whom I asked the question in my report: why was it that, he, Mr Wright was not picked up for three years for failure to pay his PAYE tax and ordinary Australians, on the evidence of the tax office, were picked up almost immediately? That is the question which the tax office and the minister have refused to answer. It is a question perfectly legitimately on the public record and is not in breach of taxpayers' rights, which I and the majority of the committee support.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —I listened with great interest for the advocacy of that part of the Joint Committee of Public Account's report which related to the unwarranted attack on Mr Boucher, which was repudiated by all of Senator Bishop's colleagues, but I did not hear a word. I waited for a denial of the fact that in this place on a previous occasion she asked me to disclose the tax affairs of a citizen, and I refused.
—That's Mr Wright, is it?

—No, it is not. It does not matter who it was; it was something which I refused to do and Senator Bishop knew I would have to refuse to do it. With regard to Mr Wright, I have no intention of inquiring into, let alone disclosing—I do not even wish to know what the circumstances are with regard to businesses with which he is now, and may previously have been, associated—how he developed a tax debt, what the circumstances are or anything that arose. It is entirely inappropriate for the parliament to inquire into that, as everybody knows. It is not appropriate to attack the privacy rights of citizens. It is a serious slur, but it is exactly what one would expect.

PARA.TAB: One would have expected a more ringing response to those things that were said. I was a little surprised to hear such a lame explanation from Senator Bishop. There is plenty of opportunity, and I will welcome it, to debate any issues of tax policy such as those to which she alluded and about which she has made comments in other media—about abolishing the capital gains tax, the absence of which was, of course, at the very heart of the tax avoidance industry of the 1970s.

TALK.START.PARA: —Then get some measures in place to measure it; qualified accounts.

—That is a different question. If I get time, I would be delighted to respond to that. The issue is: what is the nature of the society that we will go to if capital gains tax is abolished again? We would have two different sorts of income: income earned by ordinary Australian workers, about whom Senator Boswell was so concerned, which is taxed on every dollar; and income which is otherwise earned, predominantly by those more affluent in our society, which is not taxed. That is not the basis of an equitable tax system. It also opens enormous loopholes for tax avoidance, as it was pre-1983 when the principal mechanism for tax avoidance was transferring income into capital. We have here an advocacy of going back to the bad old days. It would open the tax system to abuse.
—What about Mr Wright?

—I have dealt with that. It would, in its policy implications, be profoundly unfair. This builds upon this consistent pattern of allegation of preferred treatment which all her colleagues have repudiated. They said, `You have sought to make allegations that people got preferred treatment without any evidence at all that anybody has got preferred treatment'. The implication is that there are some people in the tax office who are acting improperly. There is a slur. All these people are just slurred in the hope that Senator Bishop can make a political attack on Mr Wright and maybe on me. This is not a serious issue about which I am losing any sleep but it may be that someone else is.

PARA.TAB: It is entirely unfair to seek to raise questions as though the tax officers had any capacity freely to answer questions about tax affairs. Second Commissioner Nolan has made clear the difficulties which he has with regard to that matter on the record in the estimates committee hearings. I respect Mr Nolan and I know Senator Bishop—whatever her other criticisms are—has said she also respects him. He has put the nature of the problem adequately on the record. What we have here is the continuing attempt to do two things: to reduce the equity of the tax system and take it back to the bad old days; and to use the privilege of the parliament and the knowledge that there are secrecy provisions in the tax act to slur the reputation of individuals under the cover of privilege, while failing to give any evidence at any stage to support those unreasonable allegations.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would also like to comment on the response given by Senator McMullan. I was somewhat disappointed with Senator McMullan in that I thought he had more substance than to organise such a dorothy dix question and give such a puerile answer; it rather surprised me. The major point of Senator McMullan's response was that Senator Bishop had the audacity to write a minority report. That is an action to which anyone in the committee is perfectly entitled—certainly on our side of politics, but apparently it is a privilege not available to people on the Labor side of politics. If they go down that track they will find themselves in coventry.
—Not true; check the record.

—What a beautiful interjection. I remember in the old place Senator Georges being accused by those opposite for going down exactly that track—being called a scab and collapsing in the parliament. That is the effect it has on their people. Senator Bishop in her report said:

SPEECH.PARA: I concur with many of the recommendations of the majority report but found the need to supplement those recommendations where they did not completely maximise the sovereignty of the taxpayer.
I do not see anyone objecting to that. In regard to the Commissioner of Taxation, she went on to say:

. . . his responsibility is to administer the taxation laws in a fair and just way rather than be the instigator of harsher and more repressive taxation measures. The Parliament has an essential role in ensuring the laws it makes are administered fairly—
and so on. There is not one person in this house, in this chamber or throughout Australia who would object to that remark.

PARA.TAB: Senator Bishop made some points which are slightly different from those recommended by the committee—again, this is Senator Bishop's point of view. I might say that those changes are fairly marginal. One point relates to public rulings. The committee decided—and I thought about this at great length before I decided to agree—that public rulings should just be tabled in the parliament rather than be subject to disallowance. But Senator Bishop decided that, because they are a form of delegated legislation, they should be subject to disallowance.

My reason for not going that route may be of interest. I thought that as there is already a form of appeal, perhaps at this stage public rulings should just be simply tabled; that if this does not work, let us look at disallowance. These remarks were made by the chairman of the committee at a press conference yesterday.

The other major aspect of Senator Bishop's report is her preference for a board of taxation rather than a commission. I frankly did not see a large difference in the approach taken, but Senator Bishop did—and there is nothing wrong with that.

Senator Bishop highlighted the point that the current Prime Minister (Mr Keating) was given preferential treatment by the tax office when he was Treasurer. This was not part of the report; it was never considered by the committee because it was properly considered to be outside its terms of reference. But that does not stop Senator Bishop in her minority report from reminding the people of Australia that the man who is currently Prime Minister received preferential treatment from the tax office. I will just comment on that.
Mr Keating forgot to lodge his tax returns in 1985 and 1986. He received a very friendly letter reminding him that he had not lodged his tax returns. The letter stated:

SPEECH.PARA: I appreciate how busy you have been but I ask that you now give urgent attention to the filing of your returns . . .

The answer provided at an estimates committee hearing was that the ATO, the tax office, had obtained 10,794 convictions for non-lodgment of returns in the 1990-91 financial year. And yet the man who is now Prime Minister of this country got a cuddly, warm letter from the Deputy Commissioner of Taxation. Senator Bishop highlighted this simply to indicate that here we have a man, who is now Prime Minister, who went down the line written about by George Orwell. Honourable senators might recall that in Animal Farm the leading pig was a fellow called Napoleon. Napoleon took over the animals and made the famous statement:
All animals are equal but some animals are more equal than others.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is appropriate that I answer what Senator Parer has just said. He is absolutely right: Senator Bishop is entitled to put in a dissenting report or, as she says, a report that adds to what is in the committee's report. What I took Senator McMullan to be saying is that he disagreed with some of the material in that report. Just as Senator Bishop is entitled to put in a dissenting report, surely Senator McMullan is entitled to make points about what appears in that report—and I would have thought that Senator Bishop was more than able to look after herself.

PARA.TAB: Senator Bishop raised the question of Mr Wright. The chair of Estimates Committee D, Senator Coates, who is noted for his fairness in these matters, passed me a copy of the Hansard for Tuesday 9 November 1993. On page 525 there appears some material relating to program 6 and dealing with taxation administration and the way things are raised in estimates committees. Senator Coates introduced the item by saying:

SPEECH.PARA: The first item concerns the affairs of Mr Charles Wright. Senator Bishop has informed us that she has no questions about the matter. We will incorporate the letter from Brian Nolan, second commissioner, on this matter. It answers the issue raised at the previous hearing.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, it does not.
—Senator Bishop intervenes and says that it does not answer the question. It is a matter for people who look at this in a fair way to judge whether it does or does not. The letter reads:

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Richard Gilbert
Secretary
Estimates Committee D
The Senate
Parliament House
Canberra ACT 2600
Dear Mr Gilbert
At the hearing of Estimates Committee D on 2 September 1993, I undertook—

`I' being the second commissioner of taxation, a person who wrote this letter not ostensibly as a member of any political party. I do not know whether he is a member of any political party but he certainly does not appear before the committee on that basis—

to investigate the substance of a question by Senator Bishop as to whether there had been less than proper pursuit of a PAYE debt attributed to a particular company that is subject to winding up proceedings.

As I indicated to the Committee at that time, I am unable to discuss details of the tax affairs of any company or individual. I wish to place on record, however, that I have examined this matter in the meantime and I am satisfied that neither the company nor any director received any form of preferential treatment. I can also report that there was no external or internal interference with debt recovery processes.
Yours sincerely
(B.M. Nolan)
Second Commissioner of Taxation

TALK.START.PARA: —That does not answer the question.
—Senator Bishop has interjected and said that it does not answer the question. It becomes an issue of whether that letter is an answer to the question. Mr Nolan said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . I undertook to investigate the substance of a question by Senator Bishop . . .

According to his understanding of what the question was, he said that it was answered here. It is proper for Senator McMullan to comment on what is contained in a report by any senator, whether Senator Bishop or anyone else, and it is proper for this letter that has been sent by Mr Nolan to be read out.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crane Sen W.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Senator Bolkus) in response to a question without notice asked by Senator Crane this day, relating to the meat industry.

SPEECH.PARA: My question today to Senator Bolkus as Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, Mr Crean, related to statements made by Minister Brereton to the NFF conference this week with regard to problems in the meat industry in Australia, particularly in Victoria. He said:
. . . the export potential of meat is nowhere near being fulfilled.

He then went on to comment about outdated methods of production, low utilisation of rates for productive capacity and limited investment in market research and development. At least two of those components relate directly to the farm component, particularly the financing of the investment in market research and development.

PARA.TAB: I rise to speak on this matter because in 1990, with the encouragement of the then Minister for Industrial Relations, Senator Cook, the AIRC commissioned an inquiry into the meat industry and the problems which existed then, which was known as the Harrison inquiry. It brought down its report just two years ago. The recommendations that came out of the inquiry were sabotaged even before they were brought out. It was sabotaged by none other than Mr Wally Curran, of the AMIEU in Victoria, when he made a categorical statement that he would not take any notice of the recommendations. That is exactly as it has turned out.

Since that time, we have seen the efforts to implement those recommendations totally frustrated. In my view they were good recommendations, albeit paid for by taxpayers. They included, as I said in my question, an overseas junket to collect information—a trip that was not necessary because all the information had already been obtained in this country from previous inquiries. The Industry Commission has now been commissioned to look into the meat industry, and we have exactly the same person frustrating that course of action. I will quote from the Industry Commission transcript dated 12 August 1993 of Dr Mauldon questioning Mr Curran. In answer to a question with regard to the Harrison report, Mr Curran said:

SPEECH.PARA: Just a non-event.
Dr Mauldon questioned Mr Curran further on this matter, to which Mr Curran responded:
Well, I will tell you now it's a non-event.

In reading the transcript, we find a deliberate attempt to totally sabotage this inquiry. Much of the comment in this transcript is quite derogatory. In another answer we once again see the contempt that is held for the rationale of getting serious about the problems which exist in the industry. Certainly, it has been acknowledged on both sides of this chamber, particularly by Senator Cook and me, that there are serious problems in the meat industry in this country. We saw another example of disgraceful contempt when Dr Mauldon said:
I don't know who they are.
Mr Curran responded:
The rural community—cockatoos.
Later, Mr Gruen said:
We might want to quote you.
Mr Curran responded:
Yes, you can. When you see them out in the paddocks, you say, "Well, there's a group of the farmers, the galahs or the cockies, picking over the seed."

While this sort of attitude remains on one side of the equation, in terms of reform in the meat industry, it will never be reformed. I do not care what argument we hear from the other side of this chamber on this matter; until the government stops wasting money on these reports, picks up the recommendations of a series of reports into the meat industry that we have already seen, promotes the implementation of these recommendations, which have been sound and well based, and gets on with the serious job of doing something about it, we will continue to see this industry being treated with absolute contempt and being held to ransom by one individual—Mr Wally Curran of the AMIEU. It is time it stopped.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to speak to the matter that has just been mentioned of the role of Wally Curran in the meat industry. It has, of course, been stated here today that the problems of the meat industry can be put down to one person and that the problems that face the rural industries in Australia can be put down to one person. From what I know of Wally Curran, I am sure that he would regard it as quite flattering to assume that he has such extraordinary power and influence over the affairs of this country. It is quite an extraordinary observation to say that one person can be attributed with all the responsibility for the problems within the meat industry of this country and, of course, within the rural industry of this country.

PARA.TAB: I have known Wally Curran for a long time. What I can say about him—and many things are said by others about what sort of a wicked man he is—is that he has a dedication and commitment to the meat industry that extends over nearly 40 years. Wally Curran has a dedication and commitment to servicing his members and he has a dedication and commitment to ensuring that workers in rural communities, often isolated and often working in the most foul conditions, are allowed to have some sort of voice in our society.

Wally Curran has a commitment to ensuring that there is decency in the way in which people are treated in rural communities. He has a commitment to understanding how and why our society operates in the way it does and the way in which some employers operate, particularly members of the National Farmers Federation, and particularly in Victoria where a war has been launched against meatworkers in that industry. I have not seen him do anything to warrant the sorts of accusations we have heard here today.

We have also noted that Wally Curran has ensured, through the various enterprise agreements that have been undertaken in Victoria, substantial improvements in the conditions of workers and the operations and effectiveness of the meat industry in Victoria. We have seen exports improve dramatically. However, we have seen a small group of people around the National Farmers Federation in Victoria, such as at Seymour Meats and various other places, such as around the Colac district, with the connivance of police authorities and various other instrumentalities of the state, undertake quite serious breaches of the law. Very serious matters have been raised in terms of fit and proper persons operating within the meat industry.

It would be appropriate, I would suggest, that if we are going to look in a balanced and fair way at the way in which things are operating within rural communities, for the National Farmers Federation to look at the sorts of people it has been supporting and look at the reasons why it has been such an abysmal failure in the various campaigns it has launched in Victoria. I draw this to the attention of the Senate because the matters that have been raised relate to Victoria. Yet, according to the honourable senator opposite, Wally Curran has such control over the national government that the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Crean) has to consult with him on every move. I wish that were true, but unfortunately it is not the case.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate Standing Committee on Rural and Regional Affairs is at the moment holding inquiries into two pieces of legislation relating to AQIS charges. As a result of that, we have visited a number of meat processing plants. I see Senator Crane is leaving us.
—I'll come back. I have a meeting to go to and I'll be late for the meeting, but I will come back.

—Good—not that Senator Crane should be late, but that he should come back. During those visits, we talked about changes which were taking place in the meat processing industry, which are very important. I agree with what Senator Crane said about some of the changes that must take place, but my point is that I made certain that I asked questions of the various processors about the role of the meatworkers union and of Wally Curran in this process. On one occasion I was told that Wally Curran had had his share of knocks, but it was found that he was a decent person to deal with, and was very cooperative and supportive of changes in the meat industry.

PARA.TAB: On another occasion, a large processor said that Wally Curran did not necessarily agree with his views, but recently an agreement was made with Curran and the AMIEU which would operate within that particular meatworks. It was an enterprise agreement that was working well and they had great hopes that it would go a long way towards the sorts of changes that they believe are needed in the meat industry. On no occasion during the discussions I had with those people did I get anything but a positive response with regard to the role of the meatworkers at this time, their approach to the changes in the meat industry and Wally Curran's role as leader of that the AMIEU.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

So, as I understand it, Mr Keating's dog has to suffer the vicissitudes of the Canberra winter like all the other Canberra dogs.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to make a personal explanation as I claim to have been misrepresented.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday in question time, as reported on page 3010 of the Hansard, Senator Schacht, when answering a question, said:

SPEECH.PARA: that citizen-
I thought I heard the words `a citizen'—
may not have carried out his duties under the laws of the land.
I interjected with the words, `That has happened before'. Senator Schacht then said:
It has happened before; that is true. Senator Alston has smeared a lot of people in his time.

When I said `That has happened before', I meant that it has happened before that a citizen of Australia has not carried out his duties under the laws of the land. I did not state or agree with the suggestion that Senator Alston has smeared a lot people in his time. I want to put the record straight on that.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The documents read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: Deputy Prime Minister and
Minister for Housing, Local Government and Community Services
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Mr R L Chynoweth MP
Chairman
Joint Standing Committee on the National Capital and External Territories
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Mr Chynoweth

I am pleased to forward you a copy of the Government's response to the joint Standing Committee on the National Capital and External Territories' June 1993 Report, City Hill: Review of the Draft Master Plan.

I would like to take this opportunity to thank the Committee for its efforts in completing the inquiry promptly. The Committee has played a major and very positive role in determining the future of City Hill.

The Government generally accepts the recommendations of the report and many are currently being acted upon. Some of the recommendations involve the Australian Capital Territory Government and accordingly I am forwarding a copy of this response to the relevant ACT Minister.
Yours sincerely
BRIAN HOWE

The Parliament established the Joint Committee on the National Capital (formerly known as the Joint Committee on the Australian Capital Territory) to inquire into and report on, inter alia, the National Capital Plan and amendments to the Plan. The Committee proposed, and the then Minister for the Arts and Territories, the Hon Wendy Fatin MP agreed on 30 October 1992 that the Committee consider the proposal to amend the National Capital Plan to incorporate a proposed Master Plan for City Hill.
The Committee had not tabled its report and ceased to exist when the 36th Parliament was dissolved for the March 1993 federal election.

On 27 May 1993 the Joint Standing Committee on the National Capital and External Territories was established and it subsequently sought to resume the inquiry. The Minister for Housing, Local Government and Community Services, the Hon Brian Howe MP agreed to refer the matter to the new Committee on 1 June 1993.

Both the Joint Committee on the National Capital and the Joint Standing Committee on the National Capital and External Territories held public hearings on the draft amendment. Both the ACT Planning Authority and the National Capital Planning Authority gave evidence.

On 23 June 1993 the Joint Standing Committee on the National Capital and External Territories presented its report to Parliament. The major recommendations of the report are that the amendment not proceed in its present form and that a revised Master Plan be prepared. Other recommendations address issues of heritage conservation, traffic arrangements, building heights, pedestrian access and land use.
The recommendations of the report are generally accepted and it is acknowledged that the Commit-
tee has played a major and very positive role in determining the future of City Hill.
Many of the recommendations are currently being acted upon. Some involve the Australian Capital Territory Government and accordingly a copy of this response will be provided to that Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to make a few brief comments in relation to the report entitled City Hill—Review of the draft master plan. It is pleasing to see that the government has accepted all the committee's recommendations, some of which acknowledge the role of the ACT government. The start of paragraph 1 of the report states:

SPEECH.PARA: City Hill is an important symbol to the people of Canberra.
It subsequently states:
A Master Plan for City Hill is needed.

But we believed that the plan we were reviewing at the time was not the one that should proceed. We referred to a number of that were less than adequately dealt with. In particular, we felt that the traffic arrangements for the new master plan had not been examined in as great a detail as was necessary. I note that the government's response indicates that that will proceed.

PARA.TAB: A number of matters were raised in the report. The consequence of this response is that the magistrates building, which was planned to be erected on Vernon Circle, cannot go ahead on that site in its proposed form. I am not at this stage aware of what steps will be taken to provide a magistrates court, which is undoubtedly needed.

I do not think there is point this afternoon in going through the issues. I note that the government has accepted the recommendations, and I am pleased that that is the case. To the extent that City Hill still does not have a master plan, I note that the NCPA is working on it. I shall be maintaining an interest in what develops in that area, as will, I am sure, the other members of the committee.

TALK.START.PARA: —As a member of the Joint Committee on the National Capital, I wish to support Senator Reid's comments. I want to say the obvious, of course, that Canberra really is the national capital, as well as the home of many Canberrans. In so far as it is the national capital, it is pleasing, I think, to recognise and note that this parliament, comprised of representatives from all over Australia, has an interest in things that happen in the national capital, particularly in the national capital aspects. I am pleased to have been a member of the committee making the recommendations to which the government is responding today.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The response read as follows—
