Mr R L Chynoweth MP
Chairman
Joint Standing Committee on the National Capital and External Territories
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Mr Chynoweth

I am pleased to forward to you a copy of the Government's response to the Joint Committee on the National Capital's November 1992 Report, Our Bush Capital: Protecting and Managing the National Capital's Open Spaces.

Only four of the Committee's 40 recommendations were not accepted. Some of the recommendations involve the Australian Capital Territory Government and accordingly I am forwarding a copy of this response to the relevant ACT Minister.
Yours sincerely
Brian Howe
JOINT COMMITTEE ON THE NATIONAL CAPITAL
OUR BUSH CAPITAL: PROTECTING AND MANAGING THE NATIONAL CAPITAL'S OPEN SPACES
NOVEMBER 1992
GOVERNMENT RESPONSE TO THE RECOMMENDATIONS
RESPONSE TO THE RECOMMENDATIONS

The Parliament established the Joint Committee on the National Capital (formerly known as the Joint Committee on the Australian Capital Territory) to inquire into and report on, inter alia, issues relating to the significance of Canberra as the National Capital.

On 17 December 1991, the Minister for the Arts, Tourism and Territories, the Hon. David Simmons MP, asked the Committee to inquire into and report on nature conservation policies and environmental management practices within those areas of open space in the ACT which are of national significance. In particular, the Committee was asked to:

PARA.TAB: inquire into and identify the ecological, symbolic, landscape and recreational values of the `Inner Hills' component of the National Capital Open Space System;

examine the relationship between, and the adequacy of, current planning and management arrangements for those areas of the NCOSS which are Designated Areas under the National Capital Plan, and for those areas to which `special requirements' apply;

examine the current legislative and other protection afforded to areas within the NCOSS and make recommendations for the types of protection appropriate to the different environments within the NCOSS;
consider the impact such protection might have on future urban and transport planning;
identify potential long and short term threats to areas within the NCOSS and suggest how these threats might be avoided or minimised;

examine the administrative and financial arrangements between the Commonwealth and Territory governments for the management of the NCOSS with recommendations as to how these arrangements might be improved; and
examine such other matters as the Committee may consider relevant to the subject of the inquiry.

SPEECH.PARA: These terms of reference were endorsed on 18 February 1992 by the then Minister for the Arts and Territories, the Hon. Wendy Fatin MP.

On 5 November 1992, the Joint Committee on the National Capital tabled its report titled Our Bush Capital: Protecting and Managing the National Capital's Open Spaces. A brief response to each of the Committee's 40 recommendations is on the following pages. Only four of the Committee's recommendations were not accepted. Some of the recommendations involve the Australian Capital Territory Government and accordingly a copy of this response will be provided to that Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

TALK.START.PARA: —Again I should like to acknowledge the government's response to this report. It has been later in coming than perhaps some of us would have hoped, but at least we now have it.

PARA.TAB: I note that the government has significantly accepted the recommendations of the committee. It has pointed out, as we knew at the time, that some of the things that we had recommended were not Commonwealth responsibilities, but to review the open spaces adequately it was necessary to refer to all of them, whether they fell within the Commonwealth's or the Australian Capital Territory government's area of responsibility.

This response, even more than the other one that I have just referred to, has within it a number of items into the future—things that have to be done and are being done at the present time. It covers the area of the inner hills, the Molonglo corridor, the Murrumbidgee River corridor, Namadgi National Park, the National Botanic Gardens and its boundaries and a number of other areas.

I am pleased with the response to the present time. These are important areas of the national capital and I and the committee will continue to monitor and meet with the NCPA as to how these things are developed, to make quite sure, I guess, that the recommendations which the government has accepted in fact come to fruition.

TALK.START.PARA: —Again I wish to place on record my support for what my colleague Senator Reid has said. This was not an inquiry in which I was totally involved. It started before I was made a member of the committee. I was not able to get to a lot of the committee meetings. But I want to congratulate the committee members on the report and note the government's response. I particularly wish to pay tribute to my colleague Senator Reid, who is, of course, a senator for Canberra, for the tremendous work she has done in overseeing the interests of the national capital in her role in this committee.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—Firstly, I must thank Senator Harradine and Senator Margetts for being prepared to support my proposal. The Democrats advised me that they were not able to support me as they have an informal arrangement that restricts their ability to move more than one urgency motion per fortnight and if they had supported my motion, they would not have been able to move a motion next week, if they so wanted. I regret that that actually brings about a situation where my motion about democracy illustrates a problem with democracy in this chamber.

PARA.TAB: The standing orders relating to matter of urgency debates require one plus four senators to raise a matter of urgency. This discriminates against the ability of independents and small parties to bring matters of urgency before the chamber. I would like it noted that this state of affairs is discriminatory and violates the principle of democracy in itself. I proposed this matter of urgency today to highlight the actions of the Tasmanian Liberal government to change the number of members of both houses of the Tasmanian parliament with only a week's notice of its intention and with no consultation with the electors of Tasmania.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order relating to procedure. As I understood it, leave was given to the Greens to explain the matter of urgency; it was not given to make a substantive speech on the matter at this stage. If Senator Chamarette has used that as a device—I am sure she would not have intended to—she would be abusing the leave of the Senate. If she wants to deliver a substantive speech, other aspects of the standing orders are available to her. I also understand that she may have taken this course to save time rather than to cost time. The matter has been before the Senate, and there were no senators standing in their places to support the matter. Therefore, it is not possible for Senator Chamarette to deliver now the substantive part of her speech, if that was her intention.
—Order! Senator Chamarette, do you want to speak to that point of order?
—I will accept your decision, Mr Deputy President, and then perhaps I will seek leave for something else.
—In a precise sense, what Senator Ray raises is correct. Leave was granted by the Senate for an explanation in respect of the matter.
—Pursuant to contingent notice of motion, I move:

PARA.TAB: That so much of the standing orders be suspended as would prevent Senator Chamarette moving a motion to provide for the consideration of a matter during general business this day, namely, a motion in relation to democratic electoral procedures.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Acting Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —The government will not be supporting Senator Chamarette's motion. When the proposition was put to consider this matter of urgency, let alone Senator Chamarette complaining about the overall barrier, there was not one single senator here to support the proposition. We are all realistic politicians and we realise that the timing of events in this chamber sometimes is unpredictable and that one can get ambushed. No-one thought it proper at the time to call a quorum to enable Senator Chamarette to get here. That situation should be noted for the record.

PARA.TAB: The government's position on this has always been that we will support our own urgency motions and matters of public importance and no-one else's. It is a consistent attitude we have taken, whether it be with the Democrats, the Nationals, the Liberals, the Greens or Senator Harradine. We support our own matters of public importance and no-one else's. What has traditionally occurred in this chamber is that the rest, if you like, the non-government people, get together if necessary to overcome the various hurdles to get a matter of public importance or an urgency motion up. The government does not interfere with those arrangements and we do not vote for anyone else's matter of public importance or urgency motion to come on.

Senator Chamarette today has complained about the effect of standing orders. It is not that this chamber has been insensitive to that. Some years ago, there was a problem for at least two senators in as much as each motion that was put before this chamber needed to be seconded. Through the standing orders committee, we removed that provision. If Senator Chamarette believes the provision for one senator plus four is wrong, she should take the matter up with the Procedure Committee, or ask the Deputy President here today whether he would be willing to refer it to the Procedure Committee, and then it may be looked at.

The original reason for having that provision in the standing orders was so that there would at least be some indication that a matter was of enough importance to be raised. I do not think it was there to persecute minority parties in the Senate, even though it may have that effect. There were and are today other opportunities for Senator Chamarette to have addressed and to address this issue. The matters of public interest discussion was on between a quarter to one and 2 o'clock today. Admittedly, there were quite a few speakers and, if we had our druthers, we would have preferred to get legislation through. Nevertheless, an opportunity was there.

Dare I say it—and I can say it with full confidence—there is ample opportunity in the adjournment debate tonight, in which I am not the duty minister, for Senator Chamarette to express long and fulsome views on this matter, having been frustrated here today. I am not going to comment on the urgency side of it—whether it is urgent that we discuss this matter or otherwise, and whether any discussion will have an effect.

I understand the points that I think Senator Chamarette would have made in her substantive speech. I refer her to an article I wrote in one of the fabian documents some years ago, which would give her a plethora of material on which to base an excellent speech. Basically, I concur entirely with the principle of Senator Chamarette's proposed motion; it is just a matter of the procedures of this place. If we had stood today to support Senator Chamarette's matter of urgency, we would be expected to do so on all occasions. At least we are consistent. As a government we say that we will support our own urgency motions and no-one else's.

We on this side of the chamber have been very responsible in terms of matters of public importance and urgency motions. We would be lucky if we moved one in a three-year period because we cede this particular ground to other members of the chamber as part of the balance in this chamber of who gets allocated time to pursue which issues. On those bases, the government is not minded to support Senator Chamarette's contingent notice of motion to bring on the urgency motion.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Chamarette, it might be helpful if I explain to you that you do not have a further right to speak and that the five minutes allocated to you was the five minutes you were able to use when you moved your contingent notice of motion. That is not to say that leave cannot be granted by the Senate if it so chooses.

—Mr Deputy President, could I speak to that and ask for a review of your decision? I did seek leave to make a short statement. As I understood it, I was going to delay the chamber for the least possible time and make what remarks I could. I was prevented from doing so and I therefore stopped speaking. It was because I was prevented from actually making the short statement on the content that had been opposed on a point of order that I sought the suspension of standing orders. So I have not been able to defend for my five minutes the suspension of standing orders or to present the context in which I considered that my urgency motion was urgent.

—Senator Chamarette, the position is this: you have moved, pursuant to your contingent notice of motion, for the suspension of standing orders to allow you to do certain things. You had five minutes available to you at the time, but you chose not to exercise it. Senator Ray then rose and spoke and he extinguished your right to further speak. But all things are possible with leave, and if the Senate were so minded it could give you leave to speak for the balance of your time.
—I seek that leave because it was in error that I sat down. I did not understand that I had the call and could continue for my five minutes.
—Is leave granted?

—As I understand it, Senator Chamarette is seeking to suspend standing orders in order to be able to move her urgency motion. That is correct, if nobody tells me it is not. It is in an unusual circumstance. I think we have been pretty generous to the government's program recently in relation to matters of public importance and urgency motions. We have called on very few, largely to facilitate the progress and processing of the legislative program. Generally speaking, the spirit of this place is that if somebody thinks a matter is of such urgency that it should be debated, the chamber facilitates that request.

PARA.TAB: As I understand it, the problem on this occasion is that four senators did not rise in their places. This meant that the standing order could not be complied with. There is an alternative procedure that could have been adopted. Had Senator Chamarette given notice of this matter of urgency, it could have been dealt with in the time allowed for general business today. As I understand it, there was time allowed for general business today but we made the decision not to take up that time. So there is actually time within today's program for a short debate on this particular issue, even though the opposition neither agrees with Senator Chamarette nor thinks that the debate is urgent at the moment.

I anticipate that it will not be a long debate. I think that Senator Archer from the opposition will respond briefly to Senator Chamarette's argument. I cannot see why that debate should not take place, being restrained by the commonsense approach that it should not take a long time. Therefore, in these unusual circumstances, I am prepared to support the suspension of standing orders.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will speak briefly to the motion before the chair. Senator Hill has indicated what the opposition intends to do. I will not be taking part in the debate but I wish to very briefly draw the Senate's attention to fact that the Democrats have refused to support the Western Australian Greens on this motion which relates to Tasmania. I notice that Senator Bell is in the chamber and he is a senator from Tasmania. I would have thought he would have taken this opportunity to discuss this matter.

PARA.TAB: The attitude of the Democrats in not cooperating with the Western Australian Greens is very interesting. I suspect that it might have something to do with the fact that Senator Devereux, currently in the Labor Party, is confidently rumoured to be about to join the Western Australian Greens and work in Tasmania. This is something which the Democrats in Tasmania greatly fear because there will two parties of the ultra Left fighting for the environmental or other very left-wing votes in Tasmania. The Democrats fear that Senator Devereux might represent Tasmania as a Green and take away some of the very minimal backing that the Democrats have in that state. I suggest that that is the reason the Democrats have refused to support their far left-wing allies in this chamber, the Western Australian Greens, and give them the necessary numbers to enable this motion to be discussed without this rigmarole.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner Sen J.P.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: VETERANS' AFFAIRS; DEFENCE SCIENCE AND PERSONNEL

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Manager of Government Business in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I think that this is an absolutely extraordinary situation. If Senator Hill's view was that the Senate ought to concern itself with this particular debate, the appropriate course of action would have been for him to show sufficient leadership to allow the requisite number of senators to stand in their places so that we could have avoided this motion for a suspension of standing orders.
—It is wasting time.

—It is doing nothing more than wasting time. It seems to me that the opposition has changed its mind on five occasions so far. It makes any attempt to manage the chamber virtually impossible. It seems an extraordinary situation that 20 minutes ago opposition members did not want to have this debate and did not rise in their places to enable this urgency motion to be dealt with, yet now they have changed their minds.

PARA.TAB: Senator Ray has outlined the principle the government works on. I explained that to Senator Chamarette earlier in the day. It is a clear principle. The government only stands in its place to support an urgency motion or an MPI that has been sponsored by a government senator. That is the government's clear position. It has been applied consistently and it was applied on this occasion.

On the other side of the chamber there are four or five opposition senators arguing amongst themselves because they do not have a clue about what is going on. What is the end result? We had general cooperation around the chamber—and to be fair including from the opposition—that we would get on with government business. I accept that there has been some cooperation from the opposition on this point today. But now, instead of having a debate on this motion limited, as agreed by the whips, to one hour, Senator Hill is proposing to support a suspension of standing orders and an open ended debate.

TALK.START.PARA: —No.
—Oh good, he has changed his mind again. I am very pleased about that.
—It is back under control; you can sit down.
—I am very pleased to hear that, Senator Ray. As always, I take Senator Ray's advice. I am very glad that Senator Ray can understand what the opposition is doing because I certainly cannot.

—In supporting the suspension of standing orders, we would encourage the opportunity for an airing of this debate—a debate that is very important to Tasmanians and those involved in the Tasmanian political system. I would have welcomed the opportunity to have an extended debate on this matter of urgency had we also had the opportunity to consider the content of the actual motion.

PARA.TAB: After all, we only have to look at the front pages of two Tasmanian newspapers today to see the concern. The Hobart Mercury has a headline `Groom rushes to cut MP numbers' and the Examiner from Launceston is concerned that there might be more accords invoked by the government's revolutionary tie breaker mechanism. This is a matter of great importance in Tasmania. I wonder whether the way the motion has been compiled by Senator Chamarette is the best way to look at it. This motion confronted me earlier this morning and I would have appreciated an opportunity to negotiate on its content. If that had occurred, the Democrats would have supported the opportunity to debate the motion and debated it fully.

The reason proffered by Senator Ian Macdonald's confused and tortured mind is not the reason we were not ready to support this motion. It was the reason I have just given. Senator Macdonald has probably spent just a bit too much time with the sun on his navel and it has obviously affected his brain.

If the suspension of standing orders is supported, we will have a short debate. It is not the debate which we would prefer. We would prefer a debate on Tasmania's forests, GATT, the employment levy proposition or tariffs. For my part, I would like to have a debate on the Federal Airports Corporation. Perhaps if the opposition is talking about Tasmania, it might like to talk about the closure of HMAS Huon. We would welcome that opportunity tomorrow. What we have here is the promise of a short debate. Only on the strength of that promise can we accede to the suspension of standing orders.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like some clarification because I am getting confused. I would like to move the motion. Do I have five minutes to speak?

—I will put the record straight. The understanding is that we will now move to general business. We will discuss documents as we normally do for up to an hour. When that is completed, Senator Chamarette will be given the opportunity to move her motion. I understand the time limit will be approximately 40 to 45 minutes. There will be one speaker from the government, one from the opposition, one and half from the Greens and perhaps one from the Democrats. That is how we will proceed. Senator Chamarette should not leave the chamber, because if the discussion of government documents collapses she will be on.

—Order! At the risk of interfering with arrangements made between the various groups and the chamber, may I say, with respect, that the procedure is to be as follows: Senator Chamarette will formally move, without speaking, a motion to bring on the debate in general business.

PARA.TAB: Motion (by Senator Chamarette) agreed to:

That a motion to provide for consideration of democratic electoral procedures may be called on during General Business as if it were a notice of motion and take precedence over other notices of motion or orders of the day other than orders of the day relating to government documents during general business.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Department of Employment, Education and Training

PARA.TAB: Motion (by Senator O'Chee) proposed:
That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tierney Sen J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on the annual report of the Department of Employment, Education and Training which has been presented today. In particular, I want to refer to the direction of higher education in this country, as revealed by this report and as revealed by a number of other committees that have met in recent times. The shape of what is emerging for higher education under this government was summed up this morning in the Sydney Morning Herald which said that what used to be Dawkinisation has now become the Beazleyisation of the university system.

PARA.TAB: I wish to distinguish between those two things. The Dawkinisation of universities was the jamming together of the CAE sector and the university sector, creating enormous trauma in the system in a period of growth. I alluded to this extensively whilst speaking about a DEET report yesterday. What has come out in this annual report and what has come out in the newspapers in the discussion of the Beazleyisation of universities is the grand plan under the new Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Beazley). Basically, that will stunt the growth of the university sector.

Here we have a party in control of a country at the moment which put out a document at the end of the Hawke era saying that it wanted to create a clever country, and it is creating a clever country by moving resources away from the university to the TAFE system. There is nothing wrong with the development and expansion of the TAFE system in this country; that is to be encouraged. This government neglected TAFE for over 10 years, suddenly discovered it again, and by the creation of ANTA and other means, it is putting resources into TAFE. That is great; that is to be commended.

But because its policies have been inappropriate in higher education for so long in terms of generating enough sources, the government has put a cap, as the Sydney Morning Herald called it this morning, on the university sector to slow down and stunt the growth of universities. It has dressed this up by saying, `Well, we're doing great things for new areas'. Yesterday Senator Robert Ray picked up the wrong briefing paper and started talking about the redistribution of money in the system.

TALK.START.PARA: —I didn't have a briefing paper.

—Whatever notes the minister used, he misunderstood the point of my question. It was not about redistributing money in the system to the growth areas, which is commendable and is what should happen. I was talking about the slowdown in the total growth of the whole university sector, which can be seen by the fact that the number of new places that will be created from 1996 on, specifically in 1996, is only 1,500 across 36 universities. That comes to a very small number of students per university. What we have seen is a tragedy for young children in this country who aspire to a university education. I had the opportunity of a university education, as many of us here had, and it certainly was not as difficult to get into university then as it is now.
—What was the retention rate for senior high school under Fraser?
—The retention rate under this government is much higher, and the driving force is the high unemployment rate.
—You did absolutely nothing in this area.

—Let us look at the comments that the minister made yesterday. He said that in Victoria there is a higher participation rate in universities and a higher number of students want to enrol. Of course they do, because of the appalling employment double whammy created by the combination of a Victorian Labor government and a federal Labor government. Obviously more

SPEECH.PARA: people want to go to university because they cannot get a job! The government touts the increased participation rate, but it is largely driven by the lack of jobs. Those who want to go to university cannot get in because each year the tertiary entrance score goes up. Why does it go up? Because there are not enough places for those who aspire and are qualified to get in. Yesterday I gave the example of my son who will have huge difficulty getting into the school of architecture. That is a disgrace for him and all other children who aspire to a university education. (Time expired)

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tierney Sen J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: I seek leave to continue my remarks later.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: The report of the National Legal Aid Advisory Committee raises a number of extremely important issues. It deals with the Dietrich case, amongst other matters, which decided that a person charged with a criminal offence may be the beneficiary of a court deciding that that person requires legal representation and, therefore, legal aid, despite the fact that that person may have exhausted the normal avenues that are open to him or her to obtain legal aid through the legal aid commissions. It is difficult to disagree with that judgment. It would be a principle of natural justice for a person accused of a crime before an Australian court to be able to be legally represented by a professional person. I think that would be acknowledged.

PARA.TAB: Nevertheless, it should be stated—I think the report acknowledges this—that this has resulted in a considerable drain on the funds available for other cases. There must be some concern about the pressure on funds, for instance, for family law matters where the threat of domestic violence and custody matters are concerned. Mr Acting Deputy President, you, more than anyone else in this chamber, would be aware of the traumatic experiences that people go through when they are involved in that sort of conflict. It would seem to me that this advisory committee might be able to give some attention to the priority rating that family law cases have.

I want to raise one of the issues that I bring up on a regular basis. I note with some regret that, apparently, the committee has not addressed this matter, either during its proceedings during the year or in its report. I again make the point that the interest that solicitors derive from trust funds should not be allowed in part to flow to their guarantee fund, which in turn reimburses members of the public who have been damaged by the defalcations of fraudulent solicitors. It seems to me that the legal profession, if it professes to be self-regulating, should look after its own black sheep and not utilise the interest from trust funds. These are funds which do not belong to the legal profession; they are funds placed in trust. They should therefore be used for public purposes, including exclusively and totally for legal aid, and should not flow in part to make good the defalcations of fraudulent solicitors.

I want to address one final point. I searched in vain—I may have overlooked this because I have not had much time to look through this report—but it does not appear as though the National Legal Aid Advisory Committee has recommended to the government to increase the allocation to legal aid funds. Legal aid funds in this current budget were increased very marginally, not at the rate of inflation. In other words, in real terms there has been a reduction of money available to legal aid commissions.

It seems to me that it would have been one of the functions of the National Legal Aid Advisory Committee to address that matter when up to 50 per cent of applications for legal aid are rejected for lack of funds. Could I suggest that the National Legal Aid Advisory Committee start doing its job and advise the government on the level of legal aid funding that is necessary in a civilised society.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator McKiernan)—On behalf of the President, I present a letter from the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Senator Gareth Evans) relating to the resolution of the Senate on 26 October 1993 concerning the extension of the United States export enhancement program to China.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: I acknowledge the response of the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Senator Gareth Evans) to the United States concerning its decision to offer up to 100,000 tonnes of heavily subsidised barley for sale to China. However, I must stress that Australia should not lessen its pressure on the United States in regard to this matter. The Australian government must, at every opportunity, remind the United States of our close cooperation and friendship. We are that country's firm friend and ally.

PARA.TAB: It is vitally important to all Australia's grain growers that this continued attack on a market which has been traditionally ours is not allowed to continue. The United States cannot credibly use its usual excuse that it was using the export enhancement program to respond to subsidised grain exports from the European Community, because in China this was clearly not the case. The EC has not operated in the Chinese malting barley market for two years. Even then, it sold only a small volume to fill a shortfall in supply from Australia. Up to 40 per cent of Australian malting barley is exported to China, which is a vital and important trading country to us.

The United States President, Bill Clinton, assured the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) that the effect of the export enhancement program on Australia would be limited and would not undermine Australia's interests. This is clearly not the case. The future role of export subsidies depends heavily on whether the next GATT round is signed on 15 December. If it is signed—and I am optimistic that it will be—export subsidies will be wound back over time. This will mean that there will be some light at the end of the tunnel for Australian farmers who are some of the most efficient and least subsidised producers of food in the world.

The Europeans are being dragged to the GATT table only because they understand that the game is up. Agricultural subsidies just cannot be maintained forever, because the cost of keeping the subsidy house of cards standing becomes unbearable to taxpayers. The French remain a main stumbling block for GATT. The French government has little proper political balance as far as its farmers are concerned. I simply say to the French government—not only in regard to Australians, to whom the French show great personal friendship, but also to the whole of the farming world—that France should be better world farming citizens for everybody's sake.

Australia's export markets are forever being squeezed between the United States and the Economic Community. We must continue to support the GATT rounds. We must protest in the strongest possible terms to the United States government and highlight the corruption of world trade through subsidisation. Australian farmers will be in the forefront of the export recovery necessary to get out of our unemployment hole. Their prosperity is Australia's prosperity.

TALK.START.PARA: —This response from the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Senator Gareth Evans) arose from a formal motion that I moved on 21 October in this place after the United States had signed a 100,000 tonne barley deal with China under the export enhancement program. The United States may claim that China is a traditional market for the sale of its barley. But this has never been the case. Australia is the traditional supplier of barley to China.

PARA.TAB: Last year, grain growers from the eastern States had a disastrous season, although grain growers in the west had a good season. Because Australia was not able to supply all the barley that China needed, the United States, probably at the invitation of the Australian Barley Board, supplied the balance. It was hoped that this arrangement would operate for only one year. On the pretence that barley could be coming into China from the Common Market—it is always a pretence when the Americans go into our traditional markets—the United States has done a deal involving up to 100,000 tonnes of barley at a highly subsidised figure.

This development is doubly disastrous for Australian barley growers, and Australian coarse grain growers in general. There has been a swing away from wool growing because of low prices. Generally speaking, higher rainfall areas that traditionally grow wool have swung into coarse grain growing—that is, barley and oats. As I say, Australian coarse grain growers are facing an extra hazard as a result of the action of the United States.

I certainly hope that the government keeps up the pressure. To date, all it has done is write to the US embassy in Canberra and pass on the resolution to our embassy in Washington. I suppose that is all the action that the government could have taken to date, but let us hope that it does not forget to follow it up if a response is not made available soon.

I, like the rest of the Senate, value the friendship of the United States. As I have said many times, I wish the United States would treat us as its allies in trade in the same way as we consider each other allies in everything else that happens in different places around the world, especially when a bubble occurs.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
