TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the documents.

SPEECH.PARA: In the course of the supplementary estimates hearings, questioning by Senator Short could have been construed as reflecting adversely on Mr Gerry Hand, the former Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, in connection with his application for registration as a migration agent. In accordance with the requirements of the procedures for the protection of witnesses before Senate committees adopted by the Senate on 25 February 1988, the committee provided Mr Hand with a copy of the relevant transcript of evidence. I have today received a letter from Mr Hand which has just been incorporated into Hansard.

PARA.TAB: I must say that I am disturbed by what seems to me to be an increasing occurrence of personal attacks by opposition senators, either on witnesses before committees or on people mentioned in questions before committees—attacks which, if made outside the protection of parliament, would be slanderous or libellous or both, attacks which are personally hurtful and damaging to the reputations of the individuals concerned.

Senators should, I believe, exercise extreme caution in checking facts before making accusations about any individual which might in any way damage the reputation of that individual. In this case Senator Short referred to a court report in the Age in which Mr Hand, a subpoenaed witness at the court hearing, was referred to as `now a migration agent'. Senator Short went on to claim that he had had the transcript of evidence from the court case in question checked. I refer to page 214 of the Hansard report of Estimates Committee F of 12 November 1993. It states:
Senator Bolkus—Have you checked the actual
proceedings to see what he did say?

TALK.START.PARA: —That is my understanding.

PARA.TAB: Senator Bolkus—Through the Age report?

TALK.START.PARA: —No.

PARA.TAB: Senator Bolkus—You have actually checked the
proceedings?

TALK.START.PARA: —I have had them checked.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Short concluded that this showed that Mr Hand had said in evidence that he had acted as a migration agent and that this was before his registration as a migration agent was approved.

PARA.TAB: The letter from Mr hand which has just been incorporated into Hansard shows that this is clearly not the case. I quote from Mr Hand's letter. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: On 11 June 1993 I appeared on subpoena in the Mok case. I was asked by Counsel:
Question: Mr Hand, your present occupation?
Answer: Primary producer, consultant but not doing a lot because I have been on the stand for this case.
I must say that is a classic Gerry Hand response. The letter continues:
Question: The consultant's—is that the migration consultant or . . .
Answer: I have registered as a migration consultant to comply with the law because you are unable to give advice to anybody, as you would be aware, without registering; that is now the law.
That is at pages 1683 and 1684 of the transcript of evidence of that court case, the Mok case.

PARA.TAB: Clearly Senator Short had neither checked the transcript of proceedings, nor had he had it checked. Yet he was prepared to imply dishonest, if not illegal, behaviour on the part of Mr Hand under the privilege of parliament—implications which, if uttered outside, would be clearly defamatory. I must say I am surprised and disappointed at Senator Short, whom I regard usually as a reasonable and fair person and not somebody who involves himself in these sorts of personal cowardly attacks in the parliament.

I ask Senator Short, though, to imagine Mr Hand's anger and distress. He expected and could cope with attacks when he was in parliament and a minister, but now out of parliament and trying to carve out a new life and a new career for himself, he finds himself the subject of cowardly attacks which, as I have said, are totally baseless. It is not an isolated incident—I am not suggesting that Senator Short has been involved in a number of these other incidents—but it does appear to be an increasingly common practice within the Senate.

It is a serious reflection on the attitudes of senators opposite to the individual rights of others, particularly as they regard themselves as the champions of individual rights. It is a serious reflection on the lack of attention to detail. Frankly, it is to be deplored.

The second matter I wish to raise very quickly was raised in the report also, and that refers to some procedural difficulties that we had. There was a recommendation in the report that we refer the matter to the Procedure Committee for its consideration. I foreshadow now that, following the resumption of the second reading debate of the appropriation bills later on today, I will move an amendment to give effect to this.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: I wish to say a few words on this matter and to respond in the strongest possible terms to Senator Beahan's comments which I regard as quite monstrously misleading and wrong. I have spoken with Mr Hand about this matter. He rang me after the estimates committee hearing last week and we have had a discussion about the matter. I said to him that, depending on developments over the next few days—including, as I was aware, the request by him to provide material—I would be saying something here in the Senate when the appropriate occasion arose, which is now.

PARA.TAB: I must say to Senator Beahan that I totally reject the proposition that I made a personal attack on Mr Hand. I also totally reject—I think the estimates committee Hansard speaks for itself—that I in any way implied illegal or dishonest actions by Mr Hand. In the Hansard to which Senator Beahan referred, Senator Bolkus asked me:

SPEECH.PARA: Are you asserting that he—
Mr Hand—
may have performed the function of a migration agent without being registered as one?
My response was:
That is what I am trying to seek clarification of.

I was trying to seek clarification because of the reports in the press and the court transcript which, as I said, I had had checked; although I had not read it myself, I now have. Senator Beahan has quoted parts of that transcript. What Mr Hand said in court on 11 or 12 June—after he had made application to become a registered migration agent, but weeks before his application was approved—could have been interpreted as suggesting that he had held himself out to be a registered migration agent. In his correspondence to the estimates committee, he has quite accurately quoted from the court transcript. When he was being questioned about his present occupation, Mr Hand said:
I have registered as a migration consultant to comply with the law because you are unable to give advice to anybody, as you would be aware, without registering; that is now the law.

That statement was technically incorrect. He had not registered as a migration consultant at that time; he had made application for registration as a migration agent. Technically, he was incorrect. That was the point on which I was trying to seek clarification. The other point that I raised at the hearing related to the article in the Age at about the same time—I think the following day—which said:
Mr Hand, now a migration consultant and primary producer, was giving evidence in an application by three Cambodian women . . .
It was a case before the courts. I repeat that the report said:
Mr Hand, now a migration consultant. . .
In the letter received today by Estimates Committee F which has now been tabled, Mr Hand stated:
Any implication in that article—
that is, the Age article—
that I was already practising as a migration agent is incorrect.

I very much welcome that statement by Mr Hand. That is precisely the statement that I had been looking for when I first raised the matter at the estimates committee hearing in September. It was the point that I discussed with Mr Hand in a fairly vigorous conversation about the matter last Friday.

PARA.TAB: In fact, Mr Hand has today—and I very much welcome it—corrected the implication in the Age article by saying that it was incorrect. It did say, `now a migration consultant'. He never did take any action to correct that statement at the time. I accept the point that he made to me over the phone in our discussion last Friday. He said, `I do not read those papers. Why should I?'. That is a fair enough point. However, he did not take the action which he has now taken as a result of my question last week. So I welcome the fact that he has set the record straight through the parliament.

Similarly, I accept the point that he is obviously making in his letter, although he does not say it specifically, that he was technically incorrect in the court hearing in saying that he had registered as a migration consultant. He had not; he had made application for registration.

TALK.START.PARA: —He said that he has registered, not that he is registered. It is quite clear.

—He had not registered; he had made application for registration as a migration agent. The important point that arises from this is that we now—and I welcome it—have on the record a clarification of the two points that were raised. It is very important that we have done that.

PARA.TAB: I very deeply resent the specific comments made by Senator Beahan about my motivation in this matter. I have always respected Gerry Hand. He knows that, I think—I would hope. We have had a quite close relationship at the professional level in Victoria over many years by virtue of our mutual interest in and association with a wide range of ethnic communities. It was never my intention, nor would it ever be, to deliberately cast aspersions or anything worse on Gerry Hand. I never had that intention. I do not believe that a careful reading of the Hansard record of the estimates committee would support Senator Beahan's allegations. I totally reject that. I am glad that the matter is cleared up.

I assure Mr Hand here in the Senate today that I have never doubted his integrity. He is a man of considerable integrity, as I think I said in the estimates committee hearing last week. I am glad the matter is now cleared up beyond anyone's doubt. I do deeply resent the way in which Senator Beahan has raised this matter today. Now that it has been raised I am very glad that all the points of possible misunderstanding which did arise, I repeat, from a technical—and I agree it was technical—mistake in Mr Hand's description of himself at the court hearing and from his failure to correct the Age mistake have been dealt with. Those two things were what led to this situation. The matter is cleared up to more than my satisfaction and I hope that the matter is now closed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McKiernan Sen J.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not intend to spend a tremendous amount of time on this subject matter, but I welcome the debate. I particularly welcome Senator Short's closing remark that he intended no malice in his questioning at the Estimates Committee F hearing last Friday. I was at that estimates committee hearing and I got very close to coming out with a more vigorous defence of Mr Hand because I discerned a thread of what appeared to me to be innuendo and inference in the line of questioning that Senator Short was addressing to the minister and to the departmental officers about Mr Hand's current profession as a registered migration agent. I accept his final comments and I am prepared to give him the benefit of the doubt on this occasion.

PARA.TAB: However, I am going to carefully watch and scrutinise him in the future. I recall some years ago in this chamber Senator Short attacking Mr Lewis Kent, another close friend and parliamentary colleague of mine, under parliamentary privilege. Mr Kent had the benefit of being able to defend himself in parliament. Mr Hand does not have that benefit. I do not think that as members of parliament we should be abusing the privilege that is given to us by virtue of the fact that we sit in this place.

In defending himself, Senator Short referred honourable senators to the Estimates Committee F Hansard. He said that if one reads it carefully, one cannot say that he was in any way directly attacking Mr Hand. I will refer to two questions that were addressed to the minister and the departmental officers. Page F214 of Hansard says:

TALK.START.PARA: —We might. Did the department note that, in the course of the legal proceedings reported in the Age, Mr Hand had incorrectly given evidence to the court that he was at the time a registered migration agent?

SPEECH.PARA: In the court record, which Senator Short told us he checked, Mr Hand never said anything of the sort. He said that he was a registered migration consultant. That is completely and utterly different from a migration agent for which registration is required. In actual fact, in his letter Mr Hand said:
The Committee should note that I stated that "I have registered" not "I am registered".

That question Senator Short asked led me to believe and support the comments that Senator Beahan made in raising this matter this afternoon. A further question from Senator Short was recorded thus in Hansard:

TALK.START.PARA: —My understanding is that in the court proceedings that were reported in the Age Mr Hand had advised the court that he was, at the time, a registered migration agent. If that advice is correct—as we can all check, but I understand it is—what action, if any, did the department take in relation to the incorrect statement?

SPEECH.PARA: There was a thread of questioning, as indicated in those two questions, that did not directly attack Mr Hand but from my perspective certainly contained innuendo and inference. Senator Short will remember that on two occasions I made a contribution at the estimates committee. That is something I am very loath to do at estimates committee hearings.

PARA.TAB: The opening questions in this line of questioning drew implications as to whether or not Mr Hand had received any form of favoured treatment in his registration as a migration agent. The first two questions Senator Short asked, which were taken on notice, had an innuendo that registration had taken place earlier. Mr Hand's response, which has been incorporated this afternoon, clearly lays down when the application was made and when registration took place. From my quick calculation of the dates—from 6 May through to 9 July—it is not within that 64-day limit which is mentioned in the Hansard of Estimates Committee F.

I am pleased that the matter has come on today, not only because the actions of a friend of mine are being debated but also because it raises the matter of parliamentary privilege and of `coward's castle' as this place is sometimes called. We do, and I say `we' collectively, abuse that privilege which is given to us in this place. I do not think we should do that. I certainly hope that we do not see a repeat of what occurred last Friday when what I believe to be an attack occurred on the integrity, character and honesty of an individual who certainly does not deserve it.

In closing, I accept Senator Short's closing remarks that there was no malice intended. I hope that Mr Hand is now satisfied with the comments that have been made and that we will hear very little more about this in the future. I also make a plea that if people are reporting this debate in the papers they report it accurately and not inaccurately like the Age newspaper did in this instance. Such inaccurate reporting sends people off on tangents.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will make some short remarks about this matter. Senator Short has come in and acknowledged the misunderstanding that existed. I think he quite candidly said that he considers Gerry Hand to be a person of integrity. I think that should be the end of the matter and, in fact, it is.

PARA.TAB: I rise to speak in this debate because I want to put the remarks in context. Mr Hand was called as a witness in a case by Mr Rose, who, as I understand it, was acting for the applicants or the plaintiffs. When any witness is introduced to a court he or she must give his or her name, address and occupation. If one reads through that part of the court transcript, it puts the whole matter in context.

Mr Hand was called at 2.17 p.m. I am not sure who was hearing this case, but I am sure, being a member of the Federal Court, he was a man of great learning. Mr Rose said, `If Your Honour pleases, I call Mr Hand.' Mr Rose then asked Mr Hand to go to the witness box. Mr Rose had to take Mr Hand through the formal parts of the case before he reached the substance of what Mr Hand was called for. So Mr Rose asked for his name, address and occupation. When asked for his occupation Mr Hand said that he was a `primary producer, consultant'. He did not say that he was a migration consultant. I think he consults on matters other than migration. For example, he has been assisting people interested in Aboriginal affairs. After His Honour made a remark, Mr Rose asked Mr Hand:

SPEECH.PARA: The consultant—is that the migration consultant or. . . ?

I suppose that did need some explanation. If Mr Hand said `yes' he was wrong and if he said `no' he was wrong because, as Senator Short said, he had applied to be a migration consultant. Nowhere does he say that he has been registered as or is acting as a migration consultant. What he is saying—and this can be obtained from the transcript of the case—is that he had put himself down to become a legal migration consultant.

PARA.TAB: Then the matter goes on to the issue in hand. After the formal parts that needed to be gone through to get Mr Hand properly introduced to the court, Mr Rose then went on to the question of the Cambodian boat people. So this issue arose as part of the formal proceedings of the court, not the substance of the case. Senator Short no doubt looked at that and said, `Leaving aside the court proceedings, does that mean he has acted as a migration agent?'
The only other point I would like to make is in defence of the department itself. In pursuing the matter in the estimates committee, Senator Short said:

SPEECH.PARA: My understanding is that in the court proceedings that were reported in the Age Mr Hand had advised the court that he was, at the time, a registered migration agent. If that advice is correct—as we can all check, but I understand it is—what action, if any, did the department take in relation to that incorrect statement?

It was not for the department to take any action in respect of the incorrect statement; that was a matter to be clarified in court. Senator Short has now explained that, in asking that question—I hope I have understood him correctly—he was not suggesting that the department should follow up whether or not it was an incorrect statement in reference to the court proceedings but whether or not Mr Hand had undertaken work for which he was not registered. I use that as an illustration in both cases where we have to be cautious in the meaning we take from the use of words. Whether in court, estimates committees or elsewhere, it is always advisable to try to see what people mean by the words they use.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak briefly on this matter, not because I had intended to speak when the matter was first raised and when Senator Short gave his explanation of events, but because, much to my disappointment, after Senator Short had made it quite clear that he intended to make no reflection whatsoever against Mr Hand—in fact, he said words to the effect that he regarded Mr Hand very highly—other senators rose to speak. We heard a rather vigorous presentation by Senator Beahan against Senator Short. I do not criticise him for that in the circumstances. Senator Short then gave his explanation very precisely and put his position very clearly. He is one of the people in this place whom I regard with the highest esteem as he is a vigorous debater and one who tackles issues head-on; he is also a very fair person. I would have hoped that after Senator Short gave his explanation it could have been left at that, particularly in view of the fact that Senator Short highlighted the fact that he discussed the matter with Mr Hand. I sincerely hope that this matter will now come to an end, having heard a number of speakers.

PARA.TAB: I was not at last Friday's hearing, nor have I read the Hansard, and I doubt whether I ever will read the Hansard. I think it is quite pointless to continue this debate when Senator Short has made his position absolutely crystal clear. As other speakers have said, I sincerely hope that this is the end of the matter and that it is not carried on outside. I have no doubt that at some future time, maybe even over a beer sometime—or maybe not over a beer—Senator Short and Mr Gerry Hand will discuss this matter. I sincerely hope that it is not carried on beyond this point. I do not think it was necessary for it to have gone past Senator Short's explanation.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the report of the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs on the effectiveness of the Financial Transaction Reports Act 1988, formerly known as the Cash Transaction Reports Act 1988, entitled Checking the cash, together with the transcript of evidence and submissions received by the committee.

PARA.TAB: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.PARA: This report of the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs deals with the operation of the Financial Transaction Reports Act 1988. Amongst other things, the act sets up a body called AUSTRAC to monitor certain types of financial transactions. AUSTRAC is held by Mr Bill Coad, an outstanding leader of undoubted integrity. He is ably assisted by Mr Graham Pinner. If the issue before the committee was the quality of AUSTRAC's management, the committee would have no difficulty in reporting most positively on it. However, the committee was asked to inquire into the way the act has worked since it became law and the report is directed to that issue.

PARA.TAB: The Financial Transaction Reports Act 1988 is one of a range of measures taken in the last decade to prevent and detect crime. Other measures taken include the establishment of the National Crime Authority at the federal level, the setting up of the independent commission against crime and corruption in New South Wales and the Criminal Justice Commission in Queensland.

Commonwealth bodies which exercise policing powers include the Department of Social Security, the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs—the minister for which I might say, since he is in the chamber, is a quite outstanding figure, not only as head of the department but also as a great civil libertarian—the Australian Taxation Office and the Australian Securities Commission.

Australia contains many bodies investigating people who live within its shores. The traditional police forces of the territories, the states and the Commonwealth are increasingly having their work carried out by other authorities. This raises the issue of how far that trend should go. Because there is a multiplicity of investigators, it does not follow that a multiplicity of crimes will be solved. It is in the public interest that crime be detected and punished and that people in the community be able to go about their lives freely and confidently.

The liberal, open and democratic society cannot accommodate every available means by which people can be examined about their activities. Totalitarianism might accept any sort of inquisition and any sort of examination of its people's activities but our sort of society does not. It is a thought that was well expressed in 1846 by Vice-Chancellor Sir J.L. Knight Bruce, when, as you remember, Mr Acting Deputy President, he said:

SPEECH.PARA: Truth, like all other good things, may be loved unwisely—may be pursued too keenly—may cost too much.
We should always remember that when we are looking at the issue of the powers we give to others to police people who live within this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who said that?
—That was Sir J.L. Knight Bruce.
—What is his connection to the chair?

—His connection to the chair is that they are both eminent lovers of the law. Policing powers should be monitored by parliament. It should grant increases in them only on the basis of compelling evidence. It should not be prepared to do so simply because they are asked for by any particular policing authority. I make those opening remarks because I have a few things to say about some of the committee's recommendations. I noticed in some notes prepared for me that attribution is given to the Costigan royal commission as being one of the origins of this act. I am not sure whether that is so or not but I can say that it was the Costigan commission that began following the money trail in a big way. That was very successful. But there is a distinction to be drawn between having a royal commission investigate a particular matter and having the powers of a royal commission institutionalised, as they have been in recent years, in bodies such as the Independent Commission Against Corruption in New South Wales. I am not condemning that body for one minute; I am simply saying that it shows a trend.

PARA.TAB: I would also say that bodies like AUSTRAC and the National Crime Authority were set up to detect major crime and to protect us from the onslaughts of criminals who engage in large-scale money laundering, drug trafficking or tax evasion. It was in that context that the committee recommended that a suggestion, which was made by or on behalf of the Department of Social Security that AUSTRAC data should be available directly to it, should be rejected. It is not that the committee in any way approves of people who commit offences against the Social Security Act but, if a body is set up that is meant to detect major crime, its resources should not be devoted to fossicking out and investigating crime that is minor in comparison to those big crimes.

If major fraud is being carried out against the Department of Social Security, then information of that would be picked up by the Federal Police and no doubt investigated by that body. But minor breaches of the law should not be the object of bodies such as AUSTRAC or the National Crime Authority. Indeed, talking about the Federal Police, I think there is an argument yet to be had that it should be doing more work than it presently does in respect of major crime. We have the Australian Securities Commission set up now and the tax office does a lot of investigation. Perhaps it is time to question whether or not that sort of crime should be investigated by the Federal Police. In any event, that was the committee's recommendation about the seeking by the Department of Social Security of a right or permission to use material coming through AUSTRAC.

The first recommendation that the committee made is that any activities involving the exercise of power by an investigative body or a body that collects material about the residents of this country should be sanctioned by parliament. In the cause of the civil rights of our citizens, whatever is done by bodies such as AUSTRAC should be sanctioned by a law passed by this parliament. If people are going to have their rights and liberties interfered with, it should be done according to the law and on no other basis. I am not suggesting for one minute that Mr Coad has allowed that to happen, but during the committee's hearings there was a suggestion—on one occasion at least—that AUSTRAC may have, quite unintentionally, moved beyond the jurisdiction given to it by the statute upon which it depends for its existence.

The second recommendation was that the threshold for significant cash transaction reports should not be allowed to erode through inflation. In other words, the amount of money that has to be reported as being a significant transaction is presently $10,000. If inflation takes place—which, of course, it will not under this government—then that ought to be taken into account and the threshold amount should be increased.

The next recommendation is a very sensible one that, if a cash dealer can report significant cash transactions by electronic means, it should do so. Recommendation 5 was that the present law dealing with the opening of accounts by customers with banks or other financial institutions should be changed. It was thought that the procedure that people opening accounts in banks or other financial institutions presently have to go through to prove their identity was too awkward, too cumbersome and not as effective as it might be. The committee has recommended a change in that procedure to allow cash dealers to satisfy themselves by their own tests whether a person is who he or she says he or she is, but that that process ought to be audited by AUSTRAC. Each should be given sufficient money to enable them to do that.

Recommendations 7, 8, 9 and 10 deal with civil rights issues. Recommendation 7 recommends that the act be amended so that the tax office no longer has a right of access to the data from AUSTRAC, but that it has to enter into a memorandum of understanding with the director. Recommendation 8 recommends:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . that a civil liberties representative be appointed to the Ministerial Advisory Committee on the FTR Act.
Recommendation 9 recommends:

. . . that the advice of the Privacy Commissioner be sought by the Director of AUSTRAC whether to appoint a civil liberties representative either to an existing AUSTRAC advisory committee, or to establish a separate committee on privacy and civil liberties issues.
Recommendation 12 recommends:
. . . that State and Territory revenue authorities be given access to FTR—
that is, financial transaction reports—
information on the basis of a Memorandum of Understanding to be entered into with the Director of AUSTRAC and subject to such conditions as the Director requires.

In other words, just as the Australian Taxation Office has access to information from AUSTRAC, similar offices at state level should also have that access so that they are able to trace the money trail to see whether people are avoiding their obligations to pay tax.

PARA.TAB: The committee noted that the tax office itself did not seem to be taking as much advantage of the information provided by AUSTRAC as was possible. The committee expressed itself to be a little disappointed with the tax office's ability to make proper use of that information. So in recommendation 14, it has recommended that Australian tax officers be trained, and that a more fruitful relationship be established between the tax office and AUSTRAC which should lead to a better recovery of revenue which would not otherwise be recovered.

I do not want to spend too long on this matter because others wish to speak, but I will deal with the dissent on one question from Senator Spindler. Senator Spindler's argument on this has a lot of intellectual merit but not enough to convince the rest of the committee. It is the question of whether or not solicitors should be included within the definition of `cash dealers'. I think the NCA, in particular, wanted solicitors included within the provisions of the act in respect of not only reporting significant cash transactions but also reporting suspect cash transactions. The difference between those two is that a significant cash transaction must be reported according to the amount of money involved; a suspect cash transaction must be reported on the basis of whether or not the receiver of the money entertains a suspicion.

Senator Spindler said he could see why solicitors should not have to report cash transactions within the second category—that is, the suspect category—but there was no reason why they should not have to report those matters that fell within the first category; that is, the significant cash transaction category.

There are two bases on which the majority rejected that. The first is the special relationship between solicitors and their clients. In fact, a law of confidentiality protects communications between solicitors and their clients in certain circumstances. There is some doubt about whether that protection would apply with the receipt of cash; nevertheless, the aura that should surround the relationship between solicitor and client ought not to be disturbed.

The second thing is that law enforcing bodies should not be able to come to parliament and gain power simply by asking for it. If the NCA and AUSTRAC want solicitors included in the category of cash dealers, they have to show on very convincing evidence—and I use the words `very convincing evidence' advisedly—that they should be included. They did produce some evidence. They did not descend to names—and I understand that there is always an embarrassment in stating names when talking about evidence associated with crime. Nevertheless, if they want solicitors included, they should show that they ought to be. Senator Spindler was convinced on the evidence; the rest of us were not, so solicitors are not included in the category of cash dealers.

The other interesting issue is the question of people who form the suspicion that there is something wrong with cash which is brought to them. A typical example would be bank tellers who receive, say, a bundle of cash which makes them suspicious and they report it. Even if they report a significant cash transaction they could be put in the position of having to give evidence. Employers, in particular, were concerned for their employees' safety and were afeard that, if the identity of tellers were revealed through them being called as witnesses, there would be some problems.

The committee recommended that the best way to deal with the protection of the identity of tellers as witnesses would be for agreements between AUSTRAC and law enforcement agencies to be drawn up along the lines of the draft agreement with the Australian Federal Police referred to in the report. In that agreement consideration is given to the position of tellers and others like them, and the essence of such an agreement should be taken into account by the DPP. Of course, we are not in any way trying to direct what the DPP ought to do but we simply make that suggestion. The committee recommended that the state law enforcement authorities be asked to take the same approach.

There is one other matter where no recommendation was but it concerned the committee. There is a suggestion that law enforcement bodies such as the Federal Police, the tax office and the National Crime Authority, be asked to pay for information that they get from AUSTRAC. The committee was quite firm on this. Paragraphs 12.37 to 12.39 of the report state:

SPEECH.PARA: 12.37 The dominant difficulty the Committee has with the proposition that law enforcement agencies should be made to pay for the use of those mechanisms which they need to properly carry out their duties is the concept of government upon which it is based.

12.38 The idea that fundamental obligations of government can be more or less met, or not met at all depending upon the ability or willingness of its instruments to pay for information that will or may help them carry out their functions is ill-founded.

12.39 Government must discharge those functions which are basic to its purpose. Seeing that justice is done is one of these. To allow the meeting of that purpose to be determined by market forces would be amazing.

In closing my address I thank the members of the committee who helped with this report; they are set out on page iii. I also thank the committee staff: Paul Griffiths, the secretary; the research staff of Rod Adams, Virginia Buring and James Warmenhoven—and I mention in passing that James Warmenhoven has recently had a son born to him, named Huw, which I think ought to be noted; Angela Misic, the Executive Assistant; and Margaret Lindeman who is up there eternally typing.

TALK.START.PARA: —And Hansard.

—I thank Senator O'Chee; I never forget Hansard normally. This is an important report. I must confess that, when it first arose for consideration, I did not think the subject was exactly a thrilling one. But it raises the issue of the proper balance between the sorts of forces that the states should use to root out crime and the sorts of restraints they should show in respect of the civil rights which we all should enjoy. That balance is one that must be eternally examined, and we examined it on this occasion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on this report by the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs on the Financial Transaction Reports Act 1988. I was privileged to be a member of the committee and to serve with the chairman and the other members of the committee on this inquiry. As usual, I appreciated the wise guidance that we received from the chairman.

PARA.TAB: I would also like to endorse the chairman's comments on the staff. I think we are not always cognisant of the tremendous support that we get from staff on committees and generally in this chamber, so I thoroughly endorse that. Having said these things, I regret that I cannot agree with the report on all matters. Since I accept the report as it stands, with one exception, I see no point in traversing again the matters that Senator Cooney has so carefully described. I will confine my remarks to the dissent that I am offering.

The dissent relates to my view that, on balance, the legal profession should be subject to the provisions of the act in one respect. I am not suggesting that legal practitioners be defined as cash dealers because that would require them to report suspicious transactions and I accept the arguments which were advanced that this could bring us too close to the bone, as it were, in going into the area of the professional relationship between client and lawyer.

However, I really do not see why the legal profession should continue to be exempt from the reporting requirements which apply to a particular amount of money. I am suggesting that $5,000 should be the threshold requirement, and I will come back to the reason for that later.

The committee has heard compelling evidence during the course of the inquiry about the involvement of members of the legal profession in money laundering. The chairperson of the National Crime Authority, Mr Sherman, informed the committee that:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . there are some aspects of money laundering that it is virtually impossible to perpetrate unless you have the assistance of lawyers. By that, I mean the conversion of funds and the integration of funds by the purchase of real estate and setting up companies and so on.

This evidence that we received was not in the form of unsupported generalisation. Twenty-seven case studies were provided to the committee and most disclosed the involvement of legal practitioners. In one case study, a solicitor received $42,000 from a client to form part of the funds for a property transaction. The money was recorded in the trust account ledger and banked on eight different days over a two-week period. No amount exceeded $8,000. The solicitor explained this conduct by saying:
. . . that if someone deposited that much cash in one go it was bound to give rise to some sort of inquiry.

And it seems rightly so. Other case studies illustrated the case of complex and unusual arrangements to finance property transactions and indeed wilful blindness to the use of false names to operate bank accounts and to acquire property. A whole range of other case studies were appended to the joint submission by AUSTRAC and the NCA.

PARA.TAB: In response to this evidence, the Law Society of New South Wales and the Law Institute of Victoria referred to the role that solicitors have in keeping the justice system functioning, the duty which solicitors have to keep client information confidential and the fiduciary duty owed by a solicitor to the client. In response to these arguments, the NCA pointed out that the law on solicitor-client confidence admits, however, that there are exceptions to the duty of confidence. In evidence to the inquiry, the NCA chair quoted from the case Gartside v. Outram, which said, `there is no confidence as to the disclosure of iniquity'.

Earlier in 1991 the NCA had completed an exhaustive 12-month inquiry into money laundering in Australia carried out by four multi-disciplinary NCA teams and recommended that the definition of `cash dealers' in the Financial Transaction Reports Act be widened to include solicitors. This recommendation was not accepted by the government. However, it is worth putting on record that I was, and am, a member of the parliamentary committee on the NCA; I have access to not only the published report on that inquiry but also a confidential appended report which detailed a score of cases where solicitors had been used in transactions which can only be described as criminal.

I also refer to some earlier material that came to light in the inquiry by Mr Justice Stewart into drugs and drug trafficking in Australia. In one particular case—the Mr Asia syndicate—it became quite clear that the essential business of financing and then of laundering the proceeds of the operation of that syndicate was carried out through the office of a practising solicitor. It seems to me that we should take account of that evidence and should close what I believe is a major loophole in our efforts to pursue white-collar crime, and worse, in Australia. I believe that we should not hamper our law enforcement agencies unduly.

As I said before, my own proposal does not go as far as the NCA's proposal. I accept that the reporting of suspicious transaction does pose a greater risk to the integrity of the solicitor-client relationship. However, I believe that there is also evidence that the legal profession accepts the distinction that I am making in not suggesting that solicitors be classed as cash dealers and therefore be compelled to disclose suspicious circumstances. A witness for the Law Society of New South Wales told the committee that there is a distinction to be made. The evidence is as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: In very broad principle, I have no objection to the reporting of facts of an objective nature—by that, I mean significant cash transactions.
And that is exactly what I am suggesting. The evidence continues:

But I wonder whether I am sufficiently taking into account the position of clients when I say that we would have no objection to objective reporting. On the other hand, the Law Society is totally opposed to the Act being extended to solicitors in regard to suspect transaction reporting.
Yes, indeed. I do appreciate the distinction which was drawn in this way, and I do understand the concerns that some solicitors would have about suspect transaction reporting.

PARA.TAB: Accordingly, I confine my dissent to the suggestion that solicitors, legal practitioners, should be required to report cash transactions of $5,000 or more. I am suggesting this amount, in contrast to the general amount of $10,000, to cater for the fact that it is also on record that solicitors do advise their clients to break up large cash transactions into smaller ones and thus evade the requirement of the act. Indeed, that happened in the example that I cited earlier.

I regret that the committee did not see fit to include this recommendation in its report. I believe that it is necessary to continue to monitor the effectiveness of this legislation and, in particular, I will take care to examine carefully future reports from AUSTRAC and its recommendations and, if necessary, bring up this recommendation again at a future date.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison Sen C.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was not a member of the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs when the matter now before us was referred. I came in halfway through the inquiry. Nonetheless, I found it to be an extremely interesting reference for a number of reasons.

PARA.TAB: Firstly, the reference involves the classical balancing of the rights of a citizen to freedom and privacy against the interests of the state. The Financial Transaction Reports Act 1988 had its genesis in the royal commissions of the early 1980s—basically the Costigan and Stewart royal commissions. At that time there was a great deal of white-collar crime going on in Australia. The underworld was basically transacting large amounts of money and this was not being detected. So in 1987 the original Cash Transactions Reports Act was introduced with the proviso that it be looked at in three years time.

I will refer to a few of the committee's recommendations without going through them ad seriatim. The first recommendation is that AUSTRAC should engage only in those activities which are clearly and unequivocally allowed under the relevant act. AUSTRAC is a body which provides information to law enforcement agencies. It really should not participate in any investigative activities.

I think it was the Victorian Council for Civil Liberties which submitted that the agency would be acting ultra vires in undertaking any investigative activities and that the answer should really be to increase the investigative functions of the law enforcement agencies rather than expand the role of AUSTRAC. I have had personal experience in relation to the Australian Federal Police in this regard. A body such as the Australian Federal Police should be given increased investigative powers rather than an information-keeping body such as AUSTRAC.

Flowing from that, the committee stated in recommendation No. 4 that suspect reporting should be retained in its present form so that not only any cash transaction over $10,000 but also any transaction which is suspect be reported. The committee, of course, had some reservations about this.

Recommendations Nos 7 to 10 deal with some restrictions which I believe go to protecting the individual's freedom and privacy. Suspect reporting involves a cash dealer making a value judgment as to a cash transaction. The amount is of no relevance; it is simply whether the transaction is suspicious or not. That places a great deal of pressure on a person such as a bank teller. Someone might roll up and bank a couple of hundred dollars. If the circumstances seem somewhat suspicious, the bank teller is at liberty to report that transaction.

The frequency of the transaction, the manner in which it is carried out and the person's financial means are all attributes which would be looked at in assessing the suspicion of the transaction.That opens the floodgates to the possibility that all sorts of cash transactions that we as citizens engage in during our daily lives could be reported. Of course, that situation would have to be looked at very carefully.

In recommendations Nos 7 to 10, the committee was of the view that the Australian Taxation Office should not have right of access; that there be a civil liberties representative appointed to the ministerial advisory committee; and that the Director of AUSTRAC have power to delete any information from AUSTRAC records in appropriate circumstances. Quite obviously, after a period such transactions might well become irrelevant. However, whilst they are sitting on the AUSTRAC database, there is a possibility for officers—or anyone, for that matter—who can break into the system to find out information on individual citizens.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the suspension of the sitting for dinner, I mentioned the committee's concern to protect the privacy and freedom of the individual in relation to the powers bestowed upon AUSTRAC. A further recommendation, recommendation 12, provides that state and territory revenue authorities be given access to AUSTRAC information, but that that be done on the basis that such access be permitted only to a small number of key officers of each authority. Of course, the commonsense there is to ensure that as few people as possible within the organisation have the information available to them, to limit any chance of the information escaping into the wider community.

PARA.TAB: The committee recommended at recommendation 22 that the definition of a cash dealer not be widened to include solicitors. Much has been said by Senator Cooney and Senator Spindler on this matter. The point I make is that it was submitted by the National Crime Authority that solicitors should be deemed cash dealers because of money passing through their trust accounts. That would result in a solicitor having to inform on his or her client if the transaction was either suspect or over the sum of $10,000, which would be the sum if our recommendation is accepted. The committee found that situation unacceptable. It concedes that evidence was presented to it, but it was not sufficient to override that longstanding rule of privilege.
I refer to page 135 of the report and the submission made by the Law Society of New South Wales, which summarises the situation quite neatly. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: .it is conducive to justice for clients to be assured that communications between them and their solicitors will remain confidential, or at least not to be disclosed beyond the implied authority given to the solicitor by them;

.our system of law requires solicitors to refrain from making judgments impugning the veracity of what their clients tell them, unless they have reason to make further inquiry of the client. Requiring solicitors to inform authorities of their personal suspicions about the conduct of clients is wholly incapable of being reconciled with this fundamental principle of our legal system;

I respect the fact that Senator Spindler dissents only from the exemption for solicitors to report on cash transactions exceeding the sum of $10,000, and he agrees that they should be exempt from reporting on suspect transactions. Nonetheless, the average law firm would have a good deal of money passing through its trust account in the normal course of conveyancing, family law settlements and the settlement of litigation. It is quite common to find solicitors having thousands of dollars pass through their trust accounts.

PARA.TAB: That would impose on solicitors the burden of notifying AUSTRAC of these transactions. Furthermore, I would estimate that 99.9 per cent of those cases would be innocent citizens going about their business, having their financial details reported to a government body. I am not saying that there is a lack of trust in AUSTRAC—quite the contrary—but the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs has to look to the rights of the citizens and has to review and guard those rights jealously because we live in a free democracy and we endorse government action only where it is needed. Where it is not necessary for government to act, it then becomes necessary for government to refrain from doing anything in its capacity.

In this case, there is a real need to keep tabs on organised crime and on the major tax evaders, but not so the average working man and woman going about their lawful business. I believe that in the circumstances the situation of solicitors not being cash dealers would not impede any investigation or the checking of large-scale crime.
Senator Cooney raised the matter of user pays, which I thought was a very good point. I am normally quite a fan of that principle; however, page 154 of the committee report states:

The idea that fundamental obligations of government can be more or less met, or not met at all, depending upon the ability or willingness of its instruments to pay for information that will or may help them carry out their functions is ill-founded.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not believe that we can impose upon the Australian Federal Police and the National Crime Authority economic constraints in the exercise of their duty. Law and order is one of the biggest issues across this country and it is one that we cannot put a price on. In this particular instance, I believe that the budget measure to impose a charging regime on AUSTRAC was an ill-founded one and one which, in turn, will impede the operation of AUSTRAC.

PARA.TAB: Finally, I refer the Senate to comments made by the committee which I believe sum up the issues at stake here. They are basically set out at page 139. It states:
From time to time, law enforcement agencies in the proper discharge of their responsibilities seek further powers and greater jurisdiction from Government. Government should not readily grant them.

Because law enforcement mechanisms are prone to impact heavily on the life and liberty of members of the community they must, in a free and open society, be instituted only after close analysis and with considerable caution. Other than in exceptional circumstances evidence on the basis of

SPEECH.PARA: which they are established should be comprehensive, complete and compelling.
I believe those two paragraphs more than adequately sum up the approach to be adopted in this case.

PARA.TAB: I commend the work the committee did. As I say, I came in only halfway through. The committee staff did a very good job and we were ably guided by our chairman, Senator Cooney. Senator Cooney remarked that it is not a particularly thrilling subject, but it is one which upon further inquiry reveals its importance all the more, because here we have a very useful tool in the combat of organised crime and large-scale tax evasion. On the other side of the scale, the interests and freedom of the citizen have to be considered. In the final analysis, if we are to demand that citizens' private financial affairs are to be made available to government organisations and instrumentalities, then those organisations and instrumentalities must jealously guard that information which it is a privilege for them to have.

I commend the report to the Senate. I respect the views that Senator Spindler expressed in his dissenting report and I can well understand his reasons for that. Nonetheless, I believe that on the most important issues the committee had a unanimous view for those most important reasons that I have outlined.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
