TALK.START.PARA: —It is worth noting that in contrast to the really massive loan raisings by the Labor governments in recent years, in 1982-83, the last year of the Fraser government, some $2.6 billion was raised, contrasting with the $22.8 billion sought to be raised in 1993.

PARA.TAB: Even more startling, the figures for 1987-88, 1988-89 and 1989-90 were zero. This shows the massive increases which have occurred over the last three years, including this year. The zero loan fund raisings was in large part due to the considerable tax raising capacities of Mr Keating. I have been critical of Mr Keating across a whole range of areas, but if the measure of the man is his capacity to increase taxes on the Australian taxpayer, then Mr Keating has certainly achieved his target.

TALK.START.PARA: —You have got to admit that a centrally heated dog kennel is a bit desperate. I can just see the headlines tomorrow—`PM loses cool over hot dog!'.

—It is interesting that Senator Collins has raised some of the lifestyle questions of our Prime Minister. I may touch on them briefly towards the end of my speech. If the minister can contain his enthusiasm, that would be a help.

PARA.TAB: The significance of this bill can be demonstrated with a number of straightforward calculations. The loan raisings this year represent some $1,500 per man, woman and child in this country or, for a family of four, some $6,000. This has been described as a machinery bill. Some machinery bill!

On top of this, ordinary Australians will face extra burdens in tax in the years to come. Ultimately, interest has to be paid on these massive loan raisings. In the end, some of these loans will be retired. Inevitably, the burden of taxes that future taxpayers in this country will have to pay will be significantly increased because of this so-called machinery bill which is before the Senate chamber this evening.

Because of the need to maintain the government's spending program, we have been told by Mr Keating that there will be no cuts in spending programs and no increases in taxes. But we note that, given the target to get the deficit down as a proportion of GDP, there is at least a $5 billion gap which somehow this government will have to raise.

TALK.START.PARA: —Plus Mabo.

—This excludes the considerable extra costs to ordinary Australians of the Mabo legislation. If the legislation goes through this chamber, which is by no means certain, it will certainly add to the costs that every Australian taxpayer will have to pay.
—I thought the coalition upheld the RDA. How are you going to do that without compensation? That will be a good trick.
—I understand that Senator Collins is sensitive about this.
—I watched your leader.

—I watched our leader tonight. I thought to myself, `How more closely in touch with mainstream Australian values is Dr Hewson compared to Mr Keating'. The fact of the matter is that those opposite have a Prime Minister who has lost touch with not only the traditional base of his party, as Senator Collins would know, but also mainstream Australia. There is no more fundamental demonstration of that than the Mabo bill which is being brought before this parliament.

PARA.TAB: As I have pointed out, the loan raisings in this bill are significant and cause concern to any Australian taxpayer who is informed about the nature of this so-called machinery bill. The deficit which was predicted this year in another high taxing, big spending budget by Mr Keating is some $16 billion. To a certain extent, this is reflected in the sums required to be raised under the Loan Bill 1993.

But even the $16 billion that the government projects is really a conjuring trick. Taking into account the asset sales, the Reserve Bank profits, the pillaging of government enterprises and, in recent years, the repayments of state debt, the figure is significantly larger than $16 billion. These various factors suggest that the real deficit is now reaching well over $20 billion. It is food for thought to consider that, if we add these one-off arrangements, the real deficit this year will be higher as a percentage of gross domestic product than even in the Whitlam years and the famous record 1975-76 deficit.

A number of other things can be interpreted from these figures. Most importantly, I suspect that they are a sign of the complete collapse of the government's will to cut general spending and, in particular, to enact meaningful economic reform. As a number of observers have correctly interpreted, the Prime Minister has lost the reformist's zeal. This government lied its way into office without any program. Now that it is in office, it is unsure what it can do. It is blocked in every area of meaningful reform by the trade union movement and the special interest groups which support it. Senator Kernot, who will be speaking after me, may reflect on the industrial relations bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am too busy reflecting on what Dr Hewson said at 7.30 p.m.

—If Senator Kernot is appalled, that is yet another sign that Dr Hewson probably got it absolutely correct. If she is appalled, it gives me even greater confidence that Dr Hewson certainly got it absolutely correct, as I believe he did.
—Saccharine insincerity personified.
—It is all about his leadership.
—Dr Hewson is in touch with what mainstream Australians want. Dr Hewson is in touch with the basic values of ordinary Australian people.
—Fear and greed.
—Senator Kernot represents a minority party.
—He is certainly not in touch with the leadership of the Liberal Party.

—It is interesting that Senator Collins should raise leadership issues. He is the expert after stabbing Mr Hawke in the back. It is well known that Senator Collins's enthusiasm for Mr Keating is on the wane.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator McKiernan)—Senator Kemp, if you addressed your comments to the chair you might not get so many interjections and you might not be so distracted in your speech.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you for that advice, Mr Acting Deputy President. Out of my great respect for you, I will certainly take that advice on board. I hope the next time I am severely provoked, you will focus your attention and venom on the cause of it rather than the symptom, if you know what I mean. In saying that, I do not reflect on your even-handedness or fairness. Mr Acting Deputy President, can I point out to you that we are, in effect, in so many areas in a policy vacuum with this government. The massive borrowings involved in this bill are simply one other symbol of a reflection of that policy vacuum.

PARA.TAB: I put it to honourable senators that this is not a machinery bill, as we heard in the second reading speech. This is a very important bill. This bill asks the Senate to approve truly massive borrowings which, as I have pointed out, will impact on the future taxes that Australians will have to pay in the years to come. This is a matter of considerable concern. The second reading speech was sloppily drafted. I urge the officers who are in the chamber to go back to the tradition of their department and, in future years when this bill is presented, spend more time trying to explain to people the real nature and significance of this bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot Sen C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The State Grants (General Purpose) Bill gives effect to the arrangements agreed to at the July Premiers Conference and Loans Council meeting for grants to the states for the 1993-94 year. As Senator Kemp said, the bill authorises payments of general revenue grants, including financial assistance grants, arterial road funding and special revenue measures. The total amount of assistance provided by the bill is estimated to be $14.4 billion in 1993-94.

PARA.TAB: The necessity for parliament to approve this legislation is obvious. Without the annual cap in hand performance of the premiers and without the begrudging transfer of huge sums of money from the federal to the state level of government, the federal system in this country would collapse. In many respects this is because of the gross imbalance between the revenue raising powers of the federal government and the spending needs of the states. In 1992-93 state and local governments collected 33 per cent of government revenue in this country, but accounted for 48 per cent of total government expenditure. About 40 per cent of all state revenue comes from federal grants, and this raises the key question that federal grants play in state budgets.

Figures show that the federal government over the last decade has required far greater expenditure constraints from the states than from its own sources. The University of New South Wales estimates that, in the seven financial years from 1985 to 1992, the level of financial assistance from the Commonwealth to other levels of government fell by 18.9 per cent in real terms. When one takes into account population growth on a per capita basis, the real cuts were even more severe. Federal government outlays were not required to be cut by amounts anywhere near this magnitude. Indeed, they grew in real terms. In 1991, faced with a collapsing revenue base, the premiers, as part of the then in vogue new federalism debate, persuaded the federal government to agree to guarantee that financial assistance grants would not be reduced in real terms for three years. The government has stuck to this commitment and the bill before us tonight marks the last of those three years of maintained grants.

The forward estimates in the budget papers suggest that the grants will continue to be maintained through to 1996-97 in real terms. That remains to be seen. I think there is a bit of a question mark over the future. Treasurer Dawkins has set up a committee headed by the good old Industry Commission—this is the revamped one, the new John Dawkins Industry Commission—to pursue an additional $3 billion in state government budget savings by forcing each of the six states to reduce their levels of services through benchmarking to that of the lowest serviced state.

The sting is in the various budget papers and the regular lectures from Canberra to the states on their reluctance to increase their own taxes. This ignores the fact that state taxes tend to be highly regressive. Most state taxes take the form of flat fees or levies which do not take into account capacity to pay. By far the largest single state tax is payroll tax, which is frequently cited by business as a major disincentive to employing more people. So what the federal government has been telling the states is to collect more regressive taxes and more taxes on employment. I do not think that in the middle of a recession—or at any time—that is good public policy.

In all of this debate about figures we can lose site of the real issue. I think the real issue is that at the moment, under our federal system, states deliver many of the basic services to the community—services such as education, hospitals, social services, roads and so forth. I honestly think that we should take the opportunity between now and the end of this century to examine the appropriate powers of the different levels of government in this country, because something is not working.

Nevertheless, at the moment states have a particular role. They are required to fund their services from a declining pool of federal funds and from a narrow and regressive tax base. The result has been two-fold: funding of basic services has been stretched to the bone and state budget deficits, with the exception of Queensland, have risen significantly. Employment in the state budget sector has been dramatically pared back over the last decade as Canberra has attempted to shift its budgetary problems to the states.

Earlier in the week I met with representatives of the public sector unions. They provided me with figures which show that in the three years from 1991 to 1994 more than 145,000 jobs will have disappeared from the state public sectors. Job cuts of that magnitude in the middle of a recession are really quite staggering. The Keating government, aided and abetted by state governments of both political persuasions around the country, have deliberately increased unemployment by reducing by an excessive amount—not an reasonable amount, an excessive amount—the number of government jobs. To make matters worse, they have borrowed hundreds of millions of dollars to pay for redundancy packages. So we have been adding to our national debt to increase unemployment.

TALK.START.PARA: —Let's raise taxes and have superannuation levies!

—That is good public policy, too! We support efforts to make the public sector more efficient and to improve productivity. Productivity, however, should be measured against better quality standards delivering better services. I do not think that the loss of 145,000 jobs can be called an efficiency measure. It can be called slash and burn, but finetuning productivity it certainly is not.

PARA.TAB: What I am increasingly concerned about is that a decade of Canberra enforced cutbacks on state governments is now seriously affecting the ability of the states to deliver basic services. Take education. Surveys by the Australian Teachers' Union have shown that in the last four years class sizes right across Australia are starting to rise. For example, almost half of early childhood classes now have more than 25 students, up by a third from four years ago. The proportion of senior secondary classes with more than 25 students has almost doubled. The worst increases have been in Victoria. With class sizes rising and subject choices falling, teachers are now noticing a marked decline in school retention rates, particularly in Victoria's western suburbs. Yet the redundancy packages which fuelled the fall in teacher numbers in western Melbourne, Labor's so-called heartland, have been funded willingly by the Keating government.

Welfare services have been even more stretched at the state level. We all know that welfare spending is usually the first area to be cut by the states because their clients are least able to lobby and to defend their interests. Data from the Commonwealth Grants Commission shows that in the four years to 1992, spending on state welfare programs per capita fell in real terms in five of the six states. In Queensland per capita welfare expenditure has actually fallen by an incredible 35 per cent.

The gross inadequacy of current state welfare services is highlighted by the two incisive reports by Brian Burdekin, one into mental illness and one into homelessness. In both reports he identified a gross inadequacy in back-up and support services for two groups least able to fend for themselves. The mental health report exposed the failure of the deinstitutionalisation program. Mentally ill patients have been thrown out into the community with virtually no back-up, and they simply cannot cope. Something like 50 to 70 per cent of the overnight stays at St Vincent de Paul hostels are now estimated to be mentally ill people who cannot fend for themselves in the community. Burdekin's youth homelessness report displayed a similar unmet need for community services.

We like Australia to do well. We like Australia to be the best at things. Well, Australia has the highest teenage suicide rate in the industrialised world. This can only be seen as a cry for help from a troubled generation. Yet the Burdekin report concludes that there is an overwhelming picture of inadequate funding, inadequate training, inadequate in-patient care, inadequate coordination between agencies, research and data collection and an inadequate commitment to the establishment of prevention and intervention services.

Youth suicide and suicide attempts have increased alarmingly over the past 20 years. This risk is exacerbated for rural youth, particularly young males, young prisoners and homeless youth. There is a desperate shortage of child and adolescent psychiatric services, despite the fact that 10 to 15 per cent of children and adolescents show significant psychiatric disturbance and one per cent of them need urgent treatment.

For young people with acute adolescent problems there are around 30 beds in New South Wales and Victoria, virtually none in Queensland, none in the public sector in South Australia and none in Western Australia. According to Mr Burdekin, there are serious deficiencies in even the most basic services for young people and state and federal budget priorities have been identified as the most fundamental problems. I will say that again: state and federal budget priorities have been identified as the most fundamental problems. One witness stated:

SPEECH.PARA: In the 1990-91 Victorian Budget, resources allocated to child and adolescent health services were reduced. One facility was actually closed, and it was the only facility in the State which provided an inpatient service to the late adolescent group aged 16-20. Other facilities had staffing and general running cost cuts.
. . . These cuts have been made worse by the reduction in other services for children and adolescents in general health, education, welfare.

An immediate funding boost for state and regional mental health care for young people is imperative to ensure appropriately trained staff, improved administration, community crisis services, effective in-patient services and out-patient treatment, as well as suitable adolescent accommodation, education, employment and training, and social and recreational activities for those recovering from mental illness. Otherwise, as Burdekin recognises:
The human rights of disturbed and at-risk young Australians are being seriously denied by such glaring omissions, with often tragic consequences for the individuals and families involved.

Another report by Justice Fogarty into Victorian child protection services showed that resources are now so sparse that 56 per cent of cases reported could not be followed up for over a week—key delays at a key time in 56 per cent of cases. Fogarty noted that the state child protection service had virtually abandoned the care of adolescents, due largely to budget constraints.

PARA.TAB: The state run public hospital system is having difficulty coping with demand as well. The proportion of health expenditure funded by the public sector decreased from 71.8 per cent in 1984-85 to 68 per cent in 1991-92. This decrease is entirely due to a fall in the Commonwealth proportion of health funding. For example, it has meant in Queensland—a state with an exploding population—some 2,000 jobs disappearing last year from the public health system in the middle of a massive health budgetary crisis.

These are just some of the effects of the cutting of 145,000 jobs from the state public sector. I think the policy is crazy. True, the public sector needs to aim for the highest possible level of efficiency, but not at the price of withdrawing services from the mentally ill, from disadvantaged youth and from other groups who simply are unable to defend their interests.

Public sector unions have raised what I think is an excellent suggestion for the Prime Minister's unemployment working party. They have argued that priority to job creation should be given to work in the community sector. Many of our pool of 982,000 unemployed have been storing life experience skills which could easily be put to good use in providing support services. Any attempt to reverse the growing disparity between demand for community services and the supply and delivery of those services must be a step in the right direction.

The necessity for this bill to be passed highlights the inadequacies of the Australian federal system. There are huge inadequacies. I just wish that we as a nation would grapple honestly and intelligently with them, instead of going on, year after year, knowing where the problems are and doing nothing about them.

I have called for an extension of the current debate about the constitution to include the issue of the role of the states and the appropriate levels of power of our existing three tiers of government. But before that debate continues, we need to seriously address the accumulating evidence that Canberra has been exporting its budgetary problems to the states. This is now affecting the delivery of basic government services and forcing increasing reliance on highly regressive taxes.

It is time that the interplay between the fiscal policies of the federal government and the fiscal policies of the states was properly debated. The cap in hand, heart on sleeve premiers conferences have become a joke. They have failed to resolve the problem since World War II. It will require a strong statement by the community that enough is enough before the bureaucrats and then politicians get out of their trenches, abandon the posturing and start talking rationally. So, with some misgivings, I support this anachronism of a bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —Some of the points that Senator Kernot made were quite valid, including the point that this government has, as an excuse for the hard work with the expenditure review committees, wound down the general purpose grants to the states. Particularly since Senator Walsh left the ministry for finance, the government has been slashing states' general purpose grants as a proportion of gross domestic product in substitution for the hard work of better economic management at the federal level, particularly better public administration at the federal level.

PARA.TAB: Specifically in terms of general funding, when Malcolm Fraser left power in early 1983, the Commonwealth's own purpose outlays as a proportion of GDP were 18.9 per cent; this year, on the government's own estimates, those own purpose outlays will be in the vicinity of 20 per cent. As a proportion of GDP, the Commonwealth's own outlays will have significantly increased over the last 10 years. That is something that I know former Senator Peter Walsh is very upset about—quite genuinely so and quite justifiably so. Of course, this situation is in contradiction to the government's own rhetoric about being frugal when it comes to Commonwealth spending.

We have some very fine examples on the micro scale of why that occurs. Something like $60 million has been handed out in the past five years by the various ministers for sports in the form of sporting grants on the fundamental criteria that those who live in a marginal Labor seat need sporting facilities, and those who live in a marginal Liberal seat or a Liberal seat do not need sporting facilities. They are the fundamental criteria for spending federal taxpayers' money that have seen the federal government's budget blow out. On an even more micro level, the taxpayers of Australia would be more concerned about spending thousands upon thousands of dollars on sketches of birds to put on the cabinet wall, if not imported rainforest timber tables at the Lodge and $24,000 chairs for the Prime Minister to sit on—that is, when he is not sleepless in Seattle.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do not forget the centrally heated dog kennel.

—We might have got it wrong there. We do get it wrong every now and again. At the same time, as Senator Kernot pointed out in a most eloquent speech, the state's own general purpose grants have been slashed as a proportion of GDP from 9.6 per cent to 7.3 per cent. The coalition is particularly concerned that when one slashes state funding in this way someone else misses out. Either the states have to put up their own taxes or people miss out on services. From her own perspective, I think Senator Kernot has pointed that out.

PARA.TAB: One of the areas of the States Grants (General Purposes) Bill that the opposition is particularly concerned about is what the Treasurer said in relation to the funding for states which allow students the freedom to join or not to join unions on campus. I was heartened to hear Senator Kernot say that she was concerned about the slashing of state funding. She would also be concerned that in clause 20 of this bill there is a measure that would ensure that if a state government chose to legislate to allow individual young Australians the choice to decide of their own free will whether or not to join a student association then the Commonwealth would cut the general purpose funding to the state by, in Western Australia's case, up to $5 million or more.

This is the case in Western Australia because we are one of the few states that has before its legislature a bill to allow individuals to make a decision whether or not to join a student association. So the threat of a further funding cut of millions of dollars hangs over my state of Western Australia.

As Senator Kernot said in her speech, if millions of dollars is cut from a state's funding that money has to be either found through increases in state taxes—such as increases in car registrations, water rates or any other forms of revenue raising a state may have—or the state is forced to cut funding to people in need. It would have to cut its assistance to crippled children, handicapped people, people in need, disadvantaged Aboriginal communities and so on. The $5 million plus that could be cut away from Western Australia as a result of this government's ideological obsession with ensuring that individual Australians do not have the freedom to choose whether or not to join an association means that those people in the state in real need will miss out on state funding or members of the general community will have their car registration fees, water rates or electricity charges put up.

Quite often people in the Liberal Party are accused of having ideological obsessions. But I must say that this government has ideological obsessions if it is prepared to go to the lengths that it has done to ensure that students leaving secondary school and moving to university campuses are forced to join an association against their will. This federal government is actually prepared to go to the lengths of chopping off general purpose funding to a state government, which is available to every other state government, because that state government wants to comply with article 20 of the United Nations Declaration on Human Rights and it wants to allow people the freedom to choose whether or not to join an association. One wonders who is the ideologically obsessed party in this parliament.
It may not be an ideological obsession; it may be a blatant, pragmatic, unprincipled, cynical decision to ensure that the Labor Party continues to receive the significant financial support—

TALK.START.PARA: —I thought you weren't going to come to the conspiracy theory.

—I may be wrong. If I ever have a choice between a stuff up and a conspiracy, Senator Evans, I always choose the stuff up because that is usually the right choice when it comes to these things. The Labor Party has the choice to decide whether the $5 million plus blackmail over the state of Western Australia and any other state that chooses to give Australian citizens the choice of whether or not to join an association is a matter of ideological obsession or pure patronage of student unions. The National Union of Students continues to actively support the Australian Labor Party when it comes to federal elections. I think even the National Union of Students should start to wonder about the support it gives to the Australian Labor Party when it sees the way it has been legged over in the last election in relation to the handling of funding of student contributions.

PARA.TAB: The crucial issue before us when it comes to voluntary student unionism is this federal government's blatant intervention in relation to either blackmailing or extorting out of state governments a commitment not to allow individual Australian citizens the freedom to make their own choice as to whether or not to join an association. Under the regime which is likely to occur in Western Australia, because of legislation which is before our parliament at the moment, students enrolling at a university will be able to make the decision of their own free will whether or not to join an association.

This is probably a concept which is totally contrary to the principles of honourable senators opposite. This is a very strange concept for those opposite because people going to a university can have a choice whether or not to join a guild or a student association. It is hard for Senator Chris Evans to come to grips with the concept of a free sensible young Australian going to a university campus and being excited by the concept of learning and excited by the concept of moving into the world. The Labor Party in Canberra cannot come to grips with the concept that those students may have to make a decision of their own free will.

I put it to the Senate that in this brave new world of freedom of association, where young students may make a decision of their own free will, student associations and guilds in Western Australia will do all sorts of things to convince students that it is a very good idea to be a member of their association or guild. They will offer them discounts at student bookshops, student sporting facilities and, dare I say it, student taverns. Other businesses in the vicinity of the university will offer people inducements to join the association. The local privately owned coffee shop might say, `We will give any member of the student guild at UWA, University of Western Australia, a 10 per cent discount on cappuccinos.' Furthermore, student associations will be able to offer inducements to students to join their associations by their pure performance, their performance in sticking up for students' rights and looking after the interests of their students.

If the WA government passes its legislation and people have the freedom to choose whether or not to join an association, the guilds and the student associations will have an enormous incentive to perform very well to ensure they have a lot of members, they represent the broad student body and provide better services. This government and the Labor Party senators opposite are ensuring that if the student guilds do not attract members then they are paid money firstly by the commonwealth taxpayer and then by the state taxpayer of Western Australia. The government is saying that it will pay the universities and student unions a subsidy to make up for what they do not collect in student membership revenue.

What this creates is a perverse incentive to ensure that student unions, associations and guilds perform very badly. The worse they get the more money they get. The worse the guild is and the more unrepresentative it is, the more money this government ensures the Western Australian taxpayers pay to subsidise that guild. That is why the coalition will vote against clause 20 of this bill so that it is defeated. If that clause of the bill is not defeated then we will vote against this blackmail section of the bill which will extort the state of Western Australia and any other state that decides it wants to legislate for freedom for young Australians to make a choice of their own free will whether or not to join an association.
This bill should be absolutely repugnant to any member of the federal parliament or any Australian, young or old, tertiary student or not.
Debate interrupted.
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Calvert)—Order! It being 10.30 p.m., under sessional order I put the question:
That the Senate do now adjourn.
Question resolved in the negative.
Debate resumed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not detain the Senate for too much longer. A major principle at stake is clause 20 of the States Grants (General Purposes) Bill 1993. The principle is whether or not people should have the right to choose to join an association. I personally believe that getting involved in associations is a very good thing for the community, but I think it is a particularly bad thing when a government compels someone to join an association.

PARA.TAB: There is a very fundamental and important difference between the philosophies and principles of the coalition, particularly of the Liberal Party, and the Australian Labor Party. We believe fervently in the rights of individuals to make decisions for themselves in their own interests. Young Australians who go to university campuses at the age of 17 or 18 should be allowed to make a decision of their own free will as to whether to join a student association. They should equally be allowed to make a decision not to join that association. The student association and the student union should be able to prove to those people whether or not membership of that association is worth while and important. As long as those student associations are worthwhile associations, a majority of students will join them.

The Australian Labor Party is making a fundamental mistake in compelling students to join unions. It is making an even further fundamental mistake—I particularly appeal to the Democrats in this—if we create a massive taxpayer funded inducement for student unions and student guilds not to perform in the eyes of their members. If student guilds are paid enormous amounts of taxpayers' money, if they are absolutely hopeless, if they do not represent the interests of their members and if they do not perform in the eyes of their members, we will ensure the destruction of student unions on Australian campuses. That would be entirely regrettable to the Liberal Party.

We would like to see strong student associations. We would like to see vigorous democratic elections on student campuses. We would quite genuinely like to see a battle of ideas on campuses. We would like to see the young potential future members of the Australian Labor Party battling ideas out in the forums of campuses with young potential future members of the progressive conservative side of politics, having active debates and fighting student union elections—but on campuses where people have the freedom of choice as to whether or not to join an association.

I put those views before the Senate quite genuinely. People have accused the Western Australian government of trying to abolish student unions and cutting off the source of funds to Labor Party controlled unions. I and many people who have been involved in the voluntary student unionism debate—I am sure I speak on behalf of Senator Kemp as well—would like to see active student unions on campuses right across Australia. We do not think imposing a form of blackmail and extortion upon a state government by cutting off general purpose grants to states is a way of encouraging the health and vigour of student associations on campuses.

There is a fundamental difference between those who sit opposite and those on our side. Members of the Australian Labor Party believe in telling Australians that they are not capable of making a free choice when it comes to joining an association. They say to them that they must join the association. We think that the dignity, pride and purpose in life of all Australians can only be enhanced by them being given the sorts of fundamental freedoms that the United Nations declaration enshrines to ensure that they have genuine freedom of choice. If a maturing young adult cannot be exposed to making a decision as to whether or not to join an association, we need to wonder about the sorts of choices the Australian Labor Party would like to see Australian citizens actually have.

That is where we are coming from. It is a quite simple proposition. The simple proposition is whether we allow Australian citizens the choice to either join or not join an association. We think it is a fundamental human right which, if one was born in Australia, one should have. The Australian Labor Party wants to take that right away. It also wants to ensure that not only a state government that seeks to legislate for that right is financially impaired but also the students and every single person living in that state are financially impaired. The coalition will be opposing clause 20. If clause 20 is not struck out by a majority of votes in the Senate, we will proudly vote against this grants bill generally.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gibson Sen B.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The States Grants (General Purposes) Bill 1993 gives effect to arrangements arising from the Premiers Conference and the Loan Council meetings of 5 July of this year whereby the Commonwealth and the states agreed on revenue grants and general purpose capital grants for this current financial year. I wish to talk about two major issues that have been with us for quite some time with regard to the financial relationship between the Commonwealth and the states. The first issue goes by the terrible name of vertical fiscal imbalance and the second issue relates to disclosure of financial status of the governments and accrual accounting.

PARA.TAB: In relation to vertical fiscal imbalance, Australia's federal arrangements are about the most imbalanced in the world. The Commonwealth currently collects 79 per cent of tax revenue and spends 51 per cent of total outlays. The states and territories collect 17 per cent of tax revenue and spend 43 per cent of total outlays. Before World War II the Commonwealth transfer payments to the states were only about 11 per cent of Commonwealth outlays; today they are 43 per cent of Commonwealth outlays. In my home state of Tasmania they actually represent 54 per cent. During World War II the Commonwealth took over the taxing powers from the states and since then there have been progressive increases in its revenue base and a decrease in the states' revenue base. In 1952 the land tax was left by the Commonwealth exclusively for the states. In 1971 payroll tax was left exclusively for the states.

This fundamental imbalance between the Commonwealth and the states leads to very serious problems because responsibility is not tied to revenue raising. In its new federalism policy, the Fraser government introduced legislation to allow income tax sharing between the Commonwealth and the states and allowed the possibility of the states to have a tax surcharge. That was not taken up by the states and the act was repealed by the Hawke government in 1989. As to the problems with this imbalance, we have had increasing control by the centralist Commonwealth government and creeping increases in specific purpose grants. We have seen great increases over the last 20 years. In the early 1970s specific purpose grants were 20 per cent of Commonwealth grants; today they are up to 53 per cent.

Without that responsibility for revenue raising by the state governments and without the Commonwealth also being closely tied to the expenditure, we have silly decisions being made. We have a disincentive for creativity, efficiency and responsibility in government revenue raising and expenditure. Just recently we have had the crazy example of expenditure in southern Tasmania—where I come from—on a double highway to the airport, which was a Commonwealth government decision, when there was no proven need for such expenditure. This is at a time when other parts of the state of Tasmania could really do with expenditure on upgrading of roads, to the better efficiency and economic wellbeing of the whole of the state.

We have states spending 50c dollars and so there is little incentive to control costs and promote efficiency. This federal-state financial relationship has also been a problem in other countries such as Canada and the USA. To keep the matter short, the recent report of the Auditor-General entitled An audit commentary on aspects of Commonwealth-state agreements also criticises the lack of clear objectives, absence of performance indicators and delays in financial reporting; in other words, no direct responsibility. The Auditor-General's report found that there was reduced incentive for the Commonwealth to monitor and manage special purpose payments.

The coalition's policy, announced in 1991, entitled Building a Better Federation, firstly, advocated support for the federal system; secondly, agreed that the Commonwealth-state financial arrangements needed reform; thirdly, acknowledged that there needed to be a matching of revenue and expenditure by all governments, in other words, we believe in competitive federalism; fourthly, agreed with the proposals by the Hawke government, the premiers and chief ministers in 1991 to work towards cooperative federalism; and, finally, asserted that reform of these arrangements would be one of the most effective and lasting ways to boost Australia's economic performance.

What happened? The Hawke government recognised these problems and, after conferring with the premiers, arranged a Special Premiers Conference for December 1991 to discuss the possibility of returning some income taxing powers to the states to reduce this vertical fiscal imbalance. However, this initiative, aimed at the strategic wellbeing of all Australians for the long term, was killed off by Mr Keating's attack on this process.

Mr Keating's attack was aimed at his own personal ambition in trying to secure the support of the Left to overthrow Mr Hawke, and it was also motivated by his very strong belief in the centralisation of power here in the Commonwealth, Mr Keating being a born centralist, as we have seen in recent days with the push for Mabo and the industrial relations bill.

If we wish Australia to prosper, this issue of responsibility between the states and the Commonwealth and the imbalance between revenue raising and expenditure must be addressed. It is one of the most important things that has to be tackled in the near future.

The second issue that I will deal with very briefly relates to disclosure. Following the fiasco over the Kirner government's exceeding the Loan Council agreements, we must have a system of better disclosure of governments' financial status. One of the key parts of that—the Senate Select Committee on the Functions, Powers and Operation of the Australian Loan Council, of which I am a member, is dealing with this matter—is a move to accrual accounting by all governments so that there is a proper understanding of the real financial status of governments, the same as happens in the private sector.

TALK.START.PARA: —And local government.

—And also in local government. There have been significant changes in the last two years. Arising from the heads of treasury meetings, a couple of reports have been put before the meetings of the premiers and the Prime Minister on this issue. Arising out of that, today we now have better reporting of where things are and, essentially, a commitment to have better reporting in the future. In the end, we need to have all governments committed to giving full accrual accounts of their total financial situation—that is, not only their borrowings but also their forward budget estimates and income estimates—so that all Australians understand where governments are going. We will then have more responsible and more effective government in Australia.

PARA.TAB: These are two major issues which will have to be addressed during the 1990s. I have raised them tonight because they are very serious and important strategic issues for Australia.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bills read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —This afternoon, having first contacted Senator Schacht, I intended to respond to an answer that he provided in the Senate largely about the extent of the recovery. Lest too many people be swayed about the extent of that recovery, as conveyed by Senator Schacht's response in question time—and particularly by virtue of the selectivity of his choice of one person's experience—and lest others, on reading the Senate Hansard, interpret the response too enthusiastically, I rise to make some comments about the state of the Australian manufacturing industry.

PARA.TAB: I believe that it is possible that Senator Schacht may quite inadvertently have gilded the lily. Perhaps in response I should quote from my colleague Dr David Kemp, the shadow minister for science, when he drew our attention to the state of our manufacturing industry. I ask honourable senators to share a few thoughts from him:

SPEECH.PARA: Australia is now producing fewer manufacturing goods per head of population than it was two decades ago. Since 1985 the volume of manufacturing output has merely kept pace with population growth. Recent OECD data shows that between 1985 and 1991, factory output per capita in most OECD countries grew by more than 10 per cent (25 per cent in Japan) and yet Australia recorded a growth of only one per cent. Manufacturing production rose by only 0.6 per cent in the March quarter 1993.

It is important to realise that, unfortunately, the most significant restraint on manufacturing production in Australia has been the comparatively slow growth in the domestic demand for manufactured goods. I have perused the Survey of Manufacturing Conditions and Future Prospects in NSW for the September quarter 1993, which is conducted by the State Bank of New South Wales and the chamber. This survey indicated that the recovery in the manufacturing sector is mild and patchy and needs to strengthen considerably before it boosts profits sufficiently to create new jobs. A feature of the current recovery is its weakness compared with the recovery following the 1982-83 recession.

PARA.TAB: I would also point out to the Senate that, despite the improvement in some of the main indicators, the level of activity of firms in that survey remained virtually unchanged between the June and September quarters. Some improvement is expected in the December quarter with 65 per cent of firms expecting to be operating above the 70 per cent of capacity level but—and this is the point—still well below the pre-Christmas levels experienced before the recession.

The survey stated that manufacturers involved in exporting welcomed the added competitiveness gained from the current weaker Australian dollar. But, of course, I must remind the Senate that a weaker dollar ultimately means increased costs to Australia as a result of that weakness, particularly to the extent that manufacturing depends on imported items.

Manufacturers' optimism about export prospects over the next three months is reflected in the 17 per cent of respondents who expect to sell more overseas compared with only three per cent who expect a decline. I think it is regrettable that the increase in manufacturing activity seems to be fairly closely linked with a weak Australian dollar which, I put to the Senate, is not a good recipe for the future recovery of Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I cannot allow the unfounded and uninformed statements concerning the New South Wales government's management of the south-east forests, which were made last night by Senator Coulter, to go unchallenged. Therefore, I would like to take a short time to set out the facts with regard to logging in New South Wales state forests and the national forests policy that Senator Coulter referred to.

PARA.TAB: Senator Coulter's remarks are just a repeat of the completely misguided allegations already made by the Greens. New South Wales is more advanced in implementing the national forests policy than any other state. The Timber Industry (Interim Protection) Act, enacted by the current New South Wales government, places substantial areas of old growth forest under moratorium until 15 separate environment impact statements have been completed and determined by the minister for planning.

In the south-east of the state of New South Wales, the inter-governmental agreement on south-east forests transfers a further 55,000 hectares of state forest to national park. Other areas, including the Cathcart State Forest to which Senator Coulter referred yesterday, were allocated for timber production. I would like to point out to Senator Coulter that Mrs Kelly was one of the two federal members who brokered this agreement.
The national forest policy also provides for ongoing timber production from old growth forests. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: Governments recognise that integrated harvesting of sawlogs and pulplogs is an important use of native forests and that it can be done in an ecologically sustainable manner. . .
Further:

Australia will continue to use old-growth timber for many years. It will come from disturbed forests containing some old growth trees and from old growth forests that are not required for the nature conservation reserve system described. . .

I would also like to refer to Senator Coulter's notice of motion, which he gave yesterday, in which he supported the recent protest organised by the Wilderness Society in the Deua area of New South Wales. These protesters are amongst those who, in recent times, have been dealt with by the courts for a range of offences, including intimidation and assault.

PARA.TAB: It disturbs me greatly that a senator in this chamber would support such actions. It is a sad reflection on the Australian Democrats that they could support unlawful behaviour and apparently encourage those who do not observe the laws of the land. Other forms of protests have included the sabotage of equipment in forests, and tampering with power poles. These life threatening acts of protest should be condemned and are condemned by all law abiding citizens. I am sure that Senator Coulter does not support these actions, but it is a pity to line up with such hoodlums. Some of these people are unbalanced terrorists with little understanding of the effects of their acts.

There is absolutely no basis for the federal government to consider taking any action with respect to the national forests policy other than working cooperatively with the New South Wales government to finalise the south-east forest agreement and support regional assessment programs. I would like to point out that the logging compartments in the Cathcart State Forest, referred to by Senator Coulter, which have or will be logged, have been lawfully licensed by the National Parks and Wildlife Service.

In conclusion, I wish to support the New South Wales state Minister for Land and Water Conservation, Mr George Souris, on the efficient and responsible manner in which he is administering New South Wales state forests in what has been and no doubt will continue to be a very sensitive and highly volatile issue.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, upon notice, on 13 September 1993:

PARA.TAB: (1) Have the fungicides ferbam, maneb and nabam been withdrawn from use in Australia, and if so, for what reason.
(2) Are agricultural chemicals approved for use on the basis that similar or image chemicals are already approved.
(3) Can agricultural chemicals be withdrawn on the basis that similar or image chemicals have previously been withdrawn.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) Yes. These decisions were taken by the Australian Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Council because of a lack of adequate toxicological and/or residue data for these chemicals.

(2) Yes. The three active constituents referred to above (ferbam, maneb and nabam) are all members of the same chemical family, (the dithiocarbamates). However, they are not "images". The term "image" is only used in relation to formulated products, (ie mixtures containing active constituent(s), together with other materials such as a solvent system, emulsifier system etc) which have the same active constituent, formulation type and use-pattern.
(3) Yes. If there is a concern about a chemical, then all products using that chemical are examined.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, upon notice, on 13 September 1993:

PARA.TAB: (1) Is the Organic Produce Advisory Committee (OPAC) part of the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service.
(2) What is the charter of OPAC.
(3) Will OPAC set the prescribed code of practice for labelling produce as organic.
(4) What role does the National Food Authority have in the function of OPAC.
(5) Does the Federal Government aim to promote organic produce to increase export dollars.
(6) Is this aim part of an overall strategy to convert current conventional systems to a more ecologically sustainable basis; if not, why not.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) No. The Organic Produce Advisory Committee (OPAC) is an advisory committee to the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service (AQIS). The Committee is chaired by AQIS and its members include representatives of key industry organisations, State Government agencies, and consumer organisations.
(2) The charter of OPAC is:
to provide advice to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy and the Department on the organic produce industry with emphasis on development and control;
to develop national standards and certification procedures for organic produce;
to provide a mechanism through which AQIS can facilitate trade in organically grown produce by:
providing endorsement of trade descriptions of such produce, and
negotiating with trading partners on exports;
to protect consumers and enhance the development of the industry through the alignment of import, export and domestic standards and requirements for organic produce.

(3) OPAC developed the National Standard for Organic and Bio-dynamic Produce which was released in February 1992 by Simon Crean, Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. At that time, the Honourable Minister indicated that the National Standard would provide the minimum requirements for all exports of organic produce.

For the domestic market the National Food Authority (NFA), as the responsible agency, has been requested by both industry and AQIS to develop labelling provisions for organic foods for inclusion in the Australian Food Standards Code. A submission to the NFA, prepared by AQIS at the request of OPAC, proposes that the National Standard form the basis for such provisions.
(4) The National Food Authority is represented on OPAC.

(5) The Federal Government responded to the increasing world demand for organic produce in 1989 when the peak advisory council to the then Minister for Primary Industries, the Honourable John Kerin, endorsed a series of recommendations submitted by AQIS on accessing niche markets overseas. One of these recommendations led to the establishment of OPAC. Australia was the first country outside of the European Community (EC) to develop a national standard recognised as equivalent to the stringent EC regulations on organic production. In January 1993, following lengthy negotiations between AQIS and EC officials, Australia was included as one of only five approved third countries for the supply of organic product into the EC. AQIS has subsequendy introduced an accreditation program for organic certification organisations which is acceptable to the EC and will form the basis for exports to other major markets.

Further, in the July 1992 Government statement, `Australian Agrifood Industries', a range of measures was announced to boost exports of high quality fresh and processed foods, particularly to Asia. The Clean Food Export Program is a key element of the Government's initiatives in this area. The program aims to increase exports by reinforcing Australia's reputation as a source of clean food, and by implementing appropriate codes of practice to ensure consistent delivery of high quality, clean foods. Total funding of $5 million is to be applied over the period 1992/93—1994/95.

(6) The Commonwealth, together with State Governments, is committed under the National Strategy for Ecologically Sustainable Development to facilitating agricultural industries which contribute to: long term productivity and Australia's economic well-being; the biological and physical resource base on which agricultural industries depend; and, improving human health and safety. This is being achieved through the promotion of initiatives which support the sustainable use of Australia's land and water resources.

Decade of Landcare Plans produced by the Commonwealth and each State provide for a national approach to sustainable land use. The National Landcare Program (NLP) is the primary Commonwealth program for implementing the Decade Plans. It has as its principal objective the implementation of sustainable natural resource management. Under the NLP, solutions to specific natural resource management programs are developed and implemented by land managers, landcare groups and catchment managers on a local and regional basis. Organic production systems are one of a number of approaches which may be applied by these groups to achieve sustainable agricultural systems.

Organic practices are adaptable to any production system, although it may not always be possible to attain full organic status for specific commodities because of geographic or other prevailing conditions. The influence of such practices may be seen in conventional farming systems through the adoption of low input practices, integrated pest management, contouring and, greater use of crop rotations and green manure.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, upon notice on 13 September 1993:

PARA.TAB: (1) Is phosphine used as a pesticide in fumigating grain for storage.
(2) Is phosphine a genotoxic chemical, that is, potentially able to react with genetic material to cause cancer.
(3) What assurances can be given that grain treated with this chemical contains no residue as a result of treatment.
(4) What are the measures taken to ensure that operators using this chemical are not placed at undue risk of exposure.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) Yes. It is widely used in Australia for this purpose.
(2) No. A recent study of phosphine by Worksafe Australia found no potential for phosphine to cause damage to human genetic material.

(3) The National Residue Survey, which is conducted by my Department, has been monitoring phosphine levels in grain for many years. In the period from 1 January 1989 to 31 May 1993, a total of 1120 samples of wheat were analysed, of which only one sample showed any trace of phosphine, and that reading was one-tenth of the approved maximum residue limit.
In addition, the Australian Wheat Board also carries out testing for phosphine from time to time. These tests have never detected the presence of phosphine.

(4) Phosphine is used on grain in two situations. At bulk grain handling facilities, phosphine gas is supplied to the grain. The systems in use in such facilities are firmly focused on worker safety, and operators are provided with appropriate training and suitable safety equipment.

In on-farm fumigation using phosphine, primary producers place pellets, which generate phosphine, into the grain storage container. Product labels carry advice on use, and this can be supplemented by suitable instructional booklets, which are widely available.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, upon notice, on 28 September 1993:

PARA.TAB: With reference to the amendment on 3 June 1992 to the Microwave Distribution System (MDS) Band Plan which placed a temporary embargo on the grant of MDS licenses for applications received after 2 June 1992:
(1) What was the date on which these applications were called for and what was the original closing date before the embargo was imposed.
(2) Why was the embargo imposed and on what basis was the embargo agreed to.
(3) What notice, if any, was given to any applicants or potential applicants prior to the embargo being imposed on 3 June 1993.
(4) Why were applicants from Amsol and BNTV, which were received after 2 June 1993, accepted by the Government although they were not lodged until after the embargo was imposed.

(5) (a) What was the legal advice which claims `the circumstances of [the applications made by these two companies] would make it difficult to not accept them as being `current' at the time the embargo was imposed'; (b) who provided this advice; and (c) please provide a copy of that advice.
(6) Were any other applications accepted after the embargo date; if so, who were they received from and why were they accepted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Communications has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question, based on information provided by the Spectrum Management Agency:

PARA.TAB: (1) Prior to the embargo which took effect on 3 June 1992, all applications for MDS licences were accepted and processed pursuant to the provisions of Section 24 of the Radiocommunications Act 1983. Applications were accepted on a `first come first served' basis on the initiative of the applicant and were not subject to any specific invitation or prescribed closing date.

(2) The embargo was imposed to prevent speculative acquisition of remaining available radiofrequency spectrum in the band assigned for MDS in the period leading up to the lifting of the pay television moratorium on 1 October 1992. The embargo was applied by means of an amendment to the MDS Band Plan pursuant to the provisions of Section 19 of the Radiocommunications Act 1983. As from October 1992 the grant of MDS licences has been subject to determinations by the Minister for Transport and Communications under Subsection 92A(1) of the Radiocommunications Act 1983 which prescribe that a price-based allocation system will apply.
(3) No prior notice of the embargo was given as this would have encouraged speculative applications contrary to the purpose of the embargo.

(4) An application by Amsol Pty Ltd was posted in Melbourne on 1 June 1992 and received on 3 June 1992. An application by BNTV Pty Ltd was faxed to the Department of Transport and Communications on 4 June 1992, confirming a telephone call to the Department made on 2 June 1992. Legal advice indicated that the full circumstances in which these two applications were submitted constituted a basis on which the applications could be regarded as having been lodged before 3 June 1992.

The legal advice referred to in (4) above was obtained from the Department of Transport and Communications' Legal Unit. The legal advice canvasses specific cases and it would be inappropriate to provide a copy of the advice.
